name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for the joint discussion on: - the report by Pilar del Castillo Vera, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, research and energy on the european Parliament and Council's proposed directive establishing the European Electronic Communications Code (redesign) (COM(2016)0590 - C8-0379/2016 - 2016/0288 (COD)) (A8-0318/2017), and - the Report by Ev-en Toen, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy on the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council establishing the Body of European Electronic Communications Regulators (COM(2016) 0591 - C8-0382/2016 - 2016/0286 (COD)) (A8-0305/2017).

name: Pilar del CASTILLO VERA
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Mr Ansip, ladies and gentlemen, we are voting today on the new European regulation on electronic communications. The last is from 2009 and since then there have been extraordinary technological changes, changes that have affected business models, the interests of users, the experiences of consumers themselves and which have absolutely transformed the electronic communications landscape.  We must begin by saying that connectivity has always been the precondition, the necessary condition for the extraordinary advances that have been known in humanity, especially in the twentieth century of technology.  Consider, for example, what situation we would be in if there had not been an infrastructure of roads, railways, radio, telephony or air transport: surely the situation of our economy and the development of our society would be very, very different.  Today we are in a similar situation, where connectivity is a necessary and urgent condition for the European Union to harness the potential of the most advanced digital technologies, such as the Internet of Things, big data, artificial intelligence, robotics, quantum computing and much more.  They are technologies that are making their way, that are making their way in an extraordinary way, at a very, very high speed and are waiting to have the capacity to connect in order to be able to develop fully and thus deploy their full potential for new opportunities for the economy and society. Consider the possibilities for 5G development that it can offer us for the future — for the very near future — such as: performing long-distance surgical interventions; high-risk work that can be done from a safe place; or for farmers themselves, for the agriculture sector, which, by obtaining real-time data, can greatly improve farms.  For all these reasons, the new regulatory framework, in addition to the digital market, strengthens and places connectivity as the backbone of this regulation of the electronic communications market. It includes a number of measures to do so, measures that will attract investment, to make investment more attractive, such as co-investment models, better and more harmonised radio spectrum management, improving the duration of licences with a minimum duration, for example, of twenty years.  The Code further obliges all Member States to release and allow the use of the well-known 5G bands before the end of 2020 and, in consumer protection, establishes and improves emergency services, giving more opportunities for location in the event of a disaster, as well as introducing a very significant reduction in pan-European calls, intra-European calls , which, after the disappearance of roaming costs, is also very good news for citizens.  In sum, the European Electronic Communications Code is intended to play a key role in the digitisation of Europe and does so by putting connectivity at its heart.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Commissioner, let me start by thanking my colleague Pilar Del Castillo, who has done an excellent job under the Code. The Code and BEREC are closely intertwined, from the outset, Mrs Pilar Del Castillo and I have acted in a coordinated manner and have finally successfully concluded both proposals on a joint trilogue.  The Code presents berec with a number of new tasks that needed to be reflected in this report. The issue of special voting rules in the Board of Regulators has proved to be the most problematic point of the final trilogue and we have been greatly helped by the Commission as a mediator. Under the agreement, BEREC also hosts a chapter originally agreed in the Code for the Regulation of Calls within the European Union. It would therefore not be fair for this to be attributed to the outcome of the BEREC report. In general, I appreciate the compromise on the Code, I believe that it will facilitate the development of high-speed networks as a 5G precondition, as Pilar Del Castillo mentioned here just now. As our political group, I am glad that the resulting text leaves more flexibility for Member States in the spectrum and does not ultimately include a single authorization or a so-called double lock. Back to the heart of the berec report – the structure of BEREC and the BEREC support office was the result of a political agreement in 2009. Now the Commission has proposed to link them up by creating one large agency. As rapporteur, I tried at the beginning to gather information from various sources on whether this double structure was working, and my colleagues and I also carried out a mission by the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy to Riga. I am not in support of fundamental dramatic changes where something works well, and positive reviews have strongly prevailed here within BEREC. We also reflected concerns about the independence of regulators' decisions. We need real independence from regulators, both at member state level and in the European Union. Their distance from national governments and the European Commission was therefore important. I therefore proposed to reject the merger of BEREC and the BEREC support office and to focus on minor improvements as the discussion took place. Nevertheless, the European Parliament was divided on this fundamental issue, with some political groups preferring the link proposed by the Commission. Finally, the new tasks for BEREC set out in the Code, namely the newly introduced arbitration decision-making of BEREC, which would be legally binding, helped us to compromise in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. As a result, BEREC would also receive legal personality. In the context of trilogues with the Council and the Commission, we then proceeded the other way around – in the end there will be no legally binding decisions in the Code, and therefore we maintain the current structure and the status of BEREC as an independent association of regulators. It is clear to me that all colleagues cannot, in fact, be entirely satisfied on this most basic issue. In any case, my big thanks go to all the shadow rapporteurs. I think that we have managed to agree a sensible modernisation of the rules so that BEREC is effective, can carry out new tasks from the Code, contribute to the single application of the regulatory framework for telecommunications and to the opening up of the Single Market of the European Union.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. – Madam President, today we are giving our citizens concrete achievements. This 500—page law will mean a future of cheaper calls, safer citizens, faster internet, better access for persons with disabilities, and a final confirmation that internet access is no longer a luxury but a right. From 15 May next year, everyone will be able to make cheaper calls. International EU rates have been unjustly high for too long. The end of roaming in Europe was a great success, but we stopped half way. I am proud and humbled to have led Parliament to complete the final step in creating an EU where country codes are obsolete and where consumers can call anyone without worrying about the price. Also, every citizen will now have a right to an affordable internet connection. As more and more services, including government services, go online, it is unthinkable to be without internet access today. The internet must be seen as a utility like electricity and gas. Finally, I want to highlight the introduction of the mobile public warning system. In the 21st century, citizens should not have to rely on rumours to know what is happening in the case of an attack or emergency. There is much more, but I’m running out of time, so let me just thank the rapporteur, Pilar del Castillo Vera, and all my fellow shadow rapporteurs who worked on this proposal.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, updating the EU’s telecom rules is an essential step in building the Digital Single Market. For that, two pieces of legislation will be vital: the European Electronic Communications Code and the Regulation on BEREC (the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications). Together, they create the legal conditions that will allow us to meet Europe’s growing connectivity needs and to boost its competitiveness. We have succeeded in providing a legal environment for European telecoms that is both investment-friendly and pro-competitive. This is something very much to be welcomed. We should not underestimate the significance of this achievement. I would like to thank the rapporteurs, Pilar del Castillo Vera, Dita Charanzová and Evžen Tošenovský, for their impressive work. The code will lay the groundwork for developing 5G across Europe. It will make sure that 5G radio spectrum is available in the EU by the end of 2020 and will give operators predictability for spectrum licensing for at least 20 years. That includes better coordination of planned radio spectrum assignments and specific rules regarding radio spectrum fees. Rolling out new, very high-capacity networks is crucial for putting Europe at the forefront of digital innovation. The code’s new provisions, including those on core investments, offer strong incentives for deploying these new networks. The new rules ensure close cooperation between the Commission and BEREC on supervising measures related to the new access provisions. Europeans expect an internet connection that is fast, reliable, affordable and safe. The code will allow that expectation to become a reality. Consumers will benefit from advanced services and from better online protection. It harmonises end-user protection of electronic communications in the EU, whether in relation to bundled services, switching providers or stronger security against hacking. We have extended the end-user protection obligations to web-based services where that makes sense. Two more important things are to be welcomed: firstly, that the universal service will guarantee that everyone can afford access to an adequate broadband internet service; and secondly, that end-users with disabilities are guaranteed equivalent access to communications. We have also strengthened people’s protection in emergency situations, including through the retrieval of more accurate caller location. The forthcoming vote will be a significant step for the Digital Single Market and for Europe.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. – Madam President, the single market for electronic communications is at the heart of the digital economy and it is therefore essential to strengthen the electronic communications sector and provide high-quality connectivity in all sectors of the European economy. In particular, BEREC aims to improve the harmonisation of legislation and strengthen the independence of national regulatory authorities. I believe that the current institutional set-up, based on the independence of national regulatory authorities from the Commission and other Union institutions, allows BEREC to provide independent and expert advice and to continue cooperation with other Union institutions. Through its opinions and recommendations, BEREC may advise Union and national regulatory authorities on how to make more efficient use of electronic communications, highlight shortcomings in their use, supervise consumer protection and also ensure cooperation between other regulatory authorities. I therefore support the retention of the dual governance structure and it is important that the composition of BEREC should consist of representatives of individual national regulatory authorities, which contributes to better regulation between Member States, thereby promoting the development of a market in the Union for citizens.

name: Petra KAMMEREVERT
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her It is particularly important to the Committee on Culture that BEREC has the task of ensuring cultural and media diversity. Ensuring that access to communications networks is not discriminated against, whether through mergers of companies or technological innovations, has a safeguarding effect on diversity. Doing everything possible to treat every form of data traffic as equally as possible also has a strong effect on diversity. Despite initial scepticism, it can be said that BEREC has done a good job of maintaining net neutrality, thereby serving all Europeans. Ensuring neutrality, fairness and non-discrimination remains a major challenge, and today we are equipping BEREC with the necessary means to address this. The European Code of Electronic Communications is also drafted in the sense of non-discrimination. It is essential that all citizens have access to an affordable, universal, available Internet connection. The switch to digital reception is also important for radio as an important source of information. We therefore welcome the fact that all new cars will have to be equipped with digital terrestrial broadcasting for reception over the next two years. It is also to be welcomed that frequencies continue to be recognised as a public good in the Code.

name: Morten PETERSEN
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Madam President! We are in the midst of the new digital age and this places extra great demands on all of us to create the best possible framework for European users and European citizens. Our community is best for Europe's citizens and businesses when we are free to travel, trade and, above all, communicate across borders without obstacles. And that is what this telecommunications package is all about. We in the Liberal Group are pleased that we have succeeded in ensuring a faster and better Internet throughout Europe. We are pleased that it has succeeded in making it cheaper to call from one EU country to another, and we are very pleased that this proposal establishes a so-called reverse 112 system where we as citizens can get messages on our mobile phone in the event of an emergency. I personally think that the reverse 112 system is a great idea. During the horrific terrorist attack in Brussels, I remember how we did not know what was happening other than what we could read about through the news, but with the reverse 112 system we as citizens will be able to receive secure information from our authorities. In concrete terms, it could save lives for the benefit of all of us, for the benefit of Europeans, and we should be pleased about that, so much thanks for working with the other rapporteurs. This is a very sensible package that we can adopt here today!

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the – Dear colleagues, i would like to thank you very much for your work. As always, the world is changing. It's always been the case. During the first industrial revolution came new technologies that radically changed people's lives. If in the past people mostly worked in rural jobs, perhaps in forestry, in fisheries, new industries, factories, completely new working environments, our great-grandfathers, say, adapted to such conditions. We are living today in the next era of revolution, the so-called digital revolution, when the whole labour market changes again, all opportunities are changing. And if perhaps even 50 years ago many people literally worked in factories, robots are working in factories now, but people are the ones who make up the robots of the future, creating future opportunities. The challenge for us in the age of this digital revolution is that these are already technologies that have evolved. In Europe, we have a very sly market: in each Member State, things were a little different. It has also affected telecommunications and so on. But we know that Europe is competing in the global global market: the United States, with a single market of 330 million people, is China with 1.3 billion inhabitants. In Europe, we have enormous potential with 500 million, but a great deal of squabble. What this telecom pack, which we are talking about today, is a common approach, a common infrastructure for the whole area. So for consumers, this means telephone calls that do not have to be paid more expensively when travelling elsewhere in Europe, i.e. a single market for telecommunications. This means simplified, secure internet access. And for the industry, this means clear conditions for further developing technologies, such as the so-called 5G technologies, which will be the key to the future for autonomous car driving, healthcare and so on. We support this package, we support our economic development. Thank you for your attention!

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, one of the great drivers we have in our society that is spreading good is information technology. It has made our lives easier, brought with it new services and technologies, but we haven’t seen it all yet. The change has only just begun. This morning I came from Paris where I had the privilege to head the Parliament’s delegation to the Internet Governance Forum. Europe is at the forefront of the digital revolution but we need to cooperate with the rest of the world and we have to make sure that we have common goals for the right use of the digital tools. To deliver that digital revolution, we need this European Electronic Communications Code. If we want better digital services, we need better digital infrastructure. If we want connected cars or if we want e—health solutions, we need fast 5G. If we want our schools and universities and businesses to thrive, we need gigabit connectivity to use artificial intelligence and cloud computing. If we want to see the next ground—breaking services to make our lives better, we need fast internet connections for all homes and mobile devices. Internet connectivity is a modern right for every European and we have defined what a very high capacity network is. It’s not just in these connections that you see that you are connected but your program doesn’t work anyway. We need fibre to boost things and we need more very good connections. The key problem we’re trying to solve here is how we can get faster, better and cheaper connections. We need this for all Europeans while maintaining the right conditions for investment so that it can happen. The outcome here today, agreed after eight months of trialogues and negotiations, reflects the Parliament position well. We have achieved the goal of promoting investments while making sure that consumers in Europe retain the right to choose their operators. The new rules for co—investments are complex and some details will be up to national implementation, but the message is clear: there can be no turning back to the monopolies. One key technology for revolution is 5G and very fast connections. It’s high time for Member States to see that we need common rules for spectrum as well, and we need the spectrum bands to be out there at the latest by 2020. With this legislation I am very happy to continue to ‘roam like home’ but to turn it the other way round, so next summer everyone can enjoy calling friends in other EU countries for a maximum of 19 cents per minute. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". My question goes in the direction: do you think it will be possible to buy a SIM card in all European countries in the long term? At present, we can only buy SIM cards permanently in our own Member States. By when will it be possible for us to have a genuine digital single market?  And do you think that something can change on a global level? We are currently paying EUR 7 for 1 GB in Europe, and if you are outside Europe it costs EUR 19 500. Do you think that progress can still be made here?

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: blue-card answer. – I very much share Mr Rübig’s worries. I would like the Commission to react quickly. As we will see the roaming follow—up this year, we see that mobile virtual network operators (MVNOs) cannot join the same retailer operating markets, but then the wholesale market prices are too high – even the ones we agreed with the Council and took down a lot last year. It still shows us that the retail markets for consumers get cheaper prices than the wholesale market caps that we agreed and halved the proposal from the Commission. Even the Council wanted to get it higher. So it’s of the utmost importance that we get this functioning, and we need new legislation for that.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: on behalf of the ECR Club. – Dear Chairman, the telecommunications services market is changing rapidly. New products and services and changed consumer habits require an adaptation of the existing legal framework. Faster, better quality, more flexible and cheaper services with maximum consumer protection, their data and privacy must be at the heart of our action in this area.  Telecoms have long been a powerful oligopoly within national borders, slowing down service development in some member states and putting consumers in an unenviable position. That is why I believe that one of our priorities must be to create a single market for telecom services where competition would be more pronounced and services to end users better and cheaper. As this process progresses, I logically consider the establishment of a European Telecommunications Agency to oversee the single market for telecom services. (The Speaker agreed to answer the question by raising the blue card on the basis of Article 162(8) of the Code of Health. Rules of procedure.)

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Madam President, my dear colleague, I agree with what you have said. You talked about data protection, consumer protection. I agree that we need to have a European code, but what do you think: are we in a situation where we have an infrastructure in all areas? What can we do with the countryside? What can we do with citizens who do not have the skills to use? Do you not think that this European code should also be supported by investment, by a budget for remote areas and for rural areas for the knowledge and skills of citizens in operation?

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Of course we do, of course we need to ensure safety so that people in rural areas stay in their homes. We have to provide them with all the necessary infrastructure, but we'll only provide that once we stop politicizing everything we touch.

name: Julia REDA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, the Telecom Package has undergone quite a transformation since it was first proposed in 2016. First, it was based on the strange notion that the best way to get companies to invest in broadband internet was to reduce competition and to offer deregulation in return for investment. Even the most conservative economists would predict the exact opposite, namely that competition drives innovation and doesn’t stifle it. The Verts/ALE Group has been at the forefront of resisting any deregulation agenda and ensuring that telecom regulators have the necessary powers to regulate. The final deal, thanks to Parliament, is much more balanced than the first draft and is much more ambitious in the field of consumer rights. With the Electronic Communications Code, we’re making real improvements to the transparency of contracts, to the ability to take your phone number with you when you switch providers, and to ensuring that everyone has affordable internet access, also recognising community networks. We are making real improvements to people’s security, too, by introducing systems that allow people to receive automatic notifications on their phones in the case of disasters. There’s a reason why telecom companies have quite a terrible reputation among consumers. Many people in Europe have the choice between just a small number of providers, and often all the available options are bad. Bad surprises, in the form of ridiculously high phone bills, slow speeds and difficulties in switching providers, are still common. When we told Europeans years ago that we would abolish roaming, they thought that would mean that wherever you called in Europe, and wherever you used the internet, you would pay the same price. What they soon had to learn was that calling somebody in another EU country is not roaming. That’s an intra—EU call – something completely different – where higher prices are considered okay. So it is a great success for Parliament that the proposals from the Greens and the left to abolish charges for intra—EU calls have made it into the final deal, at least in the form of a price cap. That will bring European consumers one step closer to a real single market. A missed opportunity in the Telecom Package is that of turning the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications (BEREC) into a fully—fledged EU regulator. The BEREC Regulation makes some modest improvements, but this Parliament and national governments failed to take the important step of creating an EU regulator with all the powers needed. It’s a missed opportunity because global threats to our open internet are becoming bigger. It’s not just that the US has abolished Federal net neutrality rules. It’s not just that, in Paris this week, Mr Macron said that net neutrality must not stand in the way of internet regulation. No, Mr Macron, net neutrality is internet regulation, and it’s precisely the kind of regulation we need to strengthen. Although the European Union has enshrined net neutrality in law, it has failed to provide a clear and unequivocal ban on zero-rating. The consequence is that today, according to BEREC’s own figures, zero—rating still exists in most EU countries and we need to take further steps to ensure that an open internet is available to everybody. I hope that this Telecom Package will be a step in the right direction.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, this legislation on the code is indeed very positive. I would like to highlight some, including the independence of national regulatory authorities, a more effective and more regulated electronic communications system (this is fundamental), greater guarantees for consumers, especially with regard to communications on charges related to communications between different countries, higher speed and 5G, but we also need to ensure equal access, we need to ensure that all this reaches all citizens. There are also dimensions that have to do, for example, with the issues of updating the rules of telecommunications and with the response that needs to be given to connectivity between different citizens and in different countries. We are talking about a package that certainly seeks to modernise the current telecommunication rules, but none of this can be done so on the basis of competition. The need for regulation has already been mentioned here and I would like to draw attention to another issue that seems to me fundamental: communications are a very sensitive area and therefore it is not only code infrastructure that we are talking about, but also what threats to the maintenance and management of communications can be. We must therefore ensure that the possibility of always redeeming basic networks for the provision of communications services, such as emergency management networks or, for example, civil protection or audiovisual signal, is maintained for the public sector. This is critical to prevent some disasters from happening in our communications.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the world of telecommunications is changing rapidly. We have stronger connections, competition is increasingly complex, there is convergence of fixed and mobile networks and demand for wireless data has exploded. Today, in response to these significant structural changes, we are preparing to launch a European telecommunications code. However, while we must encourage investment in high-capacity networks, we must ensure greater competitiveness of the markets, lowering prices and raising the quality of services for consumers and businesses.  I am glad that a number of our demands have been accepted, which are in the direction of better protection for users. First of all, the reduction of the cost of international calls between countries of the European Union. These tariffs are in no way linked to the real costs incurred by suppliers. That is why we have called for any price difference between domestic and intra-European calls to be eliminated. Unfortunately, this request has only been immediately granted, but it is important that a ceiling of 19 cents per minute has been set for intra-European calls. This, for example, in Italy will mean a drop of almost half the price of these calls. I hope that consumers will be aware of this change and that this will be the first step towards a complete reduction in the cost of intra-European calls.  Other important successes for consumer protection are the more transparent bills, so that the bill makes an explicit statement of who the suppliers are and the length of the services that are then charged, so that it is clear what we are paying for. The change of operator will be easier, because maintaining the same number and therefore portability is a key element of consumer freedom of choice and effective competition. Therefore, a new number must be made available within one working day and there must be refunds proportionate to the delays suffered. Certain times for the transfer of the line, so that it is agreed with the user and is done at the time it has been decided. Finally, it is important that support for users with disabilities has been stepped up, for example, by ensuring access to all contractual information and emergency services. I believe that this is an important step towards an accessible and transparent digital single market.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has I would like to thank Pilar del Castillo very much for your reports. With both the electronic communications code and the BEREC Regulation, they have helped to ensure that Europe will in future have more legal and planning certainty in the field of telecommunications, that the Digital Single Market will be further developed, particularly as far as BEREC is concerned. They have ensured that more flexibility in regulation is maintained by Member States without restricting regulatory competence.  As Commissioner Ansip has already mentioned, the development of digital infrastructure and digital skills are now essential drivers for competitiveness and therefore also for growth and jobs in Europe. In Austria alone, in my own country, investments of EUR 10 billion in digital infrastructure would trigger GDP growth of 15% or EUR 58 billion, according to a study by Future Business Austria presented on Monday this week. Digital infrastructure includes the construction of 5G – we have already heard it today – high-speed Internet, the possibility of autonomous driving, the Internet on the Internet of things, artificial intelligence and much more. An essential prerequisite for this is the European Electronic Communications Code, which will help to promote broadband expansion, particularly in rural areas. I think there was a question about that today. But not only that. The new Communication Code will also create essential conditions for investments in superfast Internet to take place in the first place. And how does he do that? This is by ensuring that sufficient 5G frequencies are available for network expansion over the next two years and that network operators have at least 20 years of planning certainty for spectrum licences.  But there are advantages not only for the producer, but also for consumers – it has already been mentioned today: the code will ensure that international calls within the EU – we still call it international calls – can cost a maximum of 19 cents per minute, that easier service switching and call-by is possible, that cheap communication services are available, that there is transparency, that security is increased in relation to malicious programmes and that citizens are better protected in emergencies. , by making emergency calls more traceable by means of caller location and also by issuing a public warning with a profile of "telephony". (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Madam President, what is the European Union really seeking with the renewed legislation on electronic communications? Does it want broadband infrastructure, radio spectrum and, in general, the huge development of science and technology to reduce the toil of workers and make their lives better? Quite the opposite! It wants to guarantee investment and ensure the profitability of European monopolies in competition with rival monopolies in China, the United States and India. That's why it completely liberates the market. It privatizes what is left of the state and gives them "dowry" all public infrastructure and popular property. The people and young people have bitter experience of the consequences of the liberalisation of the markets. Their access to traditional electronic communications will remain expensive, while their access to new technologies, services and products will be virtually impossible. Workers will be able to freely enjoy the achievements of science and technology, as long as they take out their monopolies, associations and power to live the life they deserve and can live.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I also congratulate the rapporteurs. I remember a student coming to me in 2006 during the Austrian Presidency and complaining about the disproportionate rip-off tariffs that exist in this area when you make cross-border calls. And I was actually proud of the fact that the European Commission delivered and that within seven months a regulation that was valid for the whole of Europe came into force and which was signed by the President-in-Office of the Council, Merkel – the German Presidency followed – together with our team in the plenary of the European Parliament. That was the first step. We have set new standards here, because for the first time we have succeeded in introducing a sunset clause. As a result, we now more or less have the fifth roaming regulation. We have introduced a price cap, which is a definition of the level at which fraud starts. Under this price cap, of course, free competition can develop. But we still do not have free competition between the Member States. Virtual operators in particular need access to market-compliant prices. I call on the Commission to do so. Here the glide path we have developed is too slow. I believe that these prices, which are set against each other, should be market-compliant. It is therefore clear that, with BEREC, we in Europe have an institution that must develop in line with the market in the future. I would ask the Commission to check this.

name: Constanze KREHL
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The Commission's proposal on BEREC aimed to create an independent BEREC Agency, thereby overcoming the existing inefficient dual structure. My group has always supported this objective because we are convinced that the future European internal market for telecommunications needs a clear and strong administrative structure in which BEREC should play a central role as an agency. However, following the conclusion of the negotiations in Parliament and with the Council, we note that the time for this change is probably not yet the time. In particular, we regret that BEREC does not have legal personality with the text now put to the vote and therefore cannot continue to take legally binding decisions. We consider this to be a short-sighted decision, because many rules will still have to be harmonised and technical solutions will have to be found on the road to the internal market. We therefore consider the text as a whole to be too unambitious and too focused on maintaining the status quo. However, what makes the revised BEREC Regulation acceptable to me in sum is something quite different, namely the inclusion of the issue of foreign calls in the text. The capping of the prices for calls to other EU countries, achieved in the trilogue negotiations on the Code, from May 2019 to 19 cents per minute is a great success for the European Parliament. The S&D Group in particular has been working for many years to reduce telephone costs for European consumers. We can rightly be proud of this agreement, which is another milestone following the abolition of roaming in 2017.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the political objective of this telecommunications legislative package is to create the large and liberalised European telecommunications market. The European Union's electronic communications regulatory body, to which the European Commission intended to grant agency status, was set up to help set up technical and political guidelines for completing this large open and liberalised market. The contradictions between the interests of the Member States, especially some Member States, and the interests of those who want a fully liberalised communications sector are obvious, removing what they consider to be the cumbersome national interests. It is resofound that this was a public sector, dominated by public companies in several European countries, public because strategic and, because strategic, public should be again.  The damage resulting from privatisation and liberalisation for populations, national interests and the public interest is clearly visible; benefits only for multinationals in the sector, which promote and benefit from monopolistic concentration on a European scale. This is a path that should be reversed and not deepened.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8)).

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: blue-card question. – Mr Ferreira, I disagree with your proposal that, to turn the clock back, we would need more European legislation. At the Congress of the Internet Governance Forum (IGF) I met a farmer from Spain who was very disappointed that the regulator there doesn’t support local community networks, building networks for places where there is no connectivity. They are waiting for the incumbent to maybe build there later and they don’t get help from the national regulator. This was one case where they wanted the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications (BEREC) to have the opportunity also to enhance competition inside the countries. How do you see this?

name: João FERREIRA
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. – Ms. Kumpula-Natri, I thank you for your question and what I can answer to you, from the experience of my country, Portugal, is like the privatisation of a strategic company that dominated the sector, which occupied a top-notther position from the point of view of innovation and which fulfilled a set of missions of public interest, called into question the public interest and , in practice, led to the dismantling of this company, now dominated by a large French telecommunications group. This is what liberalisation means that you and other groups advocate. It is losing public control over a strategic sector of the economy, at the loss to the national interest, to the population, to consumers, to businesses and to the public interest.

name: Jerzy BUZEK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I wanted, above all, to congratulate Vice-President Ansip, the entire European Commission and, above all, my colleagues in the European Parliament who negotiated what we are to vote on today. These are really great results. Please note that today we have gone further than the digital single market. That's what we dreamed of, but we've really almost done it. We need to think about the digital union, that is our task for the next five years. The best possible links, 5G network, consumer protection, international facilities, as well as start-ups, supporting companies. Let us remember that this is our economy, our future. Without this, we will not be competitive. We are also unable to achieve climate and energy targets without these solutions.  It is good that we take into account the geographical situation, because countries bordering outside with other European countries have difficulties with radio spectrum, and i am therefore pleased that this solution is also included in our decisions.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: – Illum huwa t-tmiem ta' battalja twila ħafna. Meta bdejna naħdmu fuq it-tneħħija tat-tariffi tar-roaming, kulħadd kien xettiku u bosta m'emmnux li dan huwa possibbli; iżda fil-fatt ġara.  Il-ġlieda tagħna ma waqfitx hemm u minkejja din ir-rebħa, komplejna naħdmu biex intejbu t-telekomunikazzjoni għaċ-ċittadini tagħna u biex inżidu l-benefiċċji f'dan il-qasam. L-għan aħħari kien li ntemmu l-ispejjeż eżorbitanti ta' telefonati bejn Stat Membru tal-Unjoni u ieħor. Erġajna, meta bdejna naħdmu fuq din il-leġiżlazzjoni u daħħalna l-idea tal-Inter-Union Calls, ħadd ma emmen li dan seta' jsir u b'hekk ma kienx hemm appoġġ, iżda xorta jibqa' l-fatt li rnexxielna.  Illum se nivvotaw għal leġiżlazzjoni li tistabilixxi limitu fuq il-prezz tat-telefonija bejn Stat Membru u ieħor, u mis-sena d-dieħla ċ-ċittadini Ewropej mhux se jkollhom għalfejn joqogħdħu jinkwetaw aktar dwar spejjeż eċċessivi meta jsiru telefonati għal Stat Membru ieħor. Irnexxielna wkoll ninkludu numru ta' punti importanti, fosthom: tejjibna d-drittijiet tal-konsumaturi u l-obbligi kontrattwali, ħarisna d-drittijiet tal-persuni b'diżabilità, u l-bżonn li nagħrfu li l-internet bażiku huwa affordabbli; huwa dritt universali. L-aħħar u mhux l-anqas, għall-ewwel darba għandna wkoll ftehim dwar sistema ta' reverse 112, li huwa numru li permezz tiegħu l-Istati Membri jkunu jistgħu jwissu u javżaw liċ-ċittadini permezz tal-mowbajls f'każ li jkun hemm emerġenzi u diżastri li huma imminenti jew li qed jiżviluppaw.  Fi żmien fejn iċ-ċittadini Ewropej huma dejjem aktar dubjużi dwar il-merti tal-proġett Ewropa nnifsu, illum għandu jitqies bħala vot li jista' jħalli impatt pożittiv fuq il-benefiċċji taċ-ċittadini tagħna Grazzi, New

name: Michał BONI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab We are talking about a solution that is crucial to the digital revolution. I thank the Commission, but mainly Pilar del Castillo and the rapporteurs for their great work. The Code gives us, users, new rights: access to the internet as a universal service regardless of location and income, a new cap on international call rates (it will be cheaper), access to the country's general alert system. Above all, however, the code lays the foundation for ultra-fast 5G internet, millisecond information and a future gigabit society with services that change everyone's quality of life, including in rural areas. It supports better radio spectrum sharing across the Union and investment, increasing legal predictability and spectrum access guarantees for operators. It ensures competitiveness through quality of service, not injunctions. It encourages co-investment. This would like to be introduced quickly and, in addition, the conditions for investment to be improved in practice and aligned between countries.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, dear Vice-President, the final adoption of the Telecom package marks an important stage in the modernisation of the legislative framework for the sector. Firstly, European citizens will be able to count on a more efficient and transparent telecommunications market with better access to services, particularly for disadvantaged people. Consumers will also benefit from more competition and more choice as they will be better protected from cyber threats. In addition, infrastructure investments, such as 5G and fibre, are being boosted to adapt our society to the new digital dimension and to increase the competitiveness of our economic system. Although we have not obtained the cancellation of the additional costs for fixed telephone calls in Europe, as our group proposed and as was the case with roaming, the ceiling of 19 cents per minute represents a significant reduction in costs for citizens and businesses.

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. Why is the telecoms package we are voting on today so important? We need fast Internet access, we need high-performance networks, we need fibre optic cables, we need 5G gigabit networks. Everyone is connected to everyone these days, everything will be networked over the network in the future. A good network infrastructure is the be-all and end-all, is the backbone for digital transformation, is important for every single citizen, is important for our businesses, for science, for administration. Nothing can be done without a high-performance network infrastructure. That is why it is important that we have good infrastructure, not only in the big cities, but throughout the country. The telecoms package that we are going to vote on today provides a good basis for the regulation to be issued on the fact that there will be more investment in the development of these efficient giga networks in the future. I believe that this is a very important concern. The second point I would like to raise is the good news for consumers: in future, there will be ceilings for the so-called intra-EU calls. So if you talk from home to other European countries, it will be cheaper .... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are all aware today that the challenge of global competition with Asian countries and America but also with other parts of the world, I am thinking of Canada, which runs a lot on digital, is precisely about the development of the digital economy, its ability to integrate manufacturing and services and its capacity for innovation. All this sees Europe facing a great challenge if it can withstand this competition.  Well, I think that this package, this impressive and important code, which my fellow Members personally but many other Members have negotiated, is a good framework that puts Europe in a position to face this competition for the development of the digital economy. I am thinking of investment and the rules that are in place here, because we need to develop this economy in all areas of advanced adequate connection network infrastructure.  Well, I think that this framework can be offered here, with the harmonisation of the harmonised management spectrum and also with the rules on investment. It will now be up to the operators to be able to play this challenge and put the necessary resources into it. Just two points: spectrum and international tariffs. We negotiated the fall in roaming – I was shadow rapporteur for my group – and I think that the reduction of international tariffs and the lowering goes in that direction for consumers.

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: Mr President, Commissioner, rapporteurs, thank you. From the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, I have been happy to actively contribute to this compromise. Bringing the connectivity to the fore, which actually goes into the first place, is the new communication. I would like to mention five points: 1. very happy with the maximum prices for calls and for sms;  2. the same rights for consumers when concluding and transferling a contract; 3. the fact that lapel 112, that warning system, which is alert.nl Dutch, is now being introduced europe-wide; 4. improving access for people with disabilities, large group, very important; 5. ensuring that speed, capacity, including in rural areas. That's how we make that step. The legislation was ten years old. The world doesn't stand still. We're up to date.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe is playing its future competitiveness in its Digital Agenda. With this reform we lay the foundation for boosting investments in high-speed networks and the deployment of 5G, crucial to making possible new services such as autonomous mobility or the new era of the Internet of Things. That is, new opportunities to drive innovation, economic activity and quality employment. But thanks to Parliament , I would like to congratulate Pilar del Castillo and the rapporteurs , we have introduced limits on the price of calls between Member States, which benefits all citizens. This is the case, breaking down barriers to communication, as Europe moves forward.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, firstly congratulations to the rapporteurs, especially my friend Pilar del Castillo, who has worked on this for many years, as indeed many more colleagues did. I think this is a great example of what the European Parliament can achieve. First of all, dealing with the whole roaming situation – the big operators didn’t want us to work on it, they challenged us, but we got there – and then we came along and we did geo-blocking and now we have the cap to calls’ costs to the European Union. This is a great success for the European Parliament, and indeed for citizens, because we are seen to deliver for them.  I think one area we need to focus on though, unfortunately – and in my own country especially – is the lack of high-speed broadband across the European Union. It needs to be tackled urgently, and for that reason we would hope that the Member States would up their contributions to the European budget so that we can tackle that at a European level and really make this work for everybody.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, since the 2009 regulatory review, the market for electronic communications services has changed dramatically. New actors such as WhatsApp, Telegram and Skipe are a direct consequence of the ability to rely on internet and digital access services.  The aim of the telecommunications package is to provide greater protection for consumers, for example by making it easier to switch operators or receive the necessary compensation. After the abolition of roaming, intra-European telephone calls will also cost much less thanks to the introduction of a maximum tariff of 19 cents. The structural change includes measures to stimulate investment in high-capacity networks and to adjust new frequencies to encourage mobile phone connectivity and the 5G network. For Europe, 5G is a prerequisite for joining the Gigabyte society. Industry 4.0, smart cities, research or health are just some of the prospects related to the exponential growth in demands for speed, security and increased connectivity.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission – Madam President, thank you to everyone who has made it possible for this package to become a reality. It will make a huge difference to people and business, to our society and economy. The European Commission is pleased that the European Parliament and the Council share many of the same objectives that will take us towards a gigabit society. Together we managed to agree on a balanced text that benefits and protects all Europeans and paves the way towards very high—capacity networks, including 5G. Although we have created a structure and environment for the next decade of European telecoms, our work is not yet done. In fact, it has just started. For the Commission, our focus will now be to make sure that the code is properly implemented, and we will also monitor this. EU Member States have two years to transpose and implement the rules. Not only must they do this on time, they must also do it correctly and efficiently. We will assist Member States in transposing the new rules into national law.

name: Pilar del CASTILLO VERA
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to begin now by thanking the shadow rapporteurs of other parliamentary groups: Miapetra Kumpula-Natri, Evsen Toenovsk, Kaja Kallas, Dita Charanzová and Julia Reda for the magnificent collaboration.  The cooperation with the Commission has been excellent and must be underlined. And I would also like to mention Jerzy Buzek, who presided masterfully, with great mastery, as he always does, of all the trilogs we had with the Council.  Today's debate on the European Electronic Communications Code is a great example of concrete solutions to specific problems that can only be addressed within the framework of the European Union, which we all need to address together.  In this case, solutions to a connection, to absolutely necessary connectivity if we want citizens and all economic sectors to have opportunities in this age of digitization.  I said this here yesterday, Angela Merkel: it is essential to tackle digitisation in the European Union.  And I stress: the added value of the European Union in addressing the great challenges of digitisation is essential; only together can we do it.  And this regulation is a magnificent example that we can present as a great achievement to European citizens, to voters who, in a few months, will participate again in European elections.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I think that we have agreed with the Council useful adjustments to the functioning of the Association of European Regulators BEREC and the BEREC Support Office, which will increase their effectiveness and protect the independence of regulators. I believe that the reality of telecommunications markets has not matured towards the need for more fundamental change, but this does not, of course, preclude debate in the future, quite the contrary. I would like to mention one more important issue related to BEREC. In the next step, it is necessary to ensure the personal reinforcement of this smallest Agency of the European Union in order to provide full support to telecommunications regulators. I therefore believe that, in the context of the negotiations on the 2019 budget, the Council will accept the relevant proposal from the European Parliament. Let me thank you once again for the cooperation of my colleagues, the shadow rapporteurs and everyone in our parliamentary team, including the assistants, advisers and administrators of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, because the cooperation was excellent and very complicated. I would like to thank my colleague Pilar Del Castillo once again, because the work with her has been truly excellent. I would like to thank the Bulgarian Presidency and, on the commission's part, Commissioner Gabriel and the Director-General of connect directorate-general Robert Viola, because they have actually made a very good proposal and very viable for the future, and I believe that this will be a very successful work for the future, which will bring very good and useful connections to the citizens of the European Union as time will run out.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday 14 November 2018. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. – I welcome the adoption of the European Electronic Communications Code agreed by the European Parliament with the Member States. It not only means updating existing legislation that needs to be adapted to new technologies in a rapidly changing environment, including the introduction of the 5G mobile standard, but also brings positive improvements for end consumers. I am glad that the Social Democrats have succeeded in rounding up long-term efforts to cap the price of calls from one EU member state to another, because the different price amounts have no justification in the internal market, as was pointless roaming, which we have also managed to abolish. This is also good news for consumers in our country, of course, because Czech operators are among the most expensive EU providers of electronic communications among the 28 EU Member States, according to European surveys. Personally, I consider it equally important to strengthen consumer protection, including the most vulnerable. The new Code guarantees that consumers with disabilities will not be disadvantaged in terms of quality of service provision, price or access to telecommunications services in general.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: Written. – Today, the European Parliament approves the telecoms package. The new rules will eliminate excessive tariffs for consumers, provide faster internet access and help facilitate the roll-out of a 5G network in Europe. The abolition of roaming has already made telephony and internet use abroad much more advantageous, but we have still been left with loose ends. It is still very expensive for someone to call a friend or colleague abroad. That is now being resolved by setting maximum tariffs, and I am very happy about that. We should not be silly: a lot of international communication is already happening online today, via Whatsapp for example. Nevertheless, this measure still affects 9% of European users, especially those who are not able to get away with it digitally. This package is a step forward towards a better internal market with greater protection for consumers. Now that the physical intermediate borders are gone, communication limits must also be abolished. It is also important that there should be a warning system throughout Europe in the event of a disaster or an attack. That reverse 112 will lead to you and I as citizens being notified if a serious incident has occurred in the area. That too can only be an advantage.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. – The European Union must prepare to take advantage of the ongoing digital revolution to affirm a common vision of technological development at the service of citizens.  The Paris Appeal, signed on 12 by 51 countries and hundreds of companies and organisations, to which the countries of the European Union have enthusiastically joined, should be a benchmark for the implementation of the Telecom package in the dimension of infrastructure development, regulation and access.  The package discussed today proposes an integrated, flexible approach, but with adequate levels of assurance and predictability for the viability of business investment. Another step is taken in deepening the digital single market by introducing a cap on the cost of phone calls in the intra-EU area, complementing the abolition of roaming surcharges. An alert system is also set up in the event of natural disasters or terrorist attacks, which is mandatory throughout the Union. I also point out that the WIFI4EU initiative, as a component of the Telecom package, is essential to strengthen fairness in european citizens' access to the high-quality internet, and its success and implementation quality should be a priority for the European Commission.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on the Bas Eickhout report, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, public health and food safety, on the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council setting performance standards for CO2 emissions for new heavy vehicles (COM(2018)0284 - C8-0197/2018 - 2018/0143 (COD)) (A8-0354/2018).

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, we are going to discuss here a file on regulating CO2 standards for heavy—duty vehicles for the first time in European history. I think that it is very important to stress that quite a few regions in the world are already putting CO2 standards in place, like the United States, Canada, China and Japan. They have all put CO2 regulation in place on the heavy—duty vehicle sector. Europe hasn’t done so yet. But we now have a proposal on the table from the Commission for CO2 standards for heavy—duty vehicles, and I think that is of course a very welcome development. Why? Because, if you look at heavy—duty vehicles, this is one of the sectors in Europe that is fast increasing and where CO2 emissions are also fast increasing. For now, total EU CO2 emissions are at a level of 6%, of which 25% is from road transport and it is increasing. We know that to meet our climate targets agreed in the Paris Agreement we need to go to zero emissions. This absolutely means that special attention needs to be paid to the heavy—duty vehicle sector, which this proposal is doing. For context, what we know is that, if you want to be Paris compatible, the heavy—duty vehicle sector needs to go in the direction of minus 40% by 2030. That analysis is from the Dutch institute, TNO, who say that for compatibility with the Paris Agreement, you need to go to those kind of reduction levels, and we’re not there yet. That’s also why we as a Parliament, in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI), agreed on raising the ambition level compared to what the Commission was proposing to a level that we say should be minus 20% by 2025 and minus 35% by 2030. I want to stress that this level of minus 20% by 2025 is, according to the impact assessment from the Commission, also possible with existing technologies. We know of course that, if you look to the longer term and we need to go to lower level ambitions, then we need to have an improvement in technologies because existing technologies can get to a level of minus 30%, but not much more than that. This means that we also need to prepare for new technologies in the heavy—duty vehicle sector and that’s why, also in ENVI, we have been proposing a zero and low—emission vehicle mandate to push the market into new technologies. The definition of zero and low—emission vehicles is broad, so it’s not necessarily electricity – it can also be other technologies. We are not subscribing to any technology, but are pushing just for a mandate on zero and low—emission vehicles of 5% by 2025, rising to 20% by 2030, in order to prepare the market for these new technologies to arrive in order to get to the deeper carbon cuts that are necessary for implementation of the Paris Agreement.  We are also putting forward a specific mandate for buses. I want to stress that this is important because in some of these markets the truck producers also produce buses and, if you have just one mandate and mix them all, you can create an unfair market. Therefore it is important to have separate mandates for buses and trucks because we know that on buses we can move much faster we can than on trucks. The mandate is also for all the trucks, not only the bigger ones, so that you can also achieve those zero and low—emission vehicles mandate for smaller trucks. My last point is that there was a big discussion on the fine. Let me say very clearly that we would like to stay very close to the Commission proposal because, if you lower the fine to such a level that it’s easy for the producer to pay it, what you are putting in place is just an additional price factor – a cost factor of production – and I don’t think that is what we want to do.  To conclude, I would like to thank all the shadows for all the good cooperation. On many compromises we had broad support, though not on others. We do of course see some amendments on the targets. That’s to be expected. But I would like to thank all the shadows for their great cooperation. I think the vote in ENVI, where 47 people were in favour and only six against, shows that we had broad support in that committee, which we hope also to maintain in the plenary.  (Applause)

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, it is a pleasure to be here today for the debate on the Commission proposal setting CO2 emission standards for heavy—duty vehicles. Following the debate last month on the proposal on CO2 emission standards for cars and vans, this is another key proposal to implement the 2030 climate and energy framework and continue to follow up on our commitments under the Paris Agreement.  Shortly before the upcoming COP24 in Katowice, the recent Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) special report on 1.5 degrees Celsius has once again demonstrated the urgency of reducing greenhouse gas emissions in all sectors. This is the first time ever that we are making a proposal to set CO2 standards for heavy—duty vehicles.  We do this for a number of reasons. First, we need to act to tackle the growing CO2 emissions from heavy—duty vehicles. Without action, these emissions – which represent almost 25% of road transport emissions – are set to increase by almost 10% by 2030. This new legislation will therefore help to reduce emissions from heavy—duty vehicles, while also supporting the Member States in meeting their binding national targets under the Effort Sharing Regulation. We also need to act to keep Europe’s industrial leadership. As has been said by the rapporteur, other countries, such as the United States, China and Japan, have already set emissions standards and competition in the global market is fierce. This legislation will contribute to Europe’s economic prosperity and global competitiveness, keeping us at the forefront of developing low—carbon solutions.  Finally, we need to act to support our transport companies’ savings on fuel. Fuel today accounts for about one quarter of transport companies’ operating costs. This legislation will bring fuel savings to the 600 000 small and medium—sized enterprises that operate in the European Union freight transport sector and employ almost three million people.  Your vote today is therefore instrumental to allow the adoption of this proposal during the current legislative term. We need to give a clear and stable regulatory signal to our industry as soon as possible because this will stimulate the right investments in the transition towards low and eventually zero—emission mobility. I therefore want to thank the rapporteur Mr Eickhout for his very hard work on this proposal, bringing together very rapidly the position of the European Parliament. I would also like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their efforts in the same direction.  The Commission proposal, underpinned by a thorough impact assessment, is both ambitious and realistic because it strikes the right balance between the three main policy objectives, which cannot be considered in isolation: first, achieving environmental benefits; second, bringing savings for transport operators; and third, supporting employment, growth and competitiveness.  As this is the first time this sector is being regulated and in view of the uncertainties on some key data, a stepwise approach is followed. The proposed 15% and 30% targets by 2025 and 2030 will bring significant environmental benefits, estimated at around 54 million tonnes of CO2 in the period 2020 to 2030. This is equivalent to the total annual emissions of Sweden. An early review is foreseen in 2022 to expand the scope and set the 2030 binding targets based on additional information on new technologies. Besides the targets, the proposal includes an incentive system to speed up the transition to zero— and low—emission vehicles.  The situation in this sector is different than for cars. There are virtually no large zero—emission trucks on European roads, and today 98% of the trucks rely on diesel, while almost all manufacturers have announced plans for zero—emission vehicles. We therefore propose to support the deployment of these technologies through a system of super credits, while preserving the environmental integrity of the CO2 targets.  Let me conclude by saying once again that the Commission remains fully supportive of the efforts of the European Parliament and the Council to conclude the discussion on this proposal within this legislative term. I look forward to continuing to work with you and bringing it to a successful conclusion.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: draftsman TRAN Committee. – Mr President, this is indeed the first time that CO2 emission limits have been set for lorries at European level. Unlike the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, the Committee on Transport considered that the emission limits proposed by the Commission were quite strict and demanding. By 2025, 15% less emissions and by 2030 30% less emissions. The Committee on Transport believes that these are extremely strict objectives. We supported these absolute figures from the Commission because, despite the fact that lorries have not had co2 emission limits, they are already very effective because fuel is such an expensive item of expenditure for hauliers that we have already strived for very good energy efficiency. In its own opinion, the Committee on Transport continues to criticise the fact that we are too focused on measuring emissions from the end of the exhaust pipe. We should be able to achieve a calculation method that would better look at energy consumption as a whole and, in the future, at the whole life cycle. Then we would get a better picture of transport emissions and we would also be better able to promote different alternative fuels.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: On the other: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for If we are to meet the climate challenge, we must reduce emissions from heavy transport – and radically. That is why it is good that we are now getting this draft legislation, so that for the first time in Europe we are taking seriously the issue of reducing emissions from heavy-duty vehicles. However, this is the first time we have done this, and that is why we should do so with a certain humility. After all, it is not we in this room, in this house, who are the ones who seriously reduce CO2 emissions from lorries and buses, but they are skilled technicians in vehicle manufacturers with the right conditions that are the ones who can make a difference. This is often and rapidly developed into a bidding process, where it is given the impression that those with the highest demands for emission reductions are the ones who are most beneficial to the climate. However, I would say that is wrong. It is they who find the right level and create the strongest incentives for technological development that make a real difference. We need to find a level that the technicians can deliver. Above all, we must ensure that the vehicles produced are vehicles that someone can afford to buy. It is only by replacing the old trucks and buses with high emission levels that we really reduce emissions. Unfortunately, I do not think that the Committee on the Environment succeeds in doing so, for three reasons in particular. The first is that we are saying that we will raise our ambition for 2025 to a 20% reduction. So these are trucks and buses that have already been developed, they are under development, and this will not change them. The only question is whether it is the case that there will be heavy fines. That is the second problem for those who fail. The last requirement, which we find difficult to understand how it will actually help to reduce emissions, is to ask for a special proportion of low-emission vehicles, in practice, electricity as early as 2025. We need a switch to electricity, but we in this house do not know and cannot decide exactly when that change in technology will take place. Therefore, here try to order technical development – I am sorry, but it is not possible. That is why we should vote against these demands.

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this regulation, which we support, fills a serious gap by setting common CO2 emission limits and standards for heavy goods vehicles – trucks, trucks, buses and coaches – which contribute to 25 % of the Union's total emissions, which will increase for the first time in Europe.  In addition to ambitious but achievable emission reduction targets of 20 % by 2025 and 35 % by 2030, we have introduced a road compliance test to have data on emissions and fuel consumption under real driving conditions, data that can be used by third parties for independent verification tests.  The Commission is also required to have a methodology for assessing emissions from a heavy vehicle throughout its life cycle, from design to scrapping. In order to improve the level of air quality in our cities, where more than 72 % of the population lives, there are two important innovations. The first concerns city buses: more than half of the buses produced in Europe in 2025 will have to be zero-emission and from 2030 this percentage will rise to 75 %.  For professional vehicles, such as waste collection trucks, the Commission will also have to present a proposal to reduce emissions. Finally, we want to encourage the role of natural gas in the transition to decarbonisation in the transport sector. For a Europe on the move, yes, but towards a new model of development.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – The truck fleet has to green! The N-VA delegation will soon vote in favour of ambitious CO2 standards and supports the sales targets for low-emission and zero-emission trucks. As much as a quarter of the CO2 emissions in road transport come from trucks. If we are to effectively meet our climate agreements and emit 40% less CO2 by 2030, we simply need those standards. The technology is available! Moreover, let us not forget that greening the fleet is also essential for better air quality. Our citizens have a right to clean air. The standards also save fuel, resulting in profits for businesses and consumers. Ambitious product standards are also needed to attract innovation and investment. Third countries such as the United States and China are already making a lot of use of this. The European Union must not, therefore, lag behind. The transport sector is also a questioner. So why should we hesitate? I would like to make the following comment. We support the introduction of a bonus-malus system, but we think it is a bad idea to include electric city buses in order to achieve the targets for green lorries. After all, we will give an unfair advantage to those manufacturers who build both buses and lorries and we threaten to undermine the level of ambition for the trucks themselves. So we think about that.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, Mr Eickhout, for the first time we are creating a system for heavy goods transport. Then, of course, it would be fairly wise to do it more right than less wrong. At least two larger issues should be taken into account in this context. The first is the recent IPCC report and the second is our old decisions on burden-sharing. The IPCC report showed four different paths forward. Some of those paths are moderately good, the last path will be very expensive for the next generations. That is why, of course, I believe that a path should be chosen where payments are taken now and not left to the next generation. In burden-sharing decisions, we agreed that countries in better technological and economic condition would take a bigger step and the less vulnerable would take smaller steps or no steps at all. Those countries that have had to or have agreed to take these major steps in this context may now, if we are not ambitious enough, find themselves in a rather weak position. That is why we have been reasonably in agreement with Mr Bas that clear steps must now be taken. Now we must dare and show that we bear responsibility not only for today's environment, but also for the problems of future generations and the world.

name: Karima DELLI
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we are finally preparing to set CO2 emission standards for heavy goods vehicles. This is already a victory, because such standards did not exist until now. So we can be proud of that, except that it is not enough. We have to go faster, stronger. The IPCC (Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change), a collective of scientists who regularly alert us to climate change, has warned us. We have little time to maintain a global warming of only 1.5oC instead of 2oC.  Why is it so important? Because the risks associated with climate, this warming of 1.5ooC, are certainly much lower than with a scenario at 2oC.  It is also a matter of heatwaves, precipitation, species extinction, agricultural productivity or ocean acidification.  What does a warming of 1.5oC mean? This means zero net CO2 emissions in 2050 globally, well before 2050. Did you hear me right? Long before 2050! That is why we need ambitious short-, medium- and long-term goals to chart a path that is reliable, concrete and effective. In this report we have succeeded in raising the reduction target to 20% by 2025 and 35% by 2030, because this is not only technologically possible, but above all desirable. We have also set a low, somewhat restrictive share of 10% of zero- or low-emission HGVs for 2025 and 35% for 2030. Again, it is possible, manufacturers can and should do so.  You see, ladies and gentlemen, it is a climate issue, it is an issue for jobs, but it is also innovative for clean vehicles. We can and must also save the employees of the European automotive industry, not by locking them in an old model, in the old world of fossil fuels, but by looking to the future with hope and with real solutions.

name: Stefan ECK
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Trucks are responsible for 25% of CO2 emissions from road transport, even though they account for less than 5% of traffic. In recent decades, the efficiency of the engines of these vehicles has not been significantly improved, because research is expensive and manufacturers therefore wanted to save at the expense of the environment. Despite the catastrophic effects of global warming, the industry-driven groups in this House have repeatedly undermined the best proposals from the Committee on the Environment. I believe that they will try to do so again this time.
