To those of you who believe that the polluting trucking industry must continue to protect the environment at the expense of the climate and public health: car manufacturers have recently shown that they are not trustworthy, that they lie and cheat with criminal energy, to put it bluntly, because they are always concerned only with profit. It is now up to us to massively reduce CO2 emissions in the lorry sector. That is what the citizens expect of us. Public surveys show that public awareness of the high risks associated with climate change has increased, because we all have to pay a high price for the irresponsible climate policies of the major industrialised nations. All over the world, people are already suffering from the effects of global warming. They lose their possessions, or even their lives, because of the cowardice of politics, or worse, because they were corrupted. There is no alternative. Either the European Union is acting now and is trying by all means to reduce CO2 emissions, in all areas, or it is continuing to be on the sidelines of industry and must rightly be accused by future generations of having degenerated into a lackey of corporations in the blind madness of growth. Colleagues! We have only one earth, and it must be preserved. That should be our top priority here in this House. Therefore, give Bas Eickhout a strong mandate for the forthcoming negotiations with the Council!

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the alarm bells of the latest IPCC report and the European Environment Agency projections for 2017 have thundered with disruptive force a message that should now be clear to everyone: we have entered the red stamp phase for the climate. Everyone is called upon to play their part and above all the transport sector, which is the one that has increased its emissions most of all over the years. It is therefore essential to achieve the best possible result on new heavy goods vehicles. As the 5 Star Movement we want to define a future-proof regulation, which really allows the spread of zero and low emission vehicles even in this market segment. Vehicles such as trucks, trucks, buses and coaches generate more than 6 % of total greenhouse gas emissions in the Union and 25 % of road transport. We must therefore do our best as co-legislators to protect the climate by setting significant reduction targets. Furthermore, pushing on the accelerator to stimulate the electrification of new heavy goods vehicles will also serve to protect the health of Europeans and to strengthen the energy security of the whole continent. It will help us say goodbye to that toxic technology called diesel, which almost completely powers heavy goods vehicles today, generating shocking environmental and health costs.  According to the available data and taking into account only the pollution from nitrogen oxides and particulate matter released during its normal life cycle of twelve years, a single diesel bus results in a cost to the community of EUR 19 000. Instead, the 3 200 zero-emission city buses that will circulate on our streets next year, as well as not dirtying the air in our cities, will allow us to take almost six hundred thousand barrels of oil off the market every year, saving over 40 million. The text we have worked on in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy aims to fortify and support this trend. That is why we will whole much support him here in plenary.

name: Danilo Oscar LANCINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in 2017 the European trucking sector represented a fleet of around 6.5 million vehicles, handling 14 billion tonnes of goods per year, carrying around 72 % of all land goods in Europe, or 90 % of the total value of goods. The importance of the sector to the EU economy is clear and is growing and today 98 % diesel powered by heavy goods vehicles. The importance of the sector to the EU economy is clear and is growing and today 98 % diesel-powered heavy goods vehicles. It is right to aim for an ambitious plan to reduce CO2 emissions from this sector, but this plan must have realistic objectives, both from a technological point of view and in terms of the sustainability of production costs. The current targets proposed are the result more of imagination than of a real estimate of existing and developable technologies and force the market towards the electric option alone, a choice not in itself wrong, but the market and above all technology are absolutely not ready. As I said with regard to emissions from motor vehicles and light commercial vehicles, there is no system in the proposal that recognises the role of renewable fuels.  On the other hand, it is essential that the contribution and benefits of these funds are recognised for the decarbonisation objectives through the introduction of a calculation methodology that recognises the renewable component networked at European level. It is therefore essential to consider the entire fuel chain, including the extraction and production, transport and use of fuel or electricity, in order to provide a more realistic comparison of the different options and in this sense it is very important to recognise the role of methane and biomethane. Finally, the penalties provided for in the event of non-compliance by the Commission appear to be inspired by a comparison between co2 emissions from light commercial vehicles and those of lorries in grams of CO2 per kilometre, which is misleading and paradoxically disincentives to full-load journeys, that is to say, the efficiency of road transport.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: This time, which is very rare, we are in no hurry, so I would ask you to speak calmly, but above all it is thoughtful towards the interpreters and, of course, also to all those present and listeners.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab A few comments on this report. First, there is no such thing as zero-emission vehicles. This is the use of false terminology, which then tends to make false conclusions. Unless you have invented perpetuum mobile in the meantime, and I missed something, or have already declared that perpetuum mobile is to be invented by 2030, I would not be surprised. Perhaps this is in some new amendment. There is no such thing as zero-emission vehicles, they simply do not emit in the place where they drive, they only emit where electricity is generated to power them. So let's not tell fairy tales.  Secondly, if we want to work fairly to improve the environment, then instead of using such a casuistry that for such vehicles it will be 15%, but if they are buses then no, unless articulated, then again some other percentage. Such casuiticism cannot be introduced into law. There is a very simple solution: the environmental levy should be included in the fuel – the more fuel someone will use, the more they will pay this environmental levy. And already the manufacturer's thing is to burn this fuel as little as possible. And that's it.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has The country I know best – Germany – has been very contentious about the issue of CO2 in cars.  The Ministry of the Environment has said that the Commission's proposal is not ambitious enough. And the Ministry of Economic Affairs and Transport said: yes, the Commission's proposal is a good one.  In this case, in the case of heavy goods vehicles, there is no dispute. The experts in the Ministry of the Environment also say that the European Commission's proposal is ambitious. I think that is true. I also agree with Karima Delli that it is a great step forward that, for the first time, we are making any progress at all with heavy goods vehicles.  That is why I am a little concerned that the Committee on the Environment has overstepped the mark. In particular, the figure for 2025 is very ambitious. That's a bigger leap than it will be until 2030. We must first introduce this legislation. That is why I would be grateful if we could correct this in particular at the same time – either at the plenary vote or in the trialogue. I would like us to vote in favour of the proposal by a large majority at the end of the process, so that something can be done for the climate. But we cannot overwhelm the industry concerned. The Committee on the Environment, Public Health and The European People's Committee on the Environment is not yet on target. However, I am very optimistic that we will be able to support a realistic and ambitious proposal together before the European elections.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, throughout this mandate, we have been constantly revising the European regulatory framework for controlling and reducing vehicle emissions. After the revision of emissions of pollutants from light vehicles, after the establishment of a commission of inquiry, after the tightening of the rules of registration and testing, and after the adoption of new CO2 emission reduction targets for light vehicles, we will finally regulate, for the first time, the CO2 emissions of all heavy vehicles. I call on all my colleagues not to lower the targets for a reduction of 20% in 2025 and 35% in 2030, adopted in a parliamentary committee. I also call for a massive vote for binding targets to develop the market for electric trucks and buses. We must also move towards real-world testing to avoid future CO2 emissions fraud scandals, as has been the case with pollutant emissions. Finally, I want to speak directly to European citizens to tell them that the European Union is acting and protecting you to limit the impact of emissions on your daily life. I want to tell them that we in the European Parliament are doing our job to respond to the climate emergency and to combat the scourge of air pollution. But the Member States must now also go down this road, and I regret their absence today.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: – Madam President, I assume that if you asked most Europeans if the CO2 emissions of trucks and buses are tackled in the EU they would say ‘yes’. I assume that they would be surprised if we explained to them that that’s not the case up till now. So I’m very happy that we are finally catching up with other parts of the world. That’s not only necessary to keep the Paris Climate Agreement in sight, it’s also necessary, as Commissioner Arias Cañete already emphasised, to safeguard the competitiveness of our own truck manufacturers in Europe. Let’s not forget all those truck operators, which most of the time are SME companies, that can save tens of thousands of euros if the trucks that they’re using are much more fuel efficient – a very important element as well. Finally, I’m a great supporter of a separate and ambitious target for zero—emission buses. Our European cities are struggling a lot with air quality. Let’s not get the same problem as with zero—emission vehicles, that the clean buses are simply not available if they’re asked for. So please also vote in favour of that part of this great report by our colleague, Mr Eickhout.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I believe that taking care of the environment and climate and creating incentives for the production and use of low- and zero-emission vehicles are our common task. I also believe that environmental objectives can be reconciled with caring for jobs and economic growth. I therefore believe that a 35% emission reduction allows such synergies to be maintained. The most effective solutions are those that are widely accepted by both consumers and manufacturers.  In the case of heavy goods vehicles, fuel efficiency is of paramount importance, as fuel is the highest fixed cost for transport companies. It is therefore in their interest to buy vehicles that use as little fuel as possible. Fuel efficiency is also linked to reducing emissions, so we should aim to implement as low-emission vehicles as possible for the production and use of vehicles. Ideally, they would be zero-emission vehicles. However, we must not require manufacturers and consumers to implement things that are impossible. Although it is technically possible to design, for example, a power-powered tractor unit, the barrier is of course its range, loading speed, vehicle weight. This barrier is easier to overcome on short journeys, for example in the case of cars and buses, but it is difficult to overcome when it comes to heavy vehicles.  I have encountered this problem in the work on the Directive on the promotion of clean vehicles, for which we adopted a negotiating mandate at the last session and of which I was rapporteur. There, too, we adopted other targets for buses and others, lower for trucks. I believe that, in the case of heavy goods vehicles, we should focus on improving fuel efficiency and transitional technologies such as natural gas and, in particular, biomethane, which, as a renewable fuel, can have a major impact on reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

name: Tiemo WÖLKEN
text: Madam President Hautala, I would like to thank the President-in-House for the work she has done. A comprehensive mobility package naturally includes heavy goods traffic on europe's roads. I would therefore like to begin by thanking the European Commission for the proposal and I hope that we will be able to actually adopt this proposal during this parliamentary term. This is urgently needed, given that other relevant markets have all already set standards for trucks. I therefore believe that it is time for us in the European Union to finally regulate CO2 emissions. After all, it cannot be explained to any citizen that emissions from heavy goods vehicles have not yet been regulated. MAN, for example, sent us MEPs a brochure in September which advertises an all-electric fourteen-tonne truck. So something is actually moving in industry, and new technologies are within reach. I believe that regulation is necessary and that regulation also helps the entire economy. In my constituency, for example.B, there is the second largest manufacturer in Europe for truck trailers, which has developed wind spoilers that reduce consumption. Here, however, we must also set the regulatory framework for such techniques to be used. However, as this is new legislation, we should also be careful in two or three places. I believe that we should be able to have alternative fuels counted and that we must once again look very closely at the vote on penalties.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Mr Bas Eickhout, thank you very much for your report. I think we are in complete agreement: every emission is bad for the climate. We know that. That is why we must try to reduce emissions as far as possible. Road transport is a major factor in this, as we know, and it will continue to increase. Because if we continue to have more people in the world, there will be more trade, more internal market with Europe, and there will be more on the road, because that is the main medium on which transport is carried. For the first time, we now have binding targets. That is also a good thing that we are taking care of it. The point is that we have to think: how far can we really go on the objectives? Perhaps the best way would be to introduce emissions trading for lorries and buses. We don't have that now, and that's something we'd like to do from my party. It is also important to consider the entire life cycle of a vehicle, not just what comes out of the exhaust at the back. Absolutely right! Long trucks could also be a good solution. I am saying this here because I am firmly convinced that this is the case. The trucks have already reduced a lot with Euro 6 etc. I think it is crucial that we see that we have to make demands, but they must also be workable and workable and feasible. And Here I have the impression that the Commission has actually proposed quite a lot.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In the European Parliament's Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, we have significantly tightened up an already ambitious proposal from the European Commission. We have set the interim target of 20% for 2025 and 35% by 2030. I think that we in this House must also ask the question: what is technical and what is actually achievable and feasible? I have spoken to technical experts who say that, on average, a reduction potential of 1.5% per year over the next ten years is really possible. Then I come to 15%. If we insinuate even more ambitions, we will get to 20%. I believe that we must take this very seriously, and we should not sweep the physical and technical limits under the carpet either. The operational reality is important. The production cycle for trucks is like this: it is being developed today and will be on the track in 2025. Against this background, it is important – as many colleagues have mentioned, Bas Eickhout – that is precisely the question of the 2025 intermediate target. That is too high for us as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, and we need to go back to the 15%. I am very pleased that, in the debate, Mr Wölken ...  We do not always agree, but we can find a consensus on the issue of fines and crediting e-fuels. In this respect, I believe that we can improve this dossier in the long term.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Madam President, when I was a member of the European Parliament's committee of inquiry into emissions from the automotive sector, there was a number that marked me particularly. Four hundred thousand European citizens die prematurely each year due to poor air quality. Therefore, the decarbonisation of transport is an imperative of citizenship, for economic, environmental and public health reasons.  Heavy vehicles account for 6% of total carbon dioxide emissions in the EU. We must have a significant share of new low-emission heavy vehicles to reduce emissions from this sector by 35%.  It is a challenge for European industry to develop, produce and market in Europe and beyond heavy vehicles without emissions or with low emissions. Research to this end should be encouraged and supported, but it is not enough to support industry. A high proportion of eu freight operators are SMEs. It is essential to also provide a robust incentive structure to support them.  We can't stay behind. We must aim to lead in innovative transport emission reduction technologies to meet Paris, but above all to improve the quality of life of European citizens.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: – Dear Chairman, Mr Commissioner, I welcome the adoption of this Regulation, although this Regulation, as with all CO2 emissions regulations, raises a number of outstanding questions. The question, for example, will technological developments enable the objectives set to be achieved? Will we be able to prevent the import of heavy commercial vehicles from foreign markets? Are the penalties for not meeting the targets well affected since we have two radical proposals here in plenary, of 5 000 and of 1 000 euros? Will we be able to develop emission measurement and monitoring techniques and will we have enough data for auditing, early revision, in just a few years to make this revision of this regulation of sufficient quality? However, despite all the questions raised, I support the adoption of this regulation, because if we do not, then CO2 emissions from heavy commercial vehicles could reach almost 10% of total CO2 emissions.

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I too welcome this proposal which is being put forward for the first time, because heavy vehicles account for 6% of emissions, these are increasing and ambitious targets for emission reduction in the European Union are also needed. This Regulation is an important complement to everything that has been done about fuzzy sectors, such as e4-share or light vehicle rules. But in order to give a clear signal to the industry, as you very well said, Commissioner, we need reduction targets which are both ambitious and achievable on the part of manufacturers. We need a clear definition of what low-emission vehicles are. We need the necessary adjustments to account for emissions avoided by certain renewable combustions and we need a reasonable penalty system. The truth is that we reached a vote in this House without the rapporteur being able to reach agreement between the parliamentary groups. I regret this and hope that the rapporteur will soon be able to reach an agreement with the Council to have a stable and predictable legal framework before the end of the parliamentary term.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht KOCH
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has had. By setting CO2 limits for heavy goods vehicles, we are closing a loophole in the law. In doing so, we should proceed sensibly and learn from the mistakes in creating limit values for passenger cars and light commercial vehicles. Today, it is important to avoid unrealistic regulations. I support the reduction target of 35% with a heavy heart. But that should really be the maximum value. Incentives are always better than punishments. In order to promote the purchase of fuel-efficient trucks, EU financing mechanisms must be used by transport companies, most of which are SMEs. This should also apply to the purchase of zero-emission buses. The whole thing must be accompanied by the creation of an adequate comprehensive charging and filling station infrastructure, because even the strictest limit values will not help us if the use of low-emission vehicles is not made possible. The EU must work hand in hand with the Member States on this.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: – Madam President, the decarbonisation of the transport sector is key to meeting the objectives of combating climate change, and we need to act in this sector in a special way because of its difficulty in reducing emissions and because of its volume, which accounts for a quarter of the European Union. In addition, this sector represents a very important source of work in Europe and faces a profound technological transformation. Ladies and gentlemen, society is demanding that we breathe clean air without pollution, and especially this is aggravated in our cities, in the great urban conglomerations. This Regulation has every sense of being to promote safer traffic with less polluting vehicles and more advanced technological solutions, while promoting the competitiveness of European industry.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, emissions of gaseous pollutants are harmful, firstly to the health of all of us and secondly - of course - to the environment. It is therefore obvious that measures must be taken to limit emissions of gaseous pollutants. This must also be done in the transport sector, where 70% of land transport is carried out by heavy vehicles. Therefore, the objective must first be containment. I see, however, that the objective is particularly ambitious. I think we need to have a more weighted and balanced transition. First of all, we need to look at public transport where there is public intervention, i.e. buses - which can of course be electric - and garbage trucks. Also, implementation in the private sector must be done gradually and incentives should be given to small and medium-sized enterprises in order to support micro-owners, as in the case of Greece, because otherwise we will have very large private monopolies that will throw out micro-professionals.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – Madam President, I am sorry to have to criticise again the emissions proposal from the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, but unfortunately, this time too, the Committee has not put forward a rational document. The proposed targets call for 50% of urban emissions-free, so-called electric buses to be sold in 2025 and 75% in 2030. However, these objectives completely ignore any fundamental logic of the difference between public transport and both personal and technical neutrality. Charging one heavy vehicle requires a minimum power of 40 kW. By comparison, the usual reserve of one household is 3 kW. If electric buses are to become backbone machines of public transport, then the garages of a typical transport company will have consumption comparable to the district of the city in which they reside.  Another thing that we prefer not to talk about here is the safety of the elekrovozidels. The batteries contain two components needed for burning and the classic technique is problematic to extinguish them. In any heavy vehicle, unlike a passenger battery, there are several tons. The proposed emission targets in the text of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety are twice as realistic as those analysed and will lead to an increase in transport prices, consumer prices or an increase in fleet age.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Madam President, I’ve listened to this with real interest. People say the EU doesn’t work. Well, this is entirely a great example of how it does. Climate change fanatics come here and tell us that we’re going to have plagues and death and species dying out and the world’s going to end. They come here with that message, then the people who want to have more control and more power in the EU take this and think, ‘Oh, this is great; we can say we’re going to tax more, we can say we’re going to spend more, control more, fine people, tell them what they can do, how they can produce things, and we can say, “if you don’t do it, the world’s going to end”’. It’s perfect, it’s a lovely symmetry that’s going on here. If you really want to make a change, surely the best way is through incentives. Why not create an environment where companies and industries will make research look into this new greener technology that you want and actually make a profit doing it, rather than being forced into it from top down with the threat of all this alarmism and nonsense.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, having been involved in the whole clean energy package from the outset, I think we can be very pleased with the progress we have made under the leadership of Commissioner Arias Cañete and, indeed, in this file I would like to thank Mr Eickhout for his good work in this and many other areas. And if we are to deliver on our targets for 2030 and beyond, every sector has to play its part. The transport sector hasn’t done as much as it should have up until now and we are nudging them in the right direction, giving them sensible targets over a period of time. I drive from my home in Killarney to Dublin twice a week every week, coming to Brussels and going back, and the amount of trucks and buses is enormous. Unless they are more energy efficient we will never make progress. I think the proposals here for heavy—duty vehicles make a lot of sense, will make a huge difference, and if every sector plays their part, we will meet our targets and we will give world leadership as well. So well done to Mr Eickhout, Commissioner Arias Cañete and everybody involved.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I have listened carefully to the debate today and I have heard a broad range of positions, in particular on the level of ambition and on zero— and low—emission vehicle incentives.  I would like to stress once more that the Commission proposal is balanced, ambitious and fully in line with our climate objectives. Some interventions are calling for higher ambition levels in 2025. With 15% in 2025, the Commission proposal strikes the right balance between being realistic and ambitious. We have based it on a solid impact assessment because a 15% target can be achieved using technologies that are already available on the market but not yet widely deployed. Today we have also heard calls for setting a binding and higher target for 2030. Let me please remind you that while the 2025 target can be met by deploying readily available cost—effective technologies, achieving a more ambitious 2030 target would require the implementation of new technologies that are not yet on the market. There is currently a lack of robust information on how the performance and costs of those more innovative and prospective technologies might evolve in the medium term, and this creates a risk that a binding 2030 target would not be set at the most cost—effective level right now. The Commission has therefore proposed to review the 2030 aspirational CO2 emission targets in 2022 once sufficient certified CO2 emission data has been collected and more information is available. Some interventions also called for incentives for the deployment of zero— and low—emission vehicles, an objective that the Commission supports. A crediting system based on a benchmark was considered in the impact assessment. However, it was not retained, in particular in view of the very low penetration of zero— and low—emission vehicles in the fleet and of the scarcity of robust data on such markets. Adding a malus would mean that manufacturers meeting the CO2 targets would actually be penalised if they did not meet the benchmark. Instead, the Commission proposal contains a super—credit system which also preserves the environmental integrity of the CO2 target. CO2 emissions standards cannot be set yet for buses, as the CO2 emissions are not yet certified. However, as set out in the 2022 review clause, buses will be included in future standards. But, at the same time, this proposal can help to speed up the market uptake of zero—emission bus technologies by including then in the super—credit scheme. There is a competition distortion between manufacturers which is addressed through a cap. The proposed revision of the Clean Vehicle Directive will be a key tool to steer public authorities’ decisions in purchasing zero—emission buses by creating a larger market for those vehicles. A platform has already been created to help cities make joint public procurement, and the European Union budget will also continue to support the financing of a new fleet of clean buses. However, certain zero—emission buses mandates for manufacturers will not be proposed. We heard today some interventions calling for credits for alternative fuels. The Commission proposal does not include such credits. Our approach is based on the principle of clear responsibilities for clear actors. Manufacturers are responsible for designing vehicles so that they achieve the CO2 reductions required under the legislation. However, they cannot be held responsible for the type of fuel that is actually used in its vehicle or take advantage of it. More precisely, one vehicle is not necessarily linked to one fuel type as in many cases the same vehicle can use several fuels, either conventional, biofuels or other low carbon fuels. This being said, it does not mean that we are not taking action to decarbonise emissions from fuels. The eight—year reform will ensure decarbonisation of electricity production and the Renewable Energies Directive will ensure that more low—carbon fuels will enter the market. In this context we need to apply the principle of better regulation and avoid double regulation and double accounting for incentivising renewable fuels. Some interventions today raised concerns about the proposed level of the penalties, considering them too high and possibly putting at risk the economic situation of a manufacturer exceeding its targets. Firstly, ensuring compliance is absolutely necessary for the effectiveness of any regulatory requirements. Secondly, to be in line with the objectives of the regulation, financial penalties have to be set at a level that exceeds the marginal cost of meeting the targets. The penalties need to be a real deterrent. It should not be less expensive to pay penalties than to invest in technologies to meet targets. Thirdly, the approach taken by the Commission is to set an equivalent level of stringency from an environmental point of view, as compared with cars and buses. Finally, this issue will be part of the review of the effectiveness of the legislation in 2022. To conclude, I would like to thank all of you for the interesting debate. I am looking forward to the upcoming vote. The Commission is also confident that the Council, under the leadership of the Austrian Presidency, will be able to reach swiftly a position so that the discussion between the two co—legislators can start this year. It is absolutely essential that the final political agreement between the co—legislators can be found before the end of the term of office of this Parliament. I trust that this will be possible thanks to the dedication and hard work of the two co—legislators. Again, my thanks to the rapporteur for a good, fast and ambitious job.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his replies and to thank my colleagues for this very good discussion that we have had. I feel that there is quite some support for what we did in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI), which is very good.  To touch on a couple of issues that have been raised, first, on the level of ambition, we have to be very clear here that we have already adopted national binding targets for 2030 under effort sharing. This means that we know that if in the transport sector we are not reducing our emissions enough, reductions will need to come from the other sectors that fall under the Effort Sharing Regulation, being housing or agriculture. If we don’t go for the cost—effective reductions that are possible in transport, it will mean that agriculture needs to deliver more in those countries where they will have difficulties in meeting their reduction targets. All the analysis shows that a CO2 standard on cars and heavy—duty vehicles is the cost—effective way to reduce emissions in those sectors that fall under the Effort Sharing Regulation, and that’s what we’re doing here. On the level where we, as ENVI, say that we should raise the bar to 20%, I once again want to stress that, in the Commission’s impact assessment, it’s very clearly stated that an analysis of the cost—effective technologies already at hand shows that full deployment would make it possible to achieve emission reductions between 15% to 20% by 2025. This shows that the existing technologies can be achieved with the 20% target. On top of that, we need to develop new technologies and that’s why we are making this Regulation consistent with the cars. In the cars we had super credits and now, later on, the Commission is stepping away from that in cars and comes up with super credits again in this Regulation. We think it’s better to skip that mistake that you made on cars and immediately go into a mandate for zero and low-emission vehicles at a very low level of 5%. My last point, on buses, is that it’s very important to realise that there are producers producing both trucks and buses. So if we have one mandate, you are giving very clear priority and a benefit for those who are producing both because, in buses, we can move faster, and the market is moving faster. That’s why we have decided on separate mandates for buses and heavy—duty vehicles – in order to make sure that the level playing field remains equal for all the players in the market for new technologies.  Once again, I thank everyone for the discussion. I’m looking forward to the vote and then indeed, what is the intention? A fast resolution in negotiations, hopefully to start under the Austrian Presidency.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place today, Wednesday 14 November 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Adam GIEREK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The REGULATION on CO2 emission standards for heavy-duty vehicles is part of the European Union's integrated approach to decarbonising the transport sector. Its provisions will undoubtedly be a major problem in the long term, both for vehicle manufacturers and for fuel retailers. According to the current methodology, the vehicle's CO2 emissions are attributed to it on the basis of the measured amount of CO2 emissions from the vehicle's exhaust pipe. However, the total CO2 emissions from the previous processing of crude oil into fuels, as primary energy (refineries) or in the production of renewable fuels, including biogas, shall not be taken into account. It's a mistake.  I believe that the focus should be on taking into account the emission reductions that result from the use of biofuels and alternative fuels. To this end, the European Commission should develop a new methodology for objectively counting total emissions. The new methodology for advanced and renewable liquid fuels, including gaseous fuels, while avoiding double counting will allow for further major CO2 reduction. It will also enable companies specialising in the production of heavy-duty vehicles to prepare new, forward-looking and competitive design solutions more boldly.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Dear colleagues, it is my pleasure to welcome the President of the Republic of South Africa, Cyril Ramaphosa. This important visit takes place ahead of the Seventh EU-South Africa Summit, to be held in Brussels tomorrow. President Ramaphosa, you are the fifth African leader to address this Chamber in the past year. As you can see, strengthening ties with the African continent is a priority for us, but also for me it is one of the most important points for my presidency. Let me begin by saying that the European Parliament proudly joined the worldwide celebrations to commemorate Nelson Mandela’s legacy on the centenary of his birth. He was, as you know, the first person to receive the Sakharov Prize in 1988, in recognition of his struggle to end apartheid and his fight to pursue equal rights for all. We will always remember this great man with admiration and immense respect. Mr President, in February of this year, you became South Africa’s new president. Your reforms are contributing to revitalise South Africa’s economy by attracting foreign investments, enhancing private-sector competitiveness, creating jobs, especially for the young, fighting corruption and inequality, and improving citizens’ rights. We welcome your agenda and are confident that in tomorrow’s summit we will open a new chapter in our partnership. However, structural challenges in South Africa remain: poverty, income inequality and unemployment are at the top of the list. The EU stands ready to support you in tackling these challenges. Through stronger economic diplomacy and an ambitious ‘Marshall plan’ for Africa, we can help you attract investment. South Africa is a champion of multilateralism, an active member of the African Union and of the Southern African Development Community. It is the only African member of the G20. This means we have to work together on our most pressing common challenges – trade, climate change, terrorism, migration and unemployment. I also wish to congratulate you on the election of your country as a non-permanent member of the United Nations Security Council starting next year. South Africa has a great role to play regionally and on the global stage. President Ramaphosa, thank you once more for being here with us. You have the floor. (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: President of South Africa. – Mr President, it is indeed a great honour and a privilege to have this opportunity to address this gathering, particularly in the centenary year of the birth of Nelson Mandela, the founding father of our democratic nation, a revered statesman and a committed internationalist. We celebrate the centenary knowing well that Nelson Mandela does not belong to us as South Africans. He belongs to all of us, and indeed to the world.  (Applause) He is one person who, through his life and deeds, proved to all the people across the world that championing human rights and doing what is right in terms of embracing universal values was the right thing to do, and that is precisely what he dedicated his life to. He belongs not only to those who lived through the tumultuous events of the last century, but he also belongs to the generations that are going to follow all of us. We live in the world that Nelson Mandela and many other great leaders of his age made. We are grateful to the European Union and to the people, as well as the leaders, of Europe for the tributes they have paid in many different ways to Nelson Mandela on the occasion of his birth, and for this we thank you from the bottom of our hearts. We say thank you for honouring Nelson Mandela in the way that you have.  (Applause) It is indeed a testament to the universal appeal of his vision that he is as revered on this continent as he is across the African continent. We remember with the nations of the world the centenary of the armistice that marked the end of the First World War. We pay tribute to all those who lost their lives in that great human tragedy, including the many South Africans of all races who also fought in that war and who perished on these foreign shores. (Applause) Twenty—six years ago, in the city of Maastricht, the leaders of Europe signed the historic Treaty that would mark a new era in the continent’s history. Now, more than a quarter of a century later, that affirmation of democracy, of liberty, of respect for human rights, of fundamental freedoms and the rule of law continues to endure. These timeless values are indeed beacons of hope in our troubled times, for – despite our greatest efforts – the world today is blighted by conflict, poverty and underdevelopment in a number of poor countries. There is still a lack of meaningful social progress, unrest and displacement. The spectre of the resurgence of racism and xenophobia, cloaked in the mantle of nationalism, is rising and is causing a great deal of concern in a number of places. Unilateralism is on the rise and threatens, in many ways, to undermine our collective commitment to democratic values and respect for human rights. Now, more than ever, we turn to our great leaders for strength and inspiration as we seek to resolve the most pressing challenges of our times. We recall their words and their actions as we reaffirm our commitment to democratic values and upholding the rights of every human being. It was the great statesman and friend of the anti-apartheid cause, Olof Palme, the former Prime Minister of Sweden, who said, ‘for us, democracy is a question of human dignity. This includes political liberties, the right to freely express our views, the right to criticise and to influence opinion. It embraces the right to health, work, to education and social security’. This view of democracy resonates with Nelson Mandela’s vision of a global community of nations that affirms the centrality of human dignity and strives through all means available to improve the human condition.  Just four months after his release from prison in 1990, Nelson Mandela paid his first visit to the European Parliament to receive the Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought. He used this occasion to thank the leaders and the people of Europe for their contribution to the liberation of South Africa. I also stand here, like Nelson Mandela, and thank the people of Europe for the contribution that they made to end apartheid, and we say thank you for all the support you gave us during the dark days of apartheid. Thank you very much. (Applause) Nelson Mandela also used the opportunity, as he addressed this European Parliament, to call on the nations of Europe to continue to stand by South Africa as we sought to rebuild our country. We are here today to confirm that, indeed, the nations of Europe answered the call that Nelson Mandela made with conviction and generosity. We are here today, following in the footsteps of Nelson Mandela, to say that we would urge you and we would call on you to continue supporting South Africa as it has embarked on a journey, not only to reform itself, but to build a new South African nation from the ashes of apartheid. We thank you for continuing to support us.  (Applause) The European Union was born out of the need to end the historic divisions on the continent, to create a firm base for the construction of a new Europe rooted in solidarity and cooperation, and to contribute to global peace, security and development. The countries of Africa have similarly embarked upon a new path of peace, development and transformation. The African Union’s Agenda 2063 provides a programme for integration and prosperity on a continent that has been wracked by division, exploitation and strife. Nelson Mandela was an ardent advocate for pan—Africanism, and he believed that the continent could only reach her full potential if her peoples were united. In pursuing this goal, there are many lessons we can draw from the European Union’s path to integration, to economic and political union, and to achieving social progress.  South Africa notes the tireless work of the European Parliament to ensure that the provisions of the Lisbon Treaty on the eradication of poverty continue to underpin the EU’s approach to external development cooperation. Since 2007, South Africa and the EU have enjoyed the mutual benefits of a strategic partnership that continues to play a meaningful role in our country’s economic growth. It covers over 20 sectoral policy dialogues on diverse issues from development cooperation, science and technology, health, climate change, trade, education, skills development to peace migration, security and human rights as well.  An integral part of this partnership are the interparliamentary meetings between the South African Parliament and the European Parliament. These meetings have indeed played a crucial role in strengthening South Africa’s, as well as European, relations, contributing to a strategic partnership – a partnership that is based on equality, shared values and issues of mutual interest. Allow me to express our sincere appreciation for the contribution that the European Union – and in this case the European Parliament – have made not only to the development of South Africa, but also towards the achievement of progress across the African continent. Nelson Mandela led South Africa in its peaceful transition to democracy, but he had a bigger dream: an Africa at peace with itself and the world. In his lifetime, he supported the African Union’s effort towards conflict prevention and resolution, peaceful building, as well as post-conflict reconstruction. He would have joined us in applauding the EU’s support for the AU peace and security architecture and its steadfast support for efforts to silence the guns on the African continent for good. He always argued that lasting peace and security on the continent will not be possible without economic development. Without opportunity, without investment, without thriving economies that enable us all to enjoy our place in the sun, we cannot hope to have political and social stability on the African continent. We therefore welcome the support of the European Union for Africa’s development needs through initiatives such as the European External Investment Plan, the Economic Partnership Agreement and the new Africa—European Alliance for Sustainable Investment and Jobs. We should strive to ensure that these approaches are developed and implemented in line with Agenda 2063 of the African Union. We should seek to ensure that these developmental initiatives support the establishment of the African Continental Free Trade Area and Africa’s overall industrialisation infrastructure development, as well as economic transformation.  We need to work together, as the countries of Europe and Africa, to develop sustainable and humane responses to the challenge of irregular migration. This is a challenge that Europe has had to deal with in recent years. So, too, has South Africa, and several African countries have had to deal with this challenge as well in a number of ways. We need to work together to address the root causes of irregular migration, which include poverty, inequality, unemployment, economic exclusion and competition for scarce resources. This should be informed by the principles of solidarity, compassion and an unwavering commitment to the human rights of all the people of the world. Africa is the cradle of humankind. It is rich in land and water, abundant in minerals, and blessed with a young and vibrant population. It is the next frontier of growth, of innovation and of social progress. To realise this potential, the people of Africa are in the process of uniting themselves. Africa will continue to strengthen the bonds of partnership and friendship with the citizens of her sister continents and, in this case, her sister continent Europe. It is therefore a matter of great satisfaction and promise that our partnership with the European Union is as strong as it has been enduring. It is grounded in responsibility, respect and mutual accountability. The nations of the EU are a source of investment, trade, skills and knowledge, which has worked with us as South Africa in our quest to grow our economy and improve the lives of our people.  As we look to the future, we continue to count on the strength of this partnership between our countries and our peoples. As we advance forward to address the many challenges that our country faces – the challenges of unemployment, of poverty, and of inequality – we rely on Europe to be our partner. Right now, our country is in the process of transforming and reforming itself. We are seeking to create a South Africa that is conducive for investment flows. A few weeks ago, we held an investment conference that attracted a number of European—based companies to come to South Africa, and we were particularly overjoyed when many of them declared that they will continue to invest in South Africa. We were able, at that conference – and another conference that followed – to raise USD 26 billion that will flow into South Africa, and we are grateful for the support that we have enjoyed also from Europe, for that vote of confidence in our economy.  (Applause) It is this collaboration and partnership that we seek – a collaboration that has bound South Africa and the countries of Europe together in a pact to never again return to the excesses and divisions of the past. As South Africa, we are dealing with a number of issues that have to do with policies, policies that will consolidate South Africa and make our country more stable. We are in the process of dealing with the question of land reform. Land reform is one of those challenges that our country has had to face over hundreds of years, where the indigenous people of South Africa were denied access to land, and have over the years been yearning to have access to land. We are now at a stage where we are engaging in a dialogue – an overarching dialogue among the people of South Africa, those who own land and those who don’t own land – to see how best this important resource can be utilised to develop our country. Through this, the dialogue is leading us to a point where we are seeking to find solutions that will be inclusive and that will enable all South Africans, as we continue to consolidate our nation and to work together to resolve this problem. We have said very clearly that this problem of land will be resolved through adherence to the rule of law, through adherence to our constitution, and we will utilise the lessons that Nelson Mandela taught us with regard to resolving problems. We will resolve this problem in an inclusive basis, respecting each other’s human rights, respecting each other’s hopes and aspirations, and making sure – like we did when we resolved the apartheid problem – that we resolve it with a view to building a nation from the ashes of apartheid. This we shall do, because that is what Nelson Mandela taught us. I can assure you that we will resolve the land issue in line with the values that are enshrined in our Constitution and, when we do so, we will have an all—inclusive solution that will make all the people of South Africa work together and move together into the promised future that we see ahead of us.  (Applause) Unity and partnership, as well as solidarity, are the principles that have underpinned our cooperation across two vast and different continents out of dark histories and into a promising new dawn. South Africa, Africa and the European Union are bound by shared values of democracy and respect for human rights. We share a commitment to the ideals of free and prosperous societies, societies in which all persons live together in harmony with equal opportunities. We owe it to our great forebears, leaders of the calibre of Nelson Mandela, to focus on what unites us and not that which divides us, and to focus also on what benefits all of us and not what enriches and benefits just a few. We owe it to the leaders who are our forebears to build a strategic partnership that endures, that flourishes, and that – above all else – advances the cause of humanity. We thank you for your friendship, we thank you for your solidarity, we thank you for your partnership, and we thank you all for your support and for your continued help in everything that we are doing to rebuild the South African nation so that we, too, can enjoy the type of progress that you, as Europeans, have achieved. Thank you very much.  (Sustained applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: President Ramaphosa, thank you very much. The message from the European Parliament is very clear: we want to strengthen cooperation between the European Union and Africa and between the European Union and the Republic of South Africa. Thank you very much for coming. (Applause) (Parliament met for the awarding of the LUX prize)

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: – Mr President, two prominent democratic guests from Hong Kong are today visiting the European Parliament. I would like to welcome Mr Martin Lee, from the Democratic Party, and Mr Alan Leong, from the Civic Party. (Applause)

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Mr President, I did not want to interrupt the solemn sittings, but I would like to ask you about how you chaired our work yesterday during the exchange with Chancellor Merkel. The instructions we have received state: "Please note that the Speaker will allocate the time between Members based on the amount of time allocated to political groups according to their size." My group has not been a victim of this, but I note that your group, which represents 29% of the members of this House, has received 35% of the speaking time, that the EFDD group, which represents 5.7% of our Chamber, has received 10% of the speaking time and that the group of non-registered members who represent 3.9% of our Chamber has received 10% of the speaking time. I think there is a serious imbalance in the distribution of these so-called 'on-demand interventions'. (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mrs Berès, It is not I who decides the speaking time, but it is all based on the d'Hondt system. I receive from the services the number of Members who can speak on the basis of time. So It is not I who decides how many Socialists, how many non-attached Members can speak. They were respected with one exception because, according to the time used by the group chairmen, the GUE Group, the Liberal Group and the Green Group would not have been entitled to any intervention. This is the only violation I have committed. In order to give representativeness to Members and not just to group chairmen, I made one exception. For the rest, I have scrupulously complied with the request that came to me from the services, trying to get members who had never spoken in other debates to speak, because it would be unfair, when the catch the eye was made, to always have the Members themselves speak. Yesterday, more than 200 Members asked to speak, but Mrs Merkel absolutely had to leave the Chamber by 5.30 p.m., as I had informed you. So for my part, I am sorry, Mrs Berès, there has been no violation of the rules of the d'Hondt system. It is not up to me that not all Members have been happy. I'd let everyone talk to me, but time is what it is. Thank you, however, for allowing me to explain the organisation of the catch-the-eye work when there are the Heads of State or Government who come to take part in the debates before Parliament.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to ask for your complicity, on the one hand to thank the ADMO association for the great commitment it has put in recent days and, on the other hand, to thank the many bone marrow donors for the challenge we must make of Alexander. Unfortunately, there are two weeks left to receive bone marrow donation. By the end of the month, this 18-month-old baby has to come to find the donor. It has not yet been found, I appeal to all of you: let us all help together so that this 18-month-old baby can find the right donor by the end of the month. Thank you for your availability and I am sure of your help.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: On 2 October 2018, I announced in this House the sanction of Giulia Moi for her conduct towards parliamentary assistants qualified as psychological harassment. On 16 October 2018, Mr Moi lodged an internal appeal against this decision before the Bureau, in accordance with Rule 167 of the Rules of Procedure. On Monday, 12 November 2018, the Bureau unanimously confirmed the scope of the sanction adopted, which was to lose the right to residence allowances for a period of 12 days.

name: Giulia MOI
text: Mr Tajani, I would like to know why your office has not been responding to me for months about infringements made by your two employees, where there have been irregularities in my request for more than a year before this fandonia over the dismissal of these two of my employees. I cannot work, there have not been rules that were supposed to protect the work of a Member of Parliament. His office has been receiving all the material for months and he's not answering me. I am stuck in my work as an MEP and you are in no way meeting the answers within the time limits set by law. The infractions of your employees are considerable and you are not giving me an explanation. You're not letting me fire two people who made irregularities. You're holding them for me and I can't do anything. This farce of this accusation is ridiculous and could also be a political attack.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr Moi, I understand your state of mind. I understand what he said. You have had time to express your views, now let me respond. He said what he thought. The sanction has been imposed, it has been confirmed. The decision was not made by me. The decision was taken by the Harassing Committee. The sanction has been imposed.

name: Jörg MEUTHEN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I will return to yesterday's catch-the-eye procedure. If you say here that the allocation of words was almost fair, then I strongly disagree with that. You have given the floor to four speakers on the eFDD Group. I was one of the first to register. We had announced internally that I should, of course, have the floor. After the chairman of the group spoke, you gave the floor to Mr Monot, then two Britons, you refused to give me the floor. There would have to be a ... (Unrest) Yes, yes, yes, these are the very pseudo-democratic stories that are going on here. If I may say so, Mr President, when the German Chancellor speaks in this Parliament, ithink that the only German from the EFDD Group should be able to respond with a speech of her own. That is exactly what you have denied me. This is shabby, and it gives a deep insight into the understanding of this House. And the behaviour i get here from the CDU, even more so. It is precisely your pseudo-democratic approach. Just be ashamed!

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I would remind you, Mr President, that this is not the Bundestag and it is not even the Bundesrat but the European Parliament, and so the representatives of the political groups are speaking. It is not a debate on the political situation in Germany.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr President, thank you for giving me the floor. I hope that my colleagues will listen to me, because this could also concern them one day. I do not know, Mr President, the case of Mrs Me. What I can tell you, however, is that it is completely abnormal, perfectly scandalous - and the other day I defended colleagues on the left - that the Bureau does not personally receive the Members concerned, or the quaestors for that matter, when there is a problem with them in the administration of this Parliament. This violates all provisions, including those that have been voted on by our Parliament, and more specifically those of the Code of Administrative Conduct, which stipulates that before any action making a grievance, the person concerned must be heard in writing or orally, if he so desires.  Secretary-General Klaus Welle sits on this provision on a regular, repetitive and scandalous basis, in defiance of the rights of parliamentarians.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is voting time. (For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Before moving on to the report on the Multiannual Financial Framework, I would like to stress the importance of this vote because the European Parliament intends to claim its power of legislative initiative by means of this vote, intends to claim its role as a leading legislator and intends to strongly demand that a decision be taken on the Multiannual Framework as quickly as possible. This is a political message that Parliament is sending to the Council and the European Commission.

name: Sabine LÖSING
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the I'm not going to stop you for long. I would just like to announce that we have tabled an oral amendment for reasons of topicality. You can find it in your voting lists.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, thank you very much. I will not make a long speech; I will only say according to the fourth subparagraph of Rule 59(4) that the plenary gives a mandate for direct negotiations with the Council.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which There is considerable political pressure from Turkey on Georgia and on other countries in the neighbourhood. This pressure is very often directed against schools and universities. We can say on Georgia that the pressure against Black Sea University has not been successful, but that, after a court decision and in very good cooperation with colleagues in the Georgian Government and in the Georgian Parliament, the future of Black Sea University is assured – against the pressure from Turkey. Thank you to my colleagues in Georgia. I would therefore ask that the specific mention of Black Sea University be deleted in our report.

name: Sylvia-Yvonne KAUFMANN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Excuse me, but a number of Members had already taken their voting cards out of their apparatus because of the break, and I therefore believe that the result is distorted. It is not the case that the figures cannot be as you have just put it. As I said, colleagues have already taken some of the cards out.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I have said twice that we needed a majority of Members. I waited longer. 595 Members voted. It is not up to me if they did not vote. I have said twice that we needed a qualified majority. There was a desire to lift the tiles.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: – Mr President, I say the same thing as my colleague has said. There are a lot of people who thought they had voted for it and removed the card because the vote took a long time to get on the screen. We've been able to lose a majority in favor of a very important law. I think it's an obvious problem. Mr. President, I'd ask to repeat the vote tomorrow. I'd ask to vote again tomorrow. We cannot send a message to European citizens that we are not in favour of humanitarian visas, President.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I have twice said that we needed a majority of Members. They are all experienced Parliamentarians, it is not that I have to say when they have to take off or put the paper. This is a mistake on the part of Members. It is a decision of the Members.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, as rapporteur for a legislative initiative requiring a qualified majority, there cannot be the slightest shadow of doubt that the vote has been exactly a reflection of the will of all Members present in the Chamber. From the moment there are testimonies — with twenty-five votes to add up to the absolute majority — that a good number of Members who voted favorably had already withdrawn the card by the time the on-screen vote count finally appeared, it seems appropriate for this House to ensure that the reflection of that count is exactly the will expressed by the Members present in the Plenary. I therefore ask you to put the vote on the humanitarian visa initiative again as the first item in tomorrow's vote, Thursday. (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr López Aguilar, Members are well aware of how this House works. I have repeated twice. It is not up to the President, other than to say that we need a majority of votes. So the vote cannot be repeated.

name: Michael CRAMER
text: – Mr President, that was not a mistake by the Members of Parliament, it was a technical mistake, and therefore you have to repeat it tomorrow. (Applause from certain quarters)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: There's no point in yelling honorable. I'm not deaf.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: That concludes the vote. Colleagues, I understand that maybe for you there is a reason for an exchange of views but to those who are not participating in the explanations of votes, please leave the Chamber and show respect to your colleagues. Once again. Those who are not participating in the explanation of votes, please leave the Chamber. Colleagues, would you like to show some respect to those who want to participate in the explanations of vote? Please leave the Chamber.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Mr President, the 2021-2027 financial framework will increase the European Structural and Cohesion Funds for Romania by 8% – EUR 27 billion that we can use to make real motorways, and not on television, to make schools, kindergartens and hospitals, to use them to equip ourselves with modern equipment, so that when we enter a hospital, we go out cured and not die , to be a people of healthy, educated and smart people. However, the current government did not use even 20% of the funds allocated to Romania in 2014. The PSD-ALDE coalition is not interested in education, health, highways that develop commercial and people mobility. They are only interested in attacking the rule of law and killing the free press. European Romania does not mean empires for party leaders. I will fight for Romania's place in Europe at all costs.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Mr President, low—lying areas in both Essex and Holland will be affected by rises in the level of the North Sea, so we swapped expertise. Norwich and Ghent are two cities with amazing histories, so sharing tourism best practices makes sense. By cooperating with our European neighbours and partners on challenges of an ageing population in Cambridgeshire, on women’s professional development in Norfolk and on food waste in Bedfordshire, these are just some of the 112 projects that European funding for cross-border projects Interreg have supported. They represent tens of millions of pounds of investment that would not have happened were we not in the European Union. I would like to thank the Commission for leaving the door open to Britain to continue to participate in Interreg, and I call on the British Government to help protect jobs, businesses and the environment in my region by negotiating our continued access to these important programmes.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Mr President, I support this interim report. We should take good note of the effectiveness of our expenditure to ensure political goals. Having limited political resources, we need to name clear political priorities. I believe that adequate resources have to be ensured to tackle new challenges. Among other priorities, we should properly finance such fields as defence and security, the Erasmus+ and Horizon programmes, allocate adequate funds to the civil society in the EU neighbourhood and ensure that the cohesion policy is for now kept at least at the 2014—2019 levels before gradually downsizing it. The MFF needs to be ambitious, effective and forward—looking. Therefore, I fully support developing the EU own resources which should fill in the budget gap left by Brexit without increasing the fiscal burden for citizens.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Mr President, I support the proposals for the next seven—year budget framework. It is increasingly clear that it is in the interests of the Member States and of citizens to reform the European Union’s system of own resources. The tension that is created by the demands on Member States limits the ability of the EU to run an effective budget that delivers added value. This needs to change. New EU resources need not add to the burden of the EU citizen and should reduce the demands on Member State contributions.  For too long, corporations more powerful than nation states have avoided taxes in ways that citizens never can do. Only this union of Member States acting together can change this. Citizens expect corporations to pay their fair share. Their faith in politicians will only be restored when politicians ensure that fair shares are paid.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Report report uneven. The Multiannual Financial Framework is a long work, extremely important, with a multi-annual, six-year perspective. I wanted to thank Janusz Lewandowski and Jan Olbrycht on this occasion because they have done a fantastic job, but in particular for bringing about the fact that the Erasmus+ programme has finally been doubled and is ultimately to be tripled in the final of this perspective. This is an extremely important programme. I also believe that, from the perspective of the Committee on Culture and Education, it is also very important to enlarge two programmes: Creative Europe and Europe for Citizens. There we have the lowest efficiency of 16-19% – this must be a concern, but for the projects themselves, thank you very much for their support!

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, with my vote, I supported the European Parliament's position on the negotiations on the next financial framework of the European Union. I consider the overall budget level at 1.08% of the EU's GDP to be realistic and modest. I believe that citizens do not expect us to increase resources vigorously, but rather spend them effectively on real priorities such as border control, security and defence.  I also advocate the idea of triple funding for erasmus, I agree that the funds for cohesion policy should not be reduced. On the contrary, I do not agree that the so-called child guarantee should be part of the European Social Fund plus. As far as the revenue side is concerned, I agree with the requirement to tax large digital companies operating throughout the European Union market.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: Mr President! It is exciting to hear the debate here about how everyone is arguing about distributing European taxpayers' money as much as possible. In reality, however, it is not at all a question of who receives money from the EU's bulging budget, which is the key. No, the real question is how the money gets there! The fact is that today the 28 Member States are paying into the budget after an agreement, but what is being proposed here, and what the vast majority of MePs want, is, of course, that the European Union should be able to collect its own taxes. And it's really not about economics at all. It's about power! Because everyone knows that there is a central link between the democratic – voting in a parliament – and that it is parliament that must then be accountable for its decisions, including how to finance its budgets. That is why, of course, the European Parliament and all the federalists want to shift that competence to Parliament, away from the Member States, away from governments, away from the national and democratic. That is at the heart of this report, which is why, of course, I voted 'no' in the name of democracy.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. I consider it one of the most important tasks to define as soon as possible our negotiating position on the union's next long-term budget, including specific amounts. Unfortunately, in its present form, however, the EU budget is not sufficient. New resources and solutions need to be sought for new tasks, for example with the increase in direct EU revenues. I agree with the European Parliament's position that we must prioritise funds for young people, economic growth, job creation, research and climate change, migration, defence and security policy. In addition, I would like to draw attention to the need to continue to place greater emphasis on agriculture and the countryside. Smart technologies can lead to investments that, on the one hand, can make food production cheaper and our food healthier. Moreover, rural communities themselves can benefit from them, for example through smart villages and, more specifically, through its social, service, energy production and training systems.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Mr President, I did not vote for this press for several reasons. I'll bring at least two. One of those reasons is the question of the European Union's own resources. Perhaps unsurprisingly, our group fundamentally opposes the creation of additional own budget resources, whether by new taxation or otherwise. The European Union is not a state, so it should not have its own budgetary resources and its budget should be strictly, directly and closely linked to contributions, in particular contributions from national states, from Member States. The second reason why I did not vote in support is the overall outlook for the structure of those European budgets. If we are serious about protecting the external borders and if we are serious about increasing spending on this chapter, this must also be taken into account in the overall restructure of the budget, and unfortunately this has not happened. So for me, minus and disagreeing.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, we spend an awful lot of time in this Chamber talking about money – it’s our main topic of interest. On this occasion, it was quite funny to see colleagues whose mandate expires in 2019 demanding the right to have a say over how money is spent between 2021 and 2027. But I think actually there will be a shortfall even before then. Obviously, what happens in that MFF is not Britain’s business, but as I speak, the chances of Britain leaving without any withdrawal agreement has hugely increased, which will of course have budgetary implications. There’s been one of those unfortunate misreadings of each other’s political conditions and the prospect is now being put of a withdrawal agreement that requires membership of the Customs Union. Plainly, that isn’t going to get through Parliament, and so we’re losing – I’m afraid – the opportunity to have had a cordial, amicable withdrawal process. There’s still time to put a looser, more skeletal deal in place that would cover the basic courtesies you expect to have with friendly neighbours, but that time is very short now.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Mr President, I would like to say this: show me where the money is going and you have shown me your policies. The multi-financial framework proposals for 2021—2027 make this clear. It puts fighting before feeding. We are moving from a common plan to feed ourselves to a common plan to go to war. A twenty-two times’ increase in defence spending to pay for this. Agriculture, rural development and cohesion funding to take the hit. A sleeping beauty is born all right, and now we are going to have to pay for it.  Also what is going to take a major hit is the sovereignty of our treasuries moving to a system of own—resources for the European Union. What on first viewing seems like something benign enough is in fact another power grab and the beginnings of creating a Treasury for the EU. The proposed increase in GNI contributions from Member States is something I cannot support, because the soup it creates contains ingredients that are indigestible when it comes to Ireland’s neutrality.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Mr President, in this complex global security environment, it is undeniable that sometimes weapons and other military machinery might also end up in conflict zones, contributing to grave human rights violations. The common position on arms exports lays down procedure and common criteria by which individual Member States should guide their transactions of arms and military technologies. Profits cannot be made at the expense of human security and respect of human rights. Each Member State should take the responsibility for its arms exports. Within this report, we call on the exporting countries to apply assessment criteria when exporting weaponry, and ensure full transparency of such transactions. Selling weapons to violent regimes is not a matter of negotiation.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by This is the European Parliament's fifth approach to illegal arms exports and a de facto fifth failure. Perhaps not so complete, not devastating, but unfortunately the effectiveness in this project – a project on the transparency of certain restrictions, building standards, we must admit it, ends in failure. I abstained on this resolution, with this report, primarily because I am opposed to transport, arms exports and arms trade where there are conflicts and great humanitarian problems. On the other hand, however, I would like to point out all the time that the European institutions and the Countries of the European Union are unfortunately ineffective in this matter.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: Mr President! Yesterday in the Chamber Angela Merkel, the German Chancellor, spoke of the need for a common European defence. We have also heard the same thing in the past from Macron in Paris and from President Juncker and so on. This report is, of course, part of that strategy. I cannot imagine anything more dangerous than the idea of European defence being detached from the America which for generations now has been the guarantee that we have just as peaceful conditions as we have.
