A World War I in which it was completely inconceivable that the outcome would have been as it was if the Americans had not intervened. A World War II world war, etc. I cannot understand, and I cannot understand at all, how this house can have such ahistorical, historyless approach to something as important as the Europeans' defence. We need the Americans, they need us, even if we may not agree with everything that is going on in the White House at the moment. All other things being equal under the Constitution, you only sit for four years at a time, we should not use these sudden sentiments to throw the baby out with the bathwater.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by This is another resolution of this Parliament that undermines the independence of the Member States. There is no valid reason for the European Union to enter this area. We did not sign up to such a Union, we did not agree with such a Union, and now, one by one, the Union is trying to eliminate the competences of the Member States from everything.  As far as the arms trade is concerned, it is governed in great detail by the law of all Member States. There is no need to add to this, and if different countries interpret 8 of the criteria of the common position differently, they have the right to do so. Why will one country now tell the other that the latter interpret these 8 criteria badly? And I can already guess which countries will tell them they are wrong. As always, we are wrong.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Mr President, we’re talking about a common standard for exports of weapons. How about we adopt a common standard that we stop exporting weapons in the first place? Why are we involved in this dirty game? Is the European Union not already filled with massive resources, which means that we can have a very high quality of life and everything we need, if it was properly distributed, without getting involved in the dirty, filthy low—life business of producing the instruments of death? Ireland, for the first time in centuries, has peace. We are lucky to have it. And the reason why we have peace is because we’ve moved out of that area. We’ve started to talk to each other, and as a result of it we now live in a better place. We need higher standards all round here. I’m voting in favour of this report, but, sadly, I have to say it is a floor, a very low floor, like a toilet.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: Mr President! I am keen to say a few positive words about the Schwab report, because it is so vitally important for growth and trade that we have proper rules for the internal market. But one of the major problems with the internal market is precisely that it has developed at such a rapid pace that the sensible rules have not been able to keep up. We see this, for example, in the judgments of the European Court of Justice, which oblige Member States to suddenly pay social benefits beyond the reasonable, completely beyond what the electorate has ever been offered when they have voted on the Treaties as a result of the single market. I therefore believe that we need to take a critical look at what the internal market really means today. The free movement of goods and capital may be relatively seamless, but services and workers are beginning to cause ever more problems in relation to our social welfare systems. We must not close our eyes to this, even if Mr Tsipras does not do so. Schwab has a hard time opening his.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. I voted in favour of this report. I am pleased that, thanks to my initiative included in the previous annual competition report, we have started our work and we have now entered a new stage of this. The proposal was supported by the S&D Group, inter alia, because it guarantees that NATIONAL COMPETITION AUTHORITIES will pursue more effective procedures by providing stronger decision-making and sanctioning tools. It was proposed in the European Parliament report that the independence of national competition authorities should not be jeopardised by possible intentions to influence government. Our positive vote also required that the harmonisation of the member states' leniency procedures be sufficiently regulated and that the maximum amount of the court should be set at at least 10 % of the total worldwide turnover of the undertaking concerned in the future.

name: Paul BRANNEN
text: – Mr President, climate change is the biggest threat that we all face, whether we live in a rich country or a poor country, and emissions from heavy goods vehicles are a major cause of CO2 emissions. Heavy goods vehicles delivering heavy loads to construction sites with steel and concrete, brick and block are a major cause of emissions in our major cities around the world. However, if we were to build in wood – which is up to five times lighter than concrete, steel, brick and block – we could drastically reduce the number of deliveries to our construction sites by as much as 80%. An 80% reduction in heavy goods vehicles delivering steel and concrete, brick and block to building sites around the world, replacing it with wood, would make a considerable contribution to tackling climate change. If we are serious about tackling climate change, we need to build in wood.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The report on CO2 emission standards for heavy goods vehicles is an excellent example of how a good intention, a good report, a good proposal can be spoiled in the votes themselves. I did not support this report primarily because it is ultimately completely unrealistic, unacceptable by many countries and extremely costly to implement. However, I believe that in such projects the European Parliament should exercise extreme caution when taking into account geographical and industrial circumstances and try to ensure that the proposals it submits are adequate and feasible. Unfortunately, as a result of this vote, we have gone far too far into a completely unrealistic, extremely costly and impossible area.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this report once again, after the Environment Committee adopted by a large majority the best compromise, which at the same time advocates convergence with the ecological targets set by the Paris Agreement and the protection of social interests and which, moreover, still brings economic benefits. This is the real solution of mutual gain. We are at a time when we cannot afford to make compromises. I therefore stress the importance of introducing penalty measures for non-compliance with the CO2 emission targets, alongside incentive measures for zero-emission vehicles. These penalties must be effective and cannot be lower than the very cost of the technological transition. If not, we will come to the ridiculousness of being cheaper to pay fines than to make the necessary investments. We have to be consistent. The CO2 correction factor for advanced performance alternative fuels is already included in the Renewable Energy Directive II. This type of measure would lead to double benefit, which makes no sense in this regulation, since car manufacturers would be benefiting from an effort that is actually made by the producers of these fuels.  Ladies and gentlemen, there is only one future... (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker.)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. I supported the resolution to express Parliament's dissatisfaction with the fact that the Commission, and in particular the Council, is blocking the interinstitutional agreement, which has been envisaged for two years, on a comprehensive mechanism to penalise member states' conduct in breach of fundamental rights. Since then, the political stakes of the issue have been further increased by the rise of extreme anti-EU populist forces in Europe and the systematic downsizing of the democratic rule of law and the daily practice of conscious violations by some governments. Unfortunately, the best, sorry, most serious example of the latter in my own country is provided by the Orban government, which, taking advantage of the shortcomings of EU law and the inconsistency of the European institutions, continues its policy of disrepressing European values and law and destroying democratic institutions without consequences. The Hungarian example itself demonstrates that the EU does not currently have a means of enforcing compliance with Community rules.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. The destruction of the rule of law is spreading as an infectious disease in the European Union. It started in Hungary, continued in Poland, but now we need to see its signs from Italy to Romania, the Czech Republic to Slovakia or Bulgaria. By violating the rule of law, these countries are not fighting the EU, but against their own citizens. When they undermine judicial independence, when corruption is allowed to spread in the country, when they violate media freedom, they violate the rights of their own citizens. At the same time, this is also dangerous for the European Union. If European integration cannot assert the fundamental rights and values on which it is based, if it lets Orbans, Kaczyńskis and Dragnea undermine the values of the rule of law undisturbed, then this community will crumble. Decisive measures and decisive action are needed to stop the destruction of the rule of law in the European Member States.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I abstained from voting on this report after much deliberation. I want to say in advance that I am a great believe in values such as democracy, the rule of law, the principles on which European civilisation is based. However, I must admit that the report, as written and conceived, does not, in my opinion, solve this problem.  I think that it creates a certain principle of collective guilt and mechanisms such as the fact that individual Member States will report on the human rights situation in their country every year, and this report is likely to be evaluated by the European Commission, rather than effectively contributing to the protection of these European values. So I am in support of protecting the rule of law, human rights, so that the European Union intervenes against states where there is a manifest violation of these values, but unfortunately this report does not provide solutions that could bring about this.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Democracy is the control of the people over power, not the mobilising of mechanisms of control over nations, over their democratic decisions, over their laws, over the institutions they create. Today's vote is an act of usurpation of Parliament in relation to the Treaties, because let us always remember that, even if we represent a majority of the states, we are only one of the authorities established by our states under the Treaties. Whoever disputes this fact, who gives Parliament more power, questions the European Treaties. Whoever attacks the countries of Europe is attacking the Union that these countries have concluded, because the European Union is the union of our countries, not an ideology that will be supported by the majority of the European Parliament. Today's act is very dangerous not only for democracy, but also for the very cooperation of the peoples of Europe.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Democracy, the rule of law and human rights are the foundation of the European Union, the soul of Europeans. This is how we are perceived all over the world, on all continents. The European Union is a model for other peoples and for other countries to create democracy and prosperity for its citizens. Unfortunately, in recent years, we have been experiencing a crisis of respect in some Member States for these great, great values of civilisation. The power of nationalist, authoritarian, anti-democratic movements destroying the rule of law and the rule of law is increasing. However, the European Union does not have the efficient and viable tools to prevent these movements, which is why, unlike the previous previous member, I am in favour of this mechanism. It is necessary to protect European citizens from authoritarian rule.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, I support this resolution, but I want to underline that this is only the first concrete step towards ensuring that the Member States respect the principles that the case has subscribed to. Central and Eastern European countries’ sole claim to fulfil the Copenhagen criteria, including their political criteria on the respect for human rights and protection of minorities, but they also made promises to improve their unaddressed issues. Let me take the example of my country, Latvia. Before accession, it was subject to the screening mechanisms that showed the need to give minorities more representation and finish with the practice of statelessness. Since the accession, Latvia put this request into the archives. It might seem ironic if it were not so sad. So, what can the EU do to avoid this moral hazard and post-accession opportunism? The reply can be found in this resolution. The Commission must present a proposal for a comprehensive new mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The whole policy of stick and carrot in the European Union is that carrots are getting smaller and the stick is getting thicker. We have already voted today on sanctions on arms exports, and now we are voting on a 'good deal' for all countries that will not listen to Germany's leadership role in this endeavour.  This is a clear violation of the treaties and the philosophy on which the European Union was to be founded. It is a tool for disciplining countries that do not listen. And what will be treated as a lack of the rule of law or the rule of law, we already know: this will be what Germany considers to be a lack of the rule of law. Not, for example, that Members are being told for the content of their statements in this Parliament, not that the vote on the application of Article 7 to Hungary violates the principle of vote counting, not that President Juncker appoints the Secretary-General in violation of the law, but that the violation of the law and the rule of law will be what will be out of hand with the Union that governinges here.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Mr President, I’m very glad the Georgian Government continues to demonstrate political will and determination to further advance the reforms within the scope of the Association Agreement. I also welcome the wide—ranging support of the Georgian people for the country’s pro—European choice, as well as the long—standing cross—party accord for this strategic policy goal. While undergoing economic and social reforms, Georgia equally – as other countries with European inspirations – needs to stay firmly focused on the implementation of its political obligations too. Full respect of core democratic principles and fundamental freedoms is the country’s essential commitment within the Association Agreement and needs to remain an absolute priority for this and other Georgian governments for years to come.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I was happy to support this report. For me, as a Member from the Czech Republic, a country that unfortunately had experience of Soviet occupation in the communist era, it is positive to read that the former Soviet Union country of Georgia is now an active partner of the European Union, that it is seeking to join the European Union, and that it is implementing the reforms that are part of today's partnership, today's relationship. It is very positive that Georgia is today the main leader of cooperation between the European Union and the region there, and I am very glad that we have adopted this commendable report, and I hope that this report will lead to a further strengthening of the Georgian Government's desire to develop a strategy for membership of the European Union and also to strengthen the appetite of the Georgian people for this country to become a member of the European Union.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Mr President, Georgia is very important both strategically and geopolitically. My political family has friends on the Georgian political scene, even in the current Georgian Government we have partners and we think that the European Union should pay due attention to Georgia, including because this country has become a model example for Russian pressure some time ago and it is good to monitor and monitor the situation closely. That is why it is good that we are monitoring the implementation of the association agreement, so it is good that progress is being made here. When we look at the path that Georgia has taken since the collapse of the Soviet Union, it is truly admirable what this country has achieved. It certainly deserves the support of the European Union and all of us in the future.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, unfortunately, this is a different case from the one we were talking about with Georgia. This time it is about the implementation of the Association Agreement between the European Union and Moldova. Unfortunately, this report is, unfortunately, rightly so, very critical of Moldova. In short, Moldova, with its internal political development, is not moving closer to the European Union, unfortunately this country is not meeting the criteria that we have for our members and partners, such as rule of law building, independent elections, functional justice and so on. The report describes very critically what is the main problem – the state of the judiciary, the strange electoral reform, the suppression of independent media. I agree with the part that says that if the situation does not improve, the limitation of macro-financial assistance to this country must be considered.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Mr President, I was recently in Moldova. This country is expecting parliamentary elections very soon after the New Year. It is a country that is plagued by a number of ills, particularly various corruption scandals and scandals that need to be carefully investigated.  I have to say, based on my own experience, my own observation, that I feel that they are not measured there by the same meter, that in some cases the scandals are swept under the carpet, whereas in some cases, rather for political reasons, the exponents are under a lot of pressure. It is also a country that faces, we can boldly call it, Russian interference, influence through the media. Moldova has already taken some measures to combat this pressure, but this needs to continue and once again developments in the country need to be closely monitored.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Although I am in favour of granting humanitarian visas in justified cases, I voted against a report in which regulations are based on a dubious legal basis.  Allowing entry into the territory of a Member State issuing a visa for the sole purpose of applying in that State may create a number of problems and should provide legal and safe procedures to avoid deaths at sea and the activities of smugglers. There is also a need to provide additional rules on the handling of persons to whom a country will be allowed to come, but without protection. There is also a well-founded fear of overburloading embassies as migrants move within the European Union.  In addition, the extremely complicated procedure for granting a visa within a maximum period of two weeks will be difficult to implement. Equally unfavourable is the idea of allowing a visa application at a distance and a mechanism for allowing external service providers.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Of course, I voted in favour of the report by my colleague, Mr Lopez Aguilar. I voted in favour with my political group and other members. But what happened at the time of the vote does not, above all, honour us: the European Parliament. This is a technical error. And I understand when ultra-right-wing politicians say that we do not have to issue humanitarian visas just because it is supposedly that there are some migrants supposedly coming, and we have to fight against migrants. This is absurd, it is their rhetoric.  But when the President of Parliament, Mr Tāni, seeing that this is a technical mistake, does not want to vote because the majority in this house in this house is in favour of issuing humanitarian visas - this seems to me to be a mistake, and we should necessarily, in principle, have had to vote on this document. He's very important. Humanitarian visas display the European flag in the world.  It was imperative that we vote in favour. Thank you!

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item on the agenda is the current debate (Article 153a of the Rules of Procedure) on strengthening the Union's resilience to the influence of external actors in the European Parliament's next election campaign (2018/2919(RSP)).

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: Author. – Mr President, Mr Representative of the Council, Commissioner, it seems to me that it is important, first of all, to realise that in the digital world, or as was said before that in the virtual world, the threats that occur to transparency, to the principles of exemption and independence in electoral processes, if you want to the pillars of democracy, are not virtual threats, they are not digital threats, they are real threats. And so it is essential that, in view of the experience of recent years and in particular what is suspected to have happened in the case of Brexit and the Brexit referendum, which may have happened in the 2016 US elections, which may be happening in some movements, such as movements on the issue of Catalonia and whether there should be more autonomy , less autonomy, independence or non-independence.  What we verify is that, digitally, there is constant interference in these processes and interference whose author we are not able to identify and often whose design we are not able to identify. And, therefore, it is with this new challenge to the issues of exemption, impartiality and transparency in the electoral process, but also in the debate that precedes the electoral process, that we have to review those that are the procedures of public authorities and, in particular, of the entities responsible for the electoral process, whether at national level or at European level. Data protection is fundamental here in the first place. We have already taken an important step when we have made the framework through this data protection regulation in which the European Union is highly innovative. It is true that the Commission itself has already come up with a set of ideas and proposals to combat cyber-attacks, but we may go further. We must go further and view these threats as global threats.  And here I wanted to introduce another factor yet, before saying what are the two fields in which I think we should act. We're dealing with external threats here. It is the theme of this current debate: external threats. But let's not have any illusions, there are also internal threats. That is, in this digital world, whether of cyberattack or of the abuse of the data that is collected, there can be both internal agents and external agents, because the opponents of democracy, the opponents of transparency, the opponents of exemption are not only foreign powers. We have evidence that they are acting in accordance with their geostrategic interest, but there is no doubt that there are also groups and entities within our borders, european borders, which have the same designs or have designs of the same kind. And here I would say that we must act in two key areas: one is the area of regulating data processing and protecting citizens in general and their data, and this goes to operators in general and also goes to businesses, foundations, political parties, public authorities.  And then we have to have another concern, which is an already criminal concern. It is already a second concern, because no more rules and guarantees that we have there will always be cyberattacks, there will always be criminals who have some success. And we must have technological conditions and police investigative conditions that will also allow us to prevent and repel and punish these kinds of attacks, whether they are foreign attacks, whether they are national attacks.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I would like to thank the House for the opportunity to exchange views on the very topical issue of increasing EU resilience against the influence of foreign actors on the upcoming European election campaign. As you will be aware, the European Council attaches great importance to the matter. This year it addressed, both in June and October, questions of internal security, including cybersecurity and disinformation, also in the context of the upcoming European elections. Work is also under way in the Council in response to the Commission communication on ‘Tackling online disinformation: a European approach’, and the package on securing free and fair European elections. On the latter, the Council is engaged in strengthening the EU Regulation on the Statute and Funding of European Political Parties and Foundations and is examining the non—legislative part of the package in order to adopt conclusions from the Council and Member States as soon as possible. In addition, we are looking forward to the action plan for a coordinated EU response to disinformation, which is being jointly developed by the Commission and the EEAS. It should be relevant both for EU institutions and for Member States, as well as for international partners, and should propose concrete measures and resources to respond to hostile information operations in a coordinated and comprehensive way. In 2018, the number of social media users world-wide reached almost 3.2 billion, marking an increase of 13% in just one year. With the number of users expanding at such a rate, it comes as no surprise why social media have become a highly attractive target to cyberattacks, capable of impacting electoral campaigns and thus destabilising the democratic basis of our societies. Criminal misuse of the internet is a serious concern for the Council. It bears the risk of violating the privacy and fundamental rights of our citizens, attacking the integrity of information and seeking to disrupt the credibility of the internet. Therefore, it should be our common goal to ensure that technology used in electoral campaigns safeguards these basic principles and guarantees the legitimacy of electoral outcomes. The improvement of our resilience and preparedness to counter cyberattacks, including targeting electoral campaigns, requires our full, immediate and constant effort. In the last two years, we have seen numerous initiatives, measures and instruments in the area of cybersecurity, seeking to enhance the resilience of our systems and networks. The ambitious Cybersecurity Package, presented by the Commission in September 2017, was followed by a set of Council conclusions and an action plan for the continuous monitoring of their respective implementation. They emphasise the need to enhance the EU’s capacity to prevent, deter and respond to cyberattacks. In June 2017, the Council agreed on a framework for a joint EU diplomatic response to malicious cyber-activities. In October 2017, the Political and Security Committee (PSC) agreed on implementing guidelines outlining the measures as part of the framework and decision—making procedures. Member States have seen repeated their wish to continuously improve the EU’s ability to respond to diplomatically to malicious cyber activities in order to influence the behaviour of potential aggressors in the short and the long term. Finally, the European Council, in its conclusion last month, calls for measures to ‘protect the Union’s democratic system and combat disinformation, including in the context of the upcoming European elections in full respect of fundamental rights’. It is our firm commitment, in line with the call to ensure rapid examination and follow-up of the recent set of measures proposed by the Commission on election cooperation networks, online transparency, protection against cybersecurity incidents, unlawful data manipulation, fighting disinformation campaigns and tightening the rules on European political party funding. The protection of the European Parliament elections and of the democratic basis of our society, including cyberspace, is our paramount task and joint responsibility.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Parliament for this most urgent plenary debate. We will have elections to the European Parliament in May 2019 and 50 various elections will have taken place by 2020. We have to adjust the protection of the integrity of our elections to the digital age. And we have to protect our democratic processes from new ways of manipulation by third countries or private interests. The Facebook Cambridge Analytica scandal showed how personal data can be misused for the profiling and targeting of voters, and how valuable our new data protection rules are. We have seen the spread of fake news or disinformation coordinated on an unprecedented scale, including from outside the EU. We have learnt of hacking of candidates and cyber attacks on elections around the world, including in Europe. Crucial electoral rules have been breached or circumvented, in particular existing rules on the transparency of campaign financing. Investigations are ongoing into allegations of dark financing from undisclosed third country sources. The most cited source of activities interfering with elections in Europe is Russia. But others are learning from Russia. We have observed other countries and private interests increase their capabilities for election interference. Given the very nature of our Union, electoral interference in one Member State affects the EU as a whole. National authorities cannot address these threats by working in isolation, nor can private sector self—regulation solve it all. Soon we will publish the results of a special Eurobarometer on elections and democracy. Already now I can share with you that it shows that Europeans are worried: 73% are concerned about disinformation or misinformation online in the pre-election period; 81% are in favour of online social networks being fully transparent about political content online and about who is paying for them; 80% are in favour of online social networks making clear the amount of money they receive from political parties. The Commission and the European External Action Service are working hand in hand to define and implement an appropriate EU—wide response. In the long term, our objective should be that our respective societies all become more resilient and capable of defending themselves against disinformation. This means, for example, improving media literacy, access to quality journalism, supporting independent fact checkers and working with online platforms on how to prevent disinformation campaigns online without – and this is important to mention – restricting freedom of expression and freedom of speech. In the short term, our priority should be a coordinated response to the threats against the upcoming European and national elections. The recent election package adopted by the Commission includes several concrete measures. They are: the establishment of elections cooperation networks at national and at EU level; guidance on the application of data protection rules in the electoral context; recommendations on greater transparency in paid online political advertisements and communication; strengthened cybersecurity; diligent enforcement of existing electoral rules; awareness—raising and a legislative proposal allowing to sanction the misuse of personal data for electoral purposes.  I encourage the co—legislators to complete their work on it as soon as possible so that it is in force before the elections. We need to improve our analytical capabilities to detect, analyse and expose disinformation campaigns in cooperation with EU Member States and with the intelligence community working on hybrid threats.  Allow me to give you a quick overview of our follow—up actions. The Commission has written to the Member States urging them to set up their national election networks, and to identify appropriate single points of contact by the end of this month. We will convene the first meeting of the European election network in January. This network will facilitate the fast exchange of information and best practices, but also provide support to Member States in addressing the main areas of concern, which are: coordination of all relevant national authorities involved in the protection of elections; cybersecurity; strategy communication; data protection and hybrid threats. In the area of cybersecurity, the Commission organised in October a high—level conference bringing together, for the first time, 70 representatives of Member States, national electoral and cybersecurity authorities. The results of this important conference, which was organised mainly by Julian King, who is here today with me, will feed into the 2018 colloquium on fundamental rights, which Commission First Vice—President Timmermans and I will organise together in November, and which will be dedicated this year to democracy in the European Union. The Commission welcomes that the leading online platforms and representatives of the online advertising sector have agreed on a self—regulatory code of practice to address online disinformation. The Commission is monitoring closely its implementation.  However, this is not enough. In June this year, the European Council tasked the Commission and the External Action Service to develop an action plan on tackling disinformation. This action plan, which we are currently working on, will outline specific proposals for a coordinated EU response to the challenge of disinformation. We will build on existing initiatives, such as the work of the East StratCom Task Force, which was created in 2015 to address Russia’s ongoing disinformation campaigns. It will also build on the work of the Hybrid Fusion Cell, as well as the European Centre of Excellence for countering hybrid threats. An important part of their work is showing who is behind the disinformation attacks that are aimed against EU interests.  Addressing disinformation also means that we need to improve our ability to make our voice heard, to pass our messages and to tell our story. We therefore need to strengthen our strategic communications capacities, both within the EU and abroad. Finally, close cooperation and coordination of our efforts with the European Parliament in the run—up to the 2019 elections is absolutely crucial, and I fully trust we can rely on your support.

name: David McALLISTER
text: – Mr President, the EU Member States, as we have just heard, are facing an unprecedented threat to their democratic societies. Disinformation campaigns and the continuous support for anti-European political forces are undermining the European project and Western democracies in general. The efforts of non-state actors and third countries – and let’s name it, especially Russia – to distort facts, to manipulate reality, to foster distrust in the democratic process and even to interfere in our democratic elections, are completely unacceptable.  We must act immediately and boldly to enhance the EU’s resilience against such threats, including the risks for our next European elections in May 2019. In the run—up to the European elections, the European Union should focus on cooperation and information. Member States and EU institutions need to cooperate more intensively and share information more effectively. In this context, Commissioner Jourová, I support the Commission’s proposal for a cybersecurity competence centre. The European Union needs an effective, well-targeted and tailor-made strategy to communicate and promote EU policies in the run-up to our next elections.  We have to stand united. The EU cannot, and must not, tolerate an undeclared war against our liberal values underpinning the peace and prosperity of our continent. (Applause)

name: Claude MORAES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the EPP and thank the author very much for introducing this topical debate. It could not be more important and better timed. For my group, the S&D, this is a big priority and I think the previous speaker spoke very eloquently on why that is the case, and I should say that very directly to him. But let’s be very clear, colleagues. For years we have been warning about the threat posed by the collection of citizens’ data online by a handful of social media companies and the power of those who hold this information. The revelations involving Cambridge Analytica and Facebook highlight the extent of this problem and show that the issue has now reached the point of threatening our core values. The author said that these were real threats to our democracy, and not virtual threats. The issue today, as the Commissioners have begun to set out, is one of action, and my Group is interested now in action and not just talking about the issue. Seven months out from the European elections, after the presidential elections in the US and after the UK referendum and leaving the European Union, I think it is about time that we talked about what we do, and the Commission has begun this process. But so has Parliament. So let’s be clear in what we have to do and let’s not leave this debate without saying it. Recent requirements in the last weeks introduced in the United States, but not here in the European Union – and also by the way, in the United Kingdom – to verify the identity, location and sponsor of political advertisements, have happened, but not here. This is important, and the same standards should be applied throughout the EU. But this does not just reveal the data involved in targeting users, which could help Facebook users contextualise political ads, understand how their data has been used, or potentially misused, and be able to respond to attempts to manipulate their opinion. We should have full algorithmic accountability and transparency for citizens to be able to protect themselves against any manipulation and to protect our electoral processes from possible foreign interference. We have now proven that this is happening, and we should have GDPR, as the Commissioner said, but also the cybersecurity resilience which Commissioner King should redouble his efforts to provide. And we should if possible – and I say this to the Council – be imaginative about e-privacy regulation if that is also possible, because the Facebook model was not just dealt with by the question of GDPR. But we need further tools and further regulation, and not just GDPR to deal with those further issues. We have to look at how political parties and campaigns are using social platforms for campaign purposes. We have called for a code of conduct to be developed with the participation of all actors concerned. And if not, then legislative action is needed. Regulation is needed. This is not about robust debate or just aggressive democracy. This is about manipulation and, as the Council said, sometimes about criminal activity and breaking the law. That is where the line has been crossed and that is where we need legislative action when necessary. But we also believe that applying conventional offline electoral safeguards, such as rules on transparency and limits to spending, respect for silence periods and equal treatment of candidates is essential, making it easy to recognise online political paid advertisements and the organisations behind them. Banning profiling for electoral purposes, including the use of online behaviour that may reveal political preference. Now is the time for action. We have spoken about the threats to our democracy, to our very core values. We at the European Parliament have had the hearings from journalists from The Guardian, we’ve examined Cambridge Analytica, we have interviewed Facebook. Now is the time for action. We have the commitment from the Commission. Let’s ask them to redouble their efforts, but here in Parliament our democracy is under threat. Let’s do something about it, and let’s have that action now.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank Commissioner Jourová for naming a series of elections we face in the years to come, because not only European elections, but every election which happens in each and every EU Member State requires a very resilient environment – resilient to external hostile malicious interference as well as, of course, to private interests. There is a role naturally of governments, legislators, national legislators as well as social media companies and civil society to build this resilience, to raise this awareness. Of course, there is a huge role for the EU and, in particular in the case of cybersecurity, for cooperation between the EU and NATO to tackle these challenges and these threats.  I would like to mention also the importance of transatlantic cooperation. Lessons learned from interference elsewhere in both the United States and other parts of the world enable cooperation over political divisions in tackling these problems because, rightly, we say that hostile violation of universal suffrage is a violation of fundamental human rights, and the role of politicians, of public actors, is to raise awareness. Therefore, we stress the importance of quality journalism. I would like to tackle one thing: the electoral process is still a dominant role and competence of EU Member States. Also, I would like to say that external actors like Russia have tailor—made these attacks, and therefore we have to be rather cautious in imposing common measures to tackle this, although I stress that we have to cooperate and cooperate closely.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, this is a very serious issue, and I am very happy to see that, judging so far by the speakers that have spoken, we have a very broad consensus here in Parliament. The fight against disinformation, from my point of view, involves two main aspects. One is enhancing our resilience against those that are spreading disinformation and the other is appropriate education awareness, in order to be able to differentiate between what is really disinformation and what is not.  If I look at these two main aspects, I need to say that on the first one, one should also emphasise the regulatory framework, and I did listen very carefully to you, Madam State Secretary and the Council’s attitude. To be honest, I use that as an opportunity to say I don’t see it, for example, in the trilogue on the Cyber Security Act. I am not talking about the presidency. I know it is a very tough task to achieve, but the mindset in some Member States that co-decide on the common position has not changed. That brings me to the second aspect, and that is that education awareness is not just about citizens; it is about politicians. I very much appreciate what Commissioner Jourová has said and that is that the main threat is Russia. If we don’t use the proper words then we will be failing, and I must say that, once again, I don’t hear that clear language from the Council. There is clear evidence of that in terms of scale, coordination and also the stated willingness of the Russians to do so, and it is increasingly dominant. The European elections are behind doors. They are absolutely key. They are also a test on what we have just spoken about and what we are tackling. A final remark, on the East StratCom. Once again, I do appreciate what the Commissioner said. It is understaffed, but it is doing excellent work. It needs a permanent budget and I would appreciate it if we could see more emphasis from the Commission – I must say I was never impressed by the attitude of High Representative Mogherini in this respect: she can provide better assistance – but also emphasis from the Council. That is key. They are  excellent and we are failing to support them.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. For a while, it looked to me that colleagues would weigh themselves in the fallacy that only Ukraine would be at the centre of the cyber and fake news attacks of the information war. It has taken several years – from 2013 to 2014, when it became apparent in Ukraine – for Europeans to understand that they themselves are the target of this information war. I believe that this recognition is the first step in defence, and I think that many of the measures that are now being taken or have been adopted are also right – in keeping with what has been said.  However, I am still not sure whether the scale of this attack, which Russia has decided on the stability of the European Union, is understood, and I just think that the endowment of the programmes that we have decided so far is so weak that I cannot believe that the dimension has been understood. I would also like to point out once again, in this context, that it is a major problem for prominent politicians from European Member States to become part of Russia's information and uncertainty campaigns. As a German, I can only keep pointing out the former chancellor and current Rosneft boss Gerhard Schroeder. I also know, however, that we need to talk about Mr Gusenbauer in Austria or Mr Prodi in Italy. The Manafort papers have given us some insight. Parties have to deal with this if they really want to take on the challenge. Otherwise, I would like to thank Anna Fotyga. Because what we really need to do better is to strengthen journalism, to strengthen independent media. Because you win against propaganda not with propaganda, but with quality journalism and information.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, the shady, secretive Constitutional Research Council (CRC), chaired by Richard Cook, donated half a million pounds to the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP), then AggregateIQ – according to openDemocracy – received tens of thousands from the DUP in the last two days of the Brexit campaign to target voters and social media. Electoral law expert, Gavin Millar QC, has said that the Electoral Commission should demand answers from the DUP, Vote Leave and Mr Cook about possible links and allegations that dark money was used to influence Brexit. Whilst we confront the Cambridge Analytica scandal, the British Government refused to extend electoral transparency legislation to the north of Ireland to expose this rotten saga. Coincidentally, the British Government is being propped up by whom? The DUP – the same DUP who refused to comment on the origins of this dark money, a party with no respect for rights, no respect for privacy and absolutely no concern for how the dark money was used for a Brexit outcome that damages Ireland, particularly the constituency that it represents.

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, all reasonable steps must be taken to protect the integrity of the forthcoming European parliamentary elections. There has been some evidence in recent years of outside actors – and in particular, the Russian state – seeking to interfere. There has also been, going back many years, slack control of the use of data harvested by social media giants and the use it’s put to, so vigilance is certainly in order. But I’m afraid to say that something else is going on here today: it’s the spectacle of the European political class clutching at straws.  So many votes have gone against its wishes – from Brexit to the defeat of Hillary Clinton, to the Italian election result, and more besides – that an elite which is unwilling to question its own complacent assumptions is looking for a scapegoat. And that scapegoat is the idea that so-called ‘fake news’ has led people into a false state of consciousness, causing them to turn unfairly against benevolent rulers and break out of parameters for political debate and action set in their own best interests from above.  Part of the thesis is the contention that almost any form of nation-state affiliation represents a giant step back towards the terrifying ethnic nationalism that left Europe drenched in blood in the 20th century. Mr Macron was at it again at the weekend when he claimed that nationalism was the opposite of patriotism. In fact, moderate, sensible nation—state preference is at the heart of sustaining the social solidarity we need to allow collective decision-making to run smoothly, and the revolt against the overreach of the globalist establishment is deep-rooted and based on considered thought. At its heart lies opposition to the ‘no borders’ ideology being pushed by the left and much of the centrist establishment too, which threatens to shatter social cohesion across Europe. Working—class voters in more prosperous European countries – people who depend on selling their labour for their income – are also in revolt against the creation of a single European labour market, which they quite correctly judge to be against their own best interests.  At a time like this, a wise European Union would be loosening the corset, allowing more room for national decision-making and respecting the mandates handed down to national governments by national electorates, but the EU we have is doing the opposite, picking fights with member nations on an almost weekly basis. My advice, therefore, is to prepare for an election result next year that most of you are not going to like, and don’t blame it on Russian bots or fake news because it will be a real message considered and profoundly meant from the people to the political class.

name: Jacques COLOMBIER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, fearing a defeat announced in the forthcoming European elections, the European and globalist cenacles have already found the explanation: the peoples of Europe would be mysteriously stripped of their free will when they vote by, I quote, 'a great foreign power'. As such, if there is indeed a manipulation of the spirits that we have just observed, it is through a clip of the French government, paid for by the French taxpayers, which attacks, coincidentally, the Hungarian Prime Minister and the Italian Minister of the Interior. What do European experts think of electoral interference? Was the Commission offended? Point at all. As such, do you intend to block the accounts and financial flows of the American billionaire George Soros, who funds a number of influential structures within the European Union? At least have the courage to nominate Russia on the issue! I think the Russian president must be laughing at the paranormal and supra-media powers you give him. So I'm going to, in the same vein, give you some advice. Some time ago, in these places, your inspiration, the inimitable Jean-Claude Juncker, declared, I quote, "that he was talking with the leaders of the other planets". So why don't we accuse the Martians this time of interference in the next European elections?

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Mr President, with tongue firmly in cheek, we all know that the European Union doesn’t do electoral interference – ‘well, of course not!’ But this, of all days – boy, doesn’t Brussels do irony! – the EU’s cyber enemies would be proud of the choreographed showdown on the deal that our Prime Minister, Theresa May, is presenting to cabinet as we speak. I’d like to find one page out of the 500 that isn’t the product of massive, manipulative and misguided interference by the European Union in a democratic decision. Tell me just where the European Union hasn’t interfered. What about the Scottish independence referendum? The EU first refused to comment, and then – just on the eve of purdah – José Manuel Barroso threatened voters in Scotland with European Union expulsion if they dared to assert themselves. A threat to the thousands of European Union Scots citizens, by the way. For the European Union, those who assert the right to be different are labelled ‘populist’. Look, stop the interference in free speech, free thought and free media and free journalistic press.

name: Esther de LANGE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, Commissioner, Commissioner, Dutch poet Lucebert said: 'Everything of value is defenseless'. If we do not act, Lucebert seems to be right, so we must now ensure the resilience of our democracy by acting against foreign influence. That's a difficult balance. I have just listened to the last three speakers who actually say in the context of freedom of the media: let the Russians pull the strings here. The EU is very quickly criticised for propaganda. However, doing nothing is not an option! I will give you the concrete examples, especially for the profession behind me. Let me start in my own member state, the Netherlands. The day after the plane MH17 was brought down, Putin's troll factories went three times as fast to shift the blame to Ukraine via social media. Then brexit. There are also findings that Kremlin trolls wanted to influence the referendum. Worse still, we already have a governing party in our own European Union using manipulated video footage on social media.  I welcome the Proposals from the European Commission. After all, the fight against this is desperately needed and must be waged on several fronts. Of course, first of all, raising awareness of fake news through education and political awareness campaigns, in close consultation with the Member States. After all, that's where it starts.  We need more transparency. This can be done in consultation with tech companies, but also through legislation if these companies do not get over the bridge. It's about transparency about funding, about where it comes from, about who's behind political ads and about algorithms on social media platforms. Actually, we need to think one step further. For example, what about developments like Deepface, where video footage is manipulated in such a way that politicians put words in their mouths that they did not say themselves. In fact, the truth or development has already caught up with us, and we may have to do more, dear Commissioners, than is already on the table. You have our support for this.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – Mr President! In order for European citizens to truly participate in fair and secure elections, we need fair and secure information, fair policies and educated citizens. For fair and secure information, we need freedom, the functioning of the media, they guarantee all conditions for the safe work of their journalists and are not in the service of interests and pressures, but in objective reporting.  Secondly, honest politicians ensure the transparency of their and party's activities, funding, advertising and not exploiting personal and other information for their own interests. And educated citizens, these are voters who don't let themselves be abused by disinformation and incitement on social media. All these areas are already heavily tainted in Europe, including Facebook and Cambridge Analytica, and the appetite for manipulation by third countries, led by Russia, as well as by private interests, undoubtedly exists. We are helping them in this, because political opacity is growing, political advertising is incorrect and we are receiving anarchy of electoral rules. Online trolls, but also real people who, by direction or out of infatuation, feed the people by blowing up ideological strife, and above all by spreading lies, ride on their wave. In some colleagues, slovenian media in Slovenia has poured in hefty money from Hungarian companies linked to The Hungarian Prime Minister Orban, and this way of financing pre-election propaganda through the media is a game of law.  And the misuse of the internet, communication tools, intimidation and manipulation of citizens by politics, the media or anyone is unacceptable, irresponsible and must be prevented. We must protect the European elections, democracy and Europeans, who must have all the conditions for a free and fair decision on what Kind of Europe we want to live in, as must the integrity of this institution.  And the European Parliament and the European Commission have taken some steps in the right direction over the last year, and countries must ensure that they implement and punish offenders harshly. The same applies, of course, to us, politicians and political parties.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. Freedom of expression is the greatest asset of a democracy. In my country, I have to see that the corridor of opinion of accepted opinions has become very narrow. Although there is no criminal prosecution, there is a social ostracism of disliked opinions everywhere. This reminds me of my childhood in the GDR, only that for many Germans today, the coverage from Switzerland or other foreign media has replaced Western television. Do you want to limit this spectrum of opinion? Just yesterday, during Mrs Merkel's speech here in plenary, Parliament's camera did not make a single swivel to our side of the Plenary. The opposition should not be visible at all, not only in terms of content, but also figuratively. If you are so convinced of the correctness of your arguments, then a different opinion is always worth a debate, is nit? Where I am with Mrs Merkel in particular, the practice of influencing foreign elections is not unknown to us either. Before the lockout period expired, the federal government transferred taxpayer money to the Clinton Foundation through its ministries. This money is also believed to have been used in the US election campaign. Has this ever been the subject of discussion in this House? Or is this becoming acceptable because you see yourself morally on the right side? The restriction of other opinions is now to be extended to foreign actors. This is unworthy of a democracy. Twenty-five years ago, when US economists in particular warned of the catastrophic effects of the introduction of the euro, this was described as anti-European. If these opinions had been seriously discussed at the time and not included in one's own bubble of moralising wishful thinking, things would be markedly different in Europe today. We must allow foreign opinions to be unrestricted, even if there are real or alleged falsehoods. We have had our own experiences with fake news in Germany since the events in Chemnitz. The EU has the opportunity to set up a website that can publish rebutts on important issues. That would stimulate the debate in the European Union, and God knows that there is sufficient need for that.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: – Mr President, a person’s right to vote by secret ballot and universal suffrage for his or her own government representation is enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and this very right is now being challenged by foreign actors – and Russia has been mentioned but it is not alone. Many are using misinformation as a form of hybrid warfare or even more sophisticated techniques, such as deep fakes, through AI and machine learning, to deceive. They’re meant to erode the trust in the public debate and in liberal democracy itself. So there’s a lot at stake and we must do what we can. What I missed in the introduction by the Commissioner, which I generally thought was very comprehensive, is a notion of an assessment of the very business models of Facebook, YouTube and others, that are designed to sell more advertisements. Whether or not that lists conspiracy theories on the top, it doesn’t really matter for them, they are not developed to advance democracy, but I do think they should respect the rule of law.  In that context self—regulation is not enough. I think every chance has been taken, and we’ve seen that it’s not enough, so responsibility has to be taken, algorithmic accountability is needed, a sector inquiry is needed and we need to look at bots. Bots don’t have freedom of expression the way individuals do. We need transparency of politically—funded advertisements and in the use of micro—targeting. We need stress tests of our election technology, because the weakest link can hurt all of us. And political parties and candidates needs to be prepared, and so should journalists, in how they may or may not deal with leaks.  In other words, we need accountability. The survival of liberal democracy is at stake.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Europe is not the only one preparing for the 2019 EP elections. External actors are also trying to double down on the fact that Europe is being pushed blind. They are not doing this by concrete fraud, but by distorting political discourse, producing fake news, insturation of fear. The main source, of course, is Russia and its allied European extremist populist forces. However, there are growing signs that some EU governments, such as Hungary and Poland, may also get involved in disinformation. We cannot stand by and watch the actors involved in our failure uninterruptedly heel our public discourse and choices. This requires support from quality independent media. It's going to take investigative work to uncover the backgrounds of fake news companies. Independent media must not spread fake news with the help of the state, as in Hungary. We need joint European publicity and news channels in order to create a public discourse on our common affairs at European level. Without quality media, there will be no democratic Member States, and without them, not only democratic, but no common Europe is possible.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Mr President, during the 1999 European elections, I was left devoid of any ability to get my positions across to the electorate due to unfair national influence – not foreign influence, national influence. With one day left to go for the big debate for the election, I was told by the national broadcaster that they would contact me later, after the election. I was gagged. Who knew? No—one. In the 2014 elections, I met the same stonewalling. This time, our national broadcaster kept me off the main debate for my constituency. I was instead put in a debate which took place after midnight when everyone – bar those returning from the pub – was tucked up in bed. The major difference between 1999 and 2014 is that I now had the ability through social media to inform the public about what was going on. A hashtag on Twitter, #RTEbias, went viral. On the night of the debate, people knew.  There is no doubt that the power of Facebook & co. must be curtailed. Their collection of data is phenomenal and their motivation questionable. However, one must also question the motivation of those who wish to limit its power – the same people who stayed quiet when my voice was gagged and my words were twisted in the past by ‘old’ media.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, today we are all called upon not only to talk about the security of the next election campaign for the election of the European Parliament, but also about the very future of the European Union. The possible influence of foreign actors is very serious but we must not be carried away by the emotion of events such as the Facebook/Cambridge Analytica scandal. Instead, we must be objective and act not only in the interests of the 500 million citizens we represent here and, in my opinion, we must think about these three points: ensuring security, not falling into censorship and focusing on education. It's right to ensure online safety, but considering traditional elections in fully safe voting booths is just a fairy tale. There are distortions such as the exchange vote, hidden funding and not given to politicians. Pointing the finger and demanding an absolute degree of security for online activities is far-fetched, as this degree does not even exist in the analogue world. This obsessive quest for security at all costs brings us to the second point, which is the risk of censorship and the restriction of freedom of expression. The European Union has the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights among its founding values, and any restriction of freedom of expression is intolerable. We therefore need a great deal of caution in the responses to be given and it is not by imposing new forms of network control, which would, moreover, be implemented by private individuals, that the regularity of the elections is guaranteed. Turning to the third and final point, I believe that the only response to be given is to promote educational policies that can provide citizens with the necessary tools to develop awareness, critical spirit and civic sense. Without education there can be no awareness and without it there can be no real democratic participation.  Finally, I would like to give unre demanded advice to the political class that is in power in Europe today: make no mistake that by implementing measures to gag the web you will be able not to miss the next European elections. The wind of change is blowing hard in Europe and will wipe out you too.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I find this debate quite surreal because it seems to me that, once again, a European Union incapable of analysing its own failures and faults translates its criticism of an external enemy that does not exist. We are shouting at the Russian enemy, at the Russian hacker, when, in my opinion, the biggest propagators of fake news are inside the European institutions. Every day we are forced to hear crazy and untruthful statements from representatives of the European institutions, and that is not acceptable. I think it is better to focus on internal criticism and why Europe is failing than shouting at an external enemy. The legitimate doubt that comes to me and that comes to so many European citizens is that the battle over fake news is being used to close, given the inability of the EU, even that space of dissent that social networks manage to give to those in the minority.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. It is, I believe, proven – from various studies and findings from the US to many other countries – that today, controlled by foreign countries – Cambridge Analytica is just one example – fake news is systematically implemented using algorithms, etc. Anyone can express their opinion; Social media is also available for this purpose. But we must not say, as one of the previous speakers said, 'the wind of change is blowing' . Yes, it may be, but not the wind of change of lies. If it is simply a lie to systematically enforce in great ways controlled by foreign countries, and when I see that all the speeches that have come from the right have obviously been a precautionary defence of this policy of lies in the election campaign – because every speech has had this approach here – then we must oppose it! The AfD in Germany, Mr Gauland, has held board meetings with the AfD in the Russian embassy, where such matters are agreed! Le Pen has received money from Russia for her election campaign! They all stand up for politics in Ukraine, only to be paid for in this way by taking action against European interests and interests of independent European nations in order to impose their policy of lying. This must be branded, and this must be made clear. There are all the possibilities of benefit, but please do not influence our policy in the European Union through foreign countries. This must be fought out in political competition within the European Union in order to take this forward. We must therefore see – as Mrs Schaake has pointed out – that this is not just Russia, it is coming elsewhere. When I see that some of these parties that sit there are working with Mr Bannon, who everyone here knows how he organised the us campaign – it has been clearly said by him that he deliberately organises opinion with forgery – then this is a situation that is unacceptable in a democratic community. Our citizens should be able to decide without the aid from abroad for the rights in this House, the fight against democracy and Europe.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we know that the Cambridge Analytica scandal has demonstrated the ease with which citizens' opinions can be manipulated by tracing their political profile from users' personal data and how easy it is to misuse them and then influence political choices. We also have examples in this House of people who have used the European Union and fake news about the European Union for electoral purposes already in recent election campaigns in different countries. So let us certainly think about the American elections and also the Brexit campaign, but let us also think about many campaigns that have taken place within the European Union. We know that politics is used today using social media, that technology and computer systems are an integral part of our lives and that is why we need to make sure that those who use them do so legally and on the basis of common rules and that it is possible to provide for financial penalties in the event of violations. Above all, we must be on our guard and firmly defend the protection of our data.  As you know, the European Parliament has already legislated in this area. Proposals are on the ground today. Mr Wieland and I are rapporteurs for the proposal on sanctioning European political parties for abuses of the use of electoral data. However, it is not only the guidelines that are needed, which are the preliminary stage – we legislate on sanctions, but the preliminary stage must prevent the violation from happening – but I believe that we also need a task force set up by the European Union to combat the use of fake news that will certainly take place using manipulated data from our constituents.  If, therefore, we fear the influence of these practices in the forthcoming European elections, we must be able to defend our public space not only with these guidelines, with rules and sanctions, but also with strong political activity. Not only the Commission but all our groups, parties and countries must work on this, so that it is not possible for deceptive influence to change the results of the forthcoming electoral laws. We have seen something here which already tells us that it will not be something that cannot happen at all, but that the real possibilities are there and that it is up to us to prevent them from becoming a reality.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: Mr President! It was one of the greatest American presidents, Abraham Lincoln, who said that you can fool a part of the population all the time, all the population part of the time, but you can't fool the whole population all the time. We in Europe can be pleased about this, because it sounds like in this House that Russian influence on national issues is something new. You have completely forgotten the Cold War, in which the majority of the left, including the peace movement, received in stacks of Russian cash, helping Russian propaganda to degrade the West's defenses. So you're talking about this with elections – that is, influence on elections – as if it's a new thing. It's not! And fortunately, there is already a great deal of understanding among the European electorate to separate rubbish from cinnamon. But if you are so keen to prevent influence on national elections, should you not look at the system you yourself have set up here in the European Union. You are spending millions and millions of taxpayers' money propagandising for all the good, everything right, the fantastic political union, without, moreover, asking the Europeans whether this is the direction they want. You equate fake news with EU scepticism in your debates, and you go so far in the proposals to combat fake news that the director of the Danish Institute for Human Rights, Jonas Christoffersen, publicly warned at the People's Meeting on Bornholm this year that the methods you use will legitimise dictatorship states like China, Russia, Venezuela and anyone else who wants to keep the freedom of expression of their peoples down. You run the risk of throwing out freedom of expression and democracy with the bathwater, because you are so afraid of losing out to the peoples of Europe and to the European electorate, who are sceptical of your utopian dream of a United States of Europe.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, everyone has already said that the forthcoming European elections will be extremely important for our future. Voters will have to choose between parties that are in favour of Europe, who are in favour of European cooperation, or parties that want to turn back the clock and actually hide behind national borders. I think we all know that there are forces, powers that actually benefit from Europe not becoming a strong player on the international market. These forces will therefore not hesitate to manipulate the elections in their favour. The Romans already knew: divide and conquer. There are two ways to do this, Commissioner, by falsifying the results of the vote or influencing the electorate through false information. Hence my call: we must be vigilant in both areas. Firstly, we need to set up networks in which Member States exchange best practices to protect voting procedures. Many members have already argued for this. The second, however, is even more important to me. We must ensure that we arm citizens against fake news, against disinformation campaigns.  I would like to make a very concrete proposal, Commissioner. I would like to make a plea here today for the appointment of a genuine special representative against disinformation, against fake news, against cybercrime. I think we really need that: a special representative who can immediately investigate whether we are dealing with fake news, who can immediately intervene with campaigns to correct that fake news so that we can make Europe great.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Mr President, a hundred years after the First World War, many have reflected on the risk of war returning to our continent, but in reality the next war has already begun. It’s a culture war, an information war, and we’re all conscripted into it, many of us without our knowing. The foreign actors distorting our elections are coming from both Russia and the USA. Last week Shahmir Sanni, the Vote Leave whistle—blower, won his unfair dismissal case that exposed the activities of nine lobby groups seeking to undermine action on climate change and help the tax avoiders, all working out of 55 Tufton Street in London. We need this activity by what we have called the ‘Brexit Syndicate’ called out as propaganda and not given oxygen by the BBC.  A year ago, the Prime Minister drew attention to Russian involvement in British politics, but she is refusing to say whether she blocked an investigation into Arron Banks’ Russian connections, and we have learned that the Mueller investigation is making similar inquiries with regard to Nigel Farage. Welcome to the culture war. It’s a war between democracy and authoritarianism. Which side are you on?

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: Mr President, this European Union is definitely struggling with democracy and freedom of expression. The Eurogagas are so afraid of meeting people next May that all means are good to stigmatize and gag those who do not agree with them. By referring to external interference in future European elections, you have the Russian government in your sights. These accusations are a fantasy, even paranoia, unless they are used to justify tougher sanctions against Russia. You are in no position to give moral lessons about outside interference, when you know that NGOs funded by foreign public powers, under the guise of defending human rights, actually serve political interests contrary to those of nations. The interference does not bother you when it is called Open Society, by George Soros, who nevertheless promoted the reception of migrants, and this of course with the blessing of the European Commission. Interference in future European elections does not bother you, when Mr Macron's government finances and broadcasts, with taxpayers' money, a clip to attack European leaders, such as Mr Orbon and Mr Salvini, who are not 21% in the polls but are praised by their people, not to mention the interference and manipulation of many media that , full of public money, swear by Brussels and allow themselves to smear the peoples of Europe by cataloguing them as xenophobes, racists or populists.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: – Mr President, free elections mean not only the possibility of choosing from more than one candidate, but also elections without disinformation and manipulation. And we are in a disinformation war with Russia, a war that threatens our democracies. Only in this context will we appreciate how visionary the Schuman Declaration was, it says, among other things: "World peace could not be preserved without creative efforts that are proportionate to the dangers that threaten that peace." This means, in our situation, that we must put at least the same effort and funding into the fight against disinformation that the adversary invests on the other side of the barricade. So we are talking at least hundreds of millions of euros. But democracy is worth it. A lie is cheap, but the truth is expensive. Now this misinformation threatens the European elections. It is therefore a Pan-European task where all-continental cooperation is needed. I am glad that the European Commission's proposals are moving towards what we really need. In addition to the protection of personal data and funding controls, this is what we need in particular – high-quality technical monitoring tools must be available in all Member States. The European Union must be able to coordinate these instruments. National teams must have sufficient capacity at European level to spread fake news. This may be paid advertising on the Internet or cooperation with public media. The dissemination of these verification messages must happen in real time within the range of hours, this is crucial. We need special forces with good algorithms and only one task – to detect, report and block misinformation. The assistance of platforms such as Facebook or Twitter is essential. But above all, we need the will, the common will, to fight disinformation. I see this will in the European Parliament, with some exceptions, and I am glad for that.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
