text: – Mr President, I am convinced that we have seen many forms of state-sponsored cyberattacks and disinformation in the most recent major elections, from the Ukraine crisis to Brexit and Catalan votes, and from the US elections to the Italian and Swedish ones, to name only a few. Moreover, social media have accelerated the spread of fake news. We are facing a global phenomenon with a high political impact, but it is also important to say that we are dealing with the tools of warfare. So we can only expect this to happen during the next European elections as well. I don’t see any reason why it should not. The role of online platforms in the proliferation of conspiracy theories, disinformation and fake news is part of the Kremlin’s ongoing influence campaign with the aim of undermining Western values and democracy. In other cases, it is unclear where the attacks are coming from, but the sources appear to be mixed: everything from other countries to lone hackers. Mr Commissioner, the 2019 vote is consequential for our fate and future. These elections are so important that is not only a matter of actually preserving the vote from disruption, but also preserving it from any rumours, fraud and interference. All available digital radars should be focused on the European election infrastructure and systems that are part of the voting process, but also on foreign intelligence activities, notably the Russian state-sponsored media outlet which operates in various Member States. And, yes, do not forget the financing of the electoral campaign and the political parties and political leaders in some countries which are too close to Moscow. Ahead of the European elections in 2019, the EU response should face these extremely topical challenges. This has to change and rapidly, before it is too late. As a result of the requested strategic communication plan to address Russia’s ongoing disinformation campaign, in 2015, East Stratcom started working. It has only 18 people and does not even have its own budget to face all those challenges. Let’s invest in Stratcom and let’s invite the Member States to work closely with Stratcom to prevent this. Finally, let me say that I call on the Commission to analyse the current situation and to address the legal framework needed in order to prevent interference.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for I agree with many of the things that colleagues have talked about. However, I would like to point out that the influence of hostile Outside Centres spreading disinformation before the elections in our countries before the European elections is not limited to anonymous activities, such as the running of blogs or Twitter accounts by fictional characters, which are in fact part of a political project. Our problem is not just trolls and bots. Actors of external influences spreading disinformation are very often known public figures.  This seems particularly dangerous to me in the performance of former national politicians or high-ranking EU officials. By employing themselves as advisers to various companies, they use their relationships, dependencies, political knowledge of cuisine to serve the interests of forces that are unfavourable to the Union and are unfavourable to European countries. Gerhard Schroeder is much more dangerous than any troll. If socialist colleagues condemn such practices so strongly – it seems that he is still an SPD politician – then I think that should change. That is why It seems to me that the urgent action should be to strengthen the policy against revolving doors, and moreover, we should publish a blacklist of such politicians acting with foreign, hostile states, our strategic enemies, acting against the Union within the Union, because they represent a real and real danger, much greater than what we are talking about.

name: Alyn SMITH
text: – Mr President, technology has always evolved – and will continue to evolve – and our laws need to evolve to keep pace with it. So we should avoid hysteria, but we do need to learn the lessons of where our laws are not fit for purpose. And we need to learn the lessons of our most recent experience, Brexit. I come from Scotland, where we comprehensively rejected Brexit, but it remains very much our problem. Because the fact is, colleagues, the UK’s a more developed democracy than most, but the UK’s laws on campaign finance, data protection, election transparency and the transparency of actors – foreign and domestic – have been proven to be not fit for purpose, and the use of technology – the abuse of data – was very much part of that campaign by a deeply dubious leave campaign which wholesale abused the law. So I support the measures which we’ve heard about and rise to bring some urgency to them. I commissioned James Patrick to analyse Scottish Twitter, and he produced this report. He analysed 27 000 Twitter accounts, 36 million tweets and found a staggering number that at least 4.25% and rising to at least 12.24% Scottish Twitter accounts are potentially malign. If it’s happening in Scottish Twitter, colleagues, it’s happening in your democracy as well, and I fear that our laws are not fit for purpose across our House and our all our democracies are under threat. Commissioners, I wish you well in your efforts.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: – Mr President, madam, the interference of external actors in electoral processes and the misuse of metadata are causing serious effects on electoral procedures, as they allow both the mass collection of confidential information of the electorate and the distribution of fake news generated to attract and misinform. Cambridge Analytica killed the privacy of 50 million people and, according to Europol's EC3, both Clinton's and Macron's campaign were attacked. Mixing authentic manipulated elements is a strategy to maximize the negative impact of an attack. Fake news websites, accounts and social media are used to spread inaccurate news, designed to look authentic and harm a candidate or party. In May there are elections to this House. It is necessary for the Union to take steps to ensure that no electoral process is criminally grafted. Public and private actors need to coordinate their actions to prevent such attacks and there is also a need for improved cooperation between agencies. The Union needs to curb the misuse of data mining with the European Cybersecurity Package, which includes promoting the establishment of a European Security Agency, and must give resources and credibility to those who already look after it, such as europol's European Cybercrime Centre (EC3). We must end the threats that attack democracy, the sovereignty of states and the fundamental rights of European citizens.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: – Mr President, this debate is very important because freedom of expression, freedom of opinion, the freedom of having free elections where citizens can cast their ballots freely is fundamental for our European democracy, for democracy as such. I’m honestly quite shocked when I listen to some of our colleagues from the far right saying that the threat of foreign actors is not a threat to the freedom of people and democracy in Europe itself. It’s astonishing that they can claim that there’s no threat. It’s been proven: take the US election as evidence that foreign actors like Russia have interfered with the purpose of destroying our freedoms, our democracy, the free will of people to cast their ballot at the polling station. This is so important, and we have to ask this very uncomfortable question: if you do not react together and protect our freedoms, our democracy, then I would ask you – how many seats will Russia have in this Parliament at next year’s election? Because that’s what will happen if we allow ourselves to be fooled into believing that we’re not seeing interference by foreign actors. They are not trying to strengthen our democracy. On the contrary, they want to destroy our democracy, our freedoms. They have a totally different world-view. We should not take that threat lightly and, therefore, I’m very happy about the different kind of plans and actions that are being taken now. I’m also happy to see that the concerns – 73% of Europeans have this concern, as the Commissioner alluded to – this is a concern we need to respond to. We need to show people that we protect their right to live in democracy and freedom and, therefore, in my opinion, Russia should have no one elected next year for this Parliament. We should stand together on our core values no matter which political group we belong to.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr. Chairman, the development of information technologies has enabled foreign factors to interfere more easily than ever in our democratic process and shape the results of elections according to their own wishes and interests. Of course we can't let them do that.  While we must take certain measures as a precaution to protect ourselves, I cannot help feeling that this issue is being exaggerated. Russian interference in the US elections has to some extent not yet been proven, although the investigation has been going on for nearly two years. Russia has also failed to manipulate the public debate on NATO entry in one Montenegro, so I don't see how it could exude decisive influence over the European elections. It's okay to be careful, but let's leave it to the witch hunt.  This narrative of foreign interference seems to be being targeted as justification for the rise of Eurosceptics in the next election, and that is why those who are leading the Union in the wrong direction, not Russia, are primarily to blame.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Commissioner for Security, Commissioner for Justice, on 26 May 2019 this European Parliament is elected, which represents 500 million European citizens democratically directly. And since 2014, the last election to the European Parliament, we have witnessed a set of episodes of criminal interference in electoral processes and consultations and referendums in Member States of the European Union. This European Parliament, which sends missions to oversee the correctness and credibility of elections abroad, has every reason to worry that the fundamental right of political participation and democratic choice is not interfered with by a hybrid war of poisoning, cyber-terrorism, manipulation or blackmail in any way. Therefore, it is urgent that we bring together all our forces to shape our anti-cybercrime and cybersecurity agenda as soon as possible with a European cybersecurity agency and Europol's cybercriminality intelligence unit, which ensures that we will be absolutely prepared that the 2019 European Parliament elections do not cast the slightest doubt on the credibility of any of the Member States of the European Union and be absolutely sure that the european Parliament result really reflects the will of europeans and not the will of those who have agreed from some dark and remote workshop of manipulation or poisoning abroad to condition the composition of this European Parliament against the European Union and its founding values.

name: Jussi HALLA-AHO
text: – Mr President, it is important to protect the integrity of our democracy against undue external influence. But there is a dangerous tendency in the mainstream politics and media to explain any unpleasant election result as an indication of such undue influence, a tendency to see Mr Putin and his agents behind every corner and under every stone.  This is a way of de-legitimising democratic elections and the choices people make. I can assure you there are a lot of people out there who genuinely do not want more third—world immigration, more globalisation or more European Union. This is the reason why they vote for Brexit, Trump or nationalist parties. Such developments may, of course, coincide with the interests of certain external actors, but they are caused by the failure and incompetence of the set mainstream.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Mr President, we need to ensure that those who are elected to the European Parliament and to all the national parliaments are elected in order to do their best for their nation and to do their best for Europe and not for those who want to divide and destabilise us.  We need to ensure that neither Russia nor anyone else can influence the elections but there let’s also be aware, this is not anything that is going on just during elections, it is going on now and there is a link between money-laundering by Estonia, Novichok in Salisbury, rumours in Germany, cyberattacks in France and cyberattacks in all of our countries. Let’s not be naive, this is not a threat, it is something that is going on right now and it is implemented in order to undermine democracy and the rule of law. And those foreign actors, they have the help and the support of those forces inside here, who would like to undermine the rule of law and democracy. This is a fight for democracy and freedom. Let’s be clear that we shall disclose those who do it, we shall have transparency, we shall sanction, and we shall do with criminal actions what is required to do with the criminal actions. We shall ensure that they are punished and they are revealed and disclosed and that we can safeguard our European Union.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Mr President, politics has always been in the way of information and counter-information strategies. Today, however, the technological association allows us to go much further and promote massive disinformation campaigns, worked in such a way as to reach and manipulate specific sectors of the electorate.  The virus of disinformation is contaminating the entire spectrum of political communication, casting distrust even about that information that is correct, and this misinformation can become lethal to democracy. I welcome the Paris appeal, signed on 12 November and endorsed by 51 countries, including all European countries, as the manifesto to help the ethical values and the rule of law prevail in the new framework of the digital society. The strategy proposed by the European Commission to combat online disinformation will have a test of fire in the forthcoming European elections. The truth is that we need a huge coalition of citizenship to make this strategy successful.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Our debate is of a special nature: it is motivated by the fear of foreign influence in the upcoming election campaign for the European Parliament. In this context, there is talk of funding European parties and foundations. There are specific names. A year ago here in this Chamber, Nigel Farage pointed to one of them: George Soros, an American financier who has an outside influence on European Union policy. He gave specific data on dozens of meetings between the billionaire and the European Commission. Franz Timmermans himself said earlier this year that he had been working with Soros for twenty years. Accusations of meddled this American billionaire in the internal affairs of the Member States of the Union were loudly artidicted by representatives of Slovakia, Romania, Italy, Spain, the United Kingdom and Hungary. So what guarantees do we have that he will not interfere through his numerous foundations in the upcoming European elections in many countries, including my own country – Poland? And what are we going to do about it?

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: – During the debate I had to think of the cartoons of Popeye, the sailor who was strong enough only after a can of spinach to protect his girlfriend. Just as Popeye Olive had to protect from the rogue Pluto, so too must we protect our European democracy from rogue foreign actors. We've seen it in the elections in the United States. We saw it in the Brexit referendum. We have seen it in the Netherlands in the investigation into the downing of MH17, which killed almost 300 people. Our job is to ensure that this list of examples stops here, that this undermining of our democracy comes to an end. With the european elections approaching, it is absolutely an important step to further strengthen our resilience in this area. The creation of the StratCom Task Force was and is, in principle, a good idea, but let us do it right. It was only in January of this year that money was allocated to this team: 1.1 million euros. By comparison, the Russians have spent more than four times as much money on a Brexit campaign alone! We cannot leave it at the very end of fine words and the proclamation of concerns, especially now that the European elections are coming up. Just as Popeye needs spinach to defeat Pluto, so too do we in the European Union need powerful weapons to stop this form of foreign interference. Let us at least from this house make sure that those weapons get there.

name: Paul TANG
text: – Interference in elections. I can talk about Putin's troll army or the Italian Deputy Prime Minister calling journalists jackals. But I want to talk about American interference. Facebook has maintained for years that it is neutral. But with all this neutrality, it has allowed fake news to be fabricated in a small town in Macedonia, that there are dark ads that influence filter bubbles, and that Cambridge Analytica has gone away with 50 million profiles. For example, Facebook has contributed to Trump and Brexit.  In 2016, some 1.4 billion euros were spent on online campaining, which Facebook and Zuckerber make money from. Zuckerberg promises better. But it has to be faster and it has to be better.  I would like to see a compelling European approach, full openness of spending for a political purpose by Facebook (who, what, where, when) and ultimately an ex ante test on the algorithms, on public opinion formation. Because let Facebook not impose its will on our democracy, but vice versa.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the fight against malicious attacks by third parties within the European Union must, of course, be common. However, there are various aspects and ways of dealing fraudulently and, of course, it is being altered or efforts are being made to corrupt the House that will be elected in the next European elections. I am referring to the guarantees of pluralism that must exist. In this Chamber, I have complained more than ten times that in Greece, both public television and large systemic private channels have silenced our movement "Greece - The Other Way". They do not give us the opportunity to express our views and this is a set-up situation through which we have been silenced. We want to see intervention and support in this matter, so that we have the right to participate on an equal footing in the European elections, because since we are silenced there is no democratic process in Greece and we are not given the opportunity to express our views. Because, Mrs Jourová, you referred to an intervention in Greece, I would ask you to explain what electoral intervention has taken place in Greece and to which you referred in your speech.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: – Dear Chairman, Gentlemen Commissioners, thank you for following this discussion and for combating the undermining of the European project. This debate came at a good time, at the dawn of the European elections and I think we should draw attention to it.  Certainly, as we can see, there are two ways of undermining elections. One way is to finance the campaign with donations, opaque donations and buy interests, or rather pressure citizens and voters. Another way, as we see, is disinformation through social networks. Social networks Facebook and Twitter are particularly strong. Particularly strong are the fake profiles used by those who want to support this project and want to support this democratic election. We must certainly resist it.  Likewise, the manipulation of citizens is evident. In 18 member states it is obvious that there have been, not to list now, countries that have already been discussed, undermining. So what we have to do is definitely strengthen independent journalism. It's very important to us.  We must also not compromise these democratic, fair elections, but in the end I still want to believe that our citizens are sufficiently educated and aware enough that they will not succumb to low passions and will discern what is democratic and what is transparent from what is fake, and fake news has really become a great danger today.

name: Alfred SANT
text: – Mr President, obviously all political and technological means should be employed to fully protect the European Parliament elections from any attempt to manipulate public opinion and results. However, beyond outrage, we should seek to have a coherent position with regard to outside foreign interference in our political affairs.  To achieve such coherence, we must also consider the inputs we make as Europeans to the political and national affairs of outsiders. Europe, as well as the US, has a wide—ranging reputation for having interfered in the internal political processes, democratic or not, of others. From Mossadegh’s Iran, to most African countries, to Latin America, the Middle East, Libya and Ukraine, we have interfered. When is our interference legitimate? When is it not? Retaliation for it can take forms unexpected by us, and unacceptable to us. What retaliation is legitimate when others interfere in our affairs? And when we interfere in theirs? Replies to such questions cannot be symmetric between countries and specific cases. After all, this Parliament regularly holds debates that seek to influence political events in, and outside, Europe. We need an overarching, coherent doctrine covering all these scenarios and aspects.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, the fight against disinformation should be a priority for both political and security reasons in the Member States and also for the whole of the European Union. In the field of security, expenditure on counterintelligence activities should therefore also be a national priority, as the impact on internal affairs, including election influence, is also a security threat to Member States. I would like to point out here that, for example, the Czech Republic has set up a centre against terrorism and hybrid threats in order, among other things, to detect disinformation campaigns, and I believe that this will pay off for the Czech Republic. The european elections will be a test of our resilience and there is no doubt that there will be an effort to influence their results in the same way as they did in the United States of America or in the event of Brexit. Russia will support anti-European disinformation campaigns. This hybrid war is more effective than violence in today's digital age, and we must face education for critical thinking, media literacy and public media support. In this context, I would like to appeal to the European External Action Service to increase financial support for its stratcom component. Its effectiveness began in 2015, revealing three and a half thousand cases of pro-Russian misinformation. However, this activity needs more financial support. Unfortunately, spending on StratCom is incomparably smaller compared to Russian media expenditure.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: – Mr President, democratic elections must be independent of any interference by other parties. As we saw with the Brexit referendum, the US presidential elections or the Dutch referendum on the association agreement with Ukraine, cyberattacks, disinformation and propaganda can completely reverse public opinion. I am therefore pleased that the European Union is starting to combat such attacks, and I appreciate the creation of centres that monitor and respond to cyberattacks. In this area, however, we should be inspired by civil activists who – sometimes alone but very effectively – are fighting a hybrid war. An example of such determination is the Slovak Ján Benčík, awarded the European Citizen's Prize last year. Disinformation and its consequences can permanently damage democracy, and defence against them is not only legitimate, but also badly needed. Next year, during the European elections, as in the past, we can expect an offensive of attacks on the European project and in support of parties and movements that wish to destroy it. The answer to such action can only be telling the truth and systematically uncovering lies. We need to talk more about what the European Union brings to people and countries and what our continent would look like without integration. Only truth and close contact with people is a cure for attacks and lies that are spread in cyberspace. Therefore, let us not be afraid to clearly name the lie and expose the causative agents of misinformation. It is we in the European Parliament who have this responsibility. The closer we get to humans, the less impact misinformation and hoaxes will have.

name: Inese VAIDERE
text: – Dear colleagues, Commissioners, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent work. As an old proverb says, if you want peace, prepare for war. This should not be taken literally, but the propaganda war must prepare to defend our values.  Russia has realised that direct intervention, such as in Crimea and south-eastern Ukraine, is facing serious Western resistance, so there is now an emphasis on fake news, propaganda on the Internet, on television, on fake profiles on social networks. Russia makes up not only fake news, as I say, but also fake views. This is an indisputable fact, interpreting in exactly the opposite sense. It is both about the occupation of the Baltic states, it was also the case with the downing of a Malaysian plane. What do we have to do? The party financing law must be sorted out first. When I heard some colleagues today who do not notice the fake news made by Russia, I think that perhaps the disorganization of the party financing law is the basis for this. Secondly, we need to work hard with journalists, to veer, to build media literacy, to inform the public. It is necessary not to mention only the bad news in the media, but it is also balanced with our achievements. We need to work with our NATO partners so that our technology specialists, cyber specialists, are stronger than those who are trying to disturb us, who are trying to hack our websites and so on. Thank you, colleagues, for supporting my pilot project on the increase in StratCom funding, but I really call on the Commission to find the means to make StratCom funding a permanent matter. Thank you!

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Bannon, Russia, fake news, technical manipulation – the weapons of the EU opponents have really been aptly described by colleagues. We must also think in very different dimensions: we need to upgrade digitally, we need early warning systems against false reports and technical interventions – not only in Brussels, no, but also in all the Member States, as the Czech colleague has just described – if we care about this European idea. But we also need to talk to Facebook and Google. We must make them accountable. If they want to do business in Europe, this can only be done if they also spread serious content. Those who are multipliers of the destroyers of Europe should not be allowed to benefit from the freedoms of the European internal market. That is why we need to have a clear conversation with Facebook and Google. However, I would also like to ask the Commission how it is possible that we are only now considering amending the Statute for foundations and parties. The new rules are intended to help guarantee fair and free elections, not least through transparent donations. Unfortunately, these new rules will only take effect after the European elections.  Ladies and gentlemen of the Commission, that is not the way to go. Let us take this as a wake-up call so that we can take the whole issue much more seriously.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Mr President, colleagues, in the recent years we have found ourselves responding to untruths, half truths, fake news and propaganda. Misinformation and disinformation dominate and penetrate our daily lives. In an environment more susceptible to foreign interference in our elections, we must find ways how to be proactive and not only retroactive. One of the most important issues in fighting foreign influence in European elections is to strengthen the media environment in our Member States, but also in candidate countries and in the neighbourhood. This goes hand-in-hand with the robust respect for freedom of media and for the work of our journalists. Looking back at the work of Jan Kuciak or Daphne Caruana Galizia, we owe it to all the journalists who put their lives on the frontline in order to report on issues of interest to the public. We owe it to the journalists in Ukraine, Belarus, Moldova, Serbia and in other countries; we owe it to our own societies. Political leaders in some Member States have dishonoured the journalistic profession by public statements against journalists. I strongly denounce these practices. All EU states must protect the personal safety and the livelihoods of investigative journalists and whistleblowers, and not only protect them but champion their causes as well, and in upcoming European elections I think that without dedicated journalists and a free media environment, it will be difficult to protect fully our own democracies.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: – Mr President, already in 2013, general Valery Gerasimov, chief of the General Staff of the Armed Forces of Russia, set out the principles of hybrid warfare. The Gerasimov doctrine emphasizes that non-military means can be more effective than traditional weapons. A properly chosen and applied word can be more destructive than tanks or missile systems. One of the divisions of this Gerasimov hybrid army is influencing electoral processes. For example: the Dutch referendum on the ratification of the Association Agreement between the European Union and Ukraine, the referendum on Britain's withdrawal from the European Union, the German elections in 2017, the French presidential elections in the same year. The presidential elections in my country, the Czech Republic, have also been flooded and affected by misinformation. They greatly helped the victory of the pro-Russian President Zeman. Finally, stopping the artificial erosion of trust in democratic institutions must become central to the agenda of the Member States, but also of the European Union itself. I therefore strongly appeal to the Heads of State or Government, as well as to the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, to make a fundamental shift in the perception of this strategic danger at the December summit. I expect to present a maximally ambitious action plan with concrete steps.  The next important target of disinformation campaigns and possible cyberattacks will be the European Parliament elections in May 2019. I'd like to hope we'll be more prepared than in the past.

name: Nuno MELO
text: – Mr President, fake news is a reality of our times. They are another element to take into account in the different variables of electoral disputes that we obviously have to fight. But anyone who is convinced that the partisan reconfiguration we have seen in recent years, from Russia to the United States, through the European Union, is only due to fake news is not seeing what is happening.  Some political forces, usually left-wing, have been colonizing the classical media for decades. Since then, they have created all the narratives of political correctness: what can be said and what cannot be said. And then they felt entitled to attack politicians who didn't follow their playbook. Political office holders have come to fear saying what they genuinely think, fearful of the media reaction. Voters, for their part, stopped hearing common sense answers to concrete problems. And who took advantage of the emptiness were all the extremisms, also helped by fake news. Those who do not understand this can hardly help to fight what is one of the worst phenomena of our times.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I would like to draw attention to the fact that local elections are an extremely sensitive area. They are not only a test for democracy, but also for the proper functioning of many institutions in individual countries, including the European institutions. Until now, we have most often dealt with (and worried about) those elements that are related to democratic rights, transparency, as well as the business purity of such elections, namely, above all, the financial transparency of the committees themselves. Today we are receiving another subject, which we have all been paying attention to for several – I stress: for several years – almost to no availy. I want to point out that fake news is already an industry. This is a serious branch that is likely to benefit states as well as large business organisations. Elections are for this industry – it must be emphasised – also a serious business and financial interest with unimaginable consequences. I draw attention to this because we need to know that fake news, external interference, fake news, fake news, fake news, fake social networks are a big, very often serious security and security threat. I would also like to draw attention to the fact that this term of office of the European Parliament began with the first report on fake news, fake news, interference in Europe's political life, as well as economic life. Unfortunately, however, we are at the same point as we were four years ago.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: – Mr President, Commissioners Jourová and King, Madam President of the Council, Ladies and Gentlemen, in April this year I questioned the European Commission on cybersecurity and the safeguarding of the integrity of the European elections. No response has been given for many months, but finally on 12 September a package of measures was presented for which I congratulate the European Commission. In 2019, as has already been said, there will be new elections for the European Parliament. We all want to prevent any electoral manipulation. We are not naïve and we know that there are many external, political, state, economic and military forces that want to condition the electoral process, either through fake news, use of large amounts of data for electoral manipulation, or through funding to extremist parties that want to destroy the European project. We all recall, as Eu Commissioner Jourová has already done, the shame of the Facebook/Cambridge Analytica case and the strong evidence of Russian interference in the European elections, all of them using the digital world and new information and communication technologies.  It is therefore essential to safeguard the rights of European citizens in these elections. Cybersecurity is, more than ever, a priority in defending the fundamental rights of the Union. It is central for the Commission and the Member States to take the necessary technical and organisational measures to manage the risks to the security of networks and information systems used in elections to the European Parliament. In a Europe contaminated by selfishness and populism, there are many who will not look at ways to destroy the European project and fight the Europe of values and freedoms.  We must act quickly for freedom.

name: Lukas MANDL
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Commissioner, Secretary of State Karoline Etdstadler, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We are discussing the fact that powers of this world want to influence elections in Europe and thus the public climate of opinion. We must ask ourselves: why do they want to influence Europe? Why is this influence taking place? And the reason is obvious: Europe is strong. Europe is stronger than ever in history because it is united, because it is economically strong, a factor that some powers in the world do not want to see cooperatively, but want to weaken in competition. Who is the target of these weakenings? The aim of these weakenings is not state institutions as perhaps in the past, but that is each and every one of them. These are women and men who simply communicate, who consume the media. Yes, they are our children too. So what do we need? We need cyber defence.  We in Europe also need to discuss security – security – not just privacy. We need to invest where digitisation requires competences that make it possible to defend against such dangers. We need education, education, education. Our children – all human beings – must be able to distinguish between fake news and true news, between conspiracy theories and a real exchange of views. And we need freedom of the press. I very much agree with Mrs Harms that we do not eat raw meat, but we constantly consume information that has not been researched in journalism, but which is completely unfiltered. We must learn to distinguish between this.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Secretary of State, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Towards the end of this debate, it is difficult to put new arguments in context. That is why I would like to express my support for what my fellow Members have already said here. I believe that we must not only address the issue of misinformation in relation to resilience, but that we must also see the aspect that our networks, the digital data networks, are more vulnerable to attacks, because attacks that were once perhaps directed at a particular country are now very simply within the Member States of the European Union, which are highly interconnected, which are very simply within the Member States of the European Union, which are highly networked. , can spread. That is why we must also see the interaction between the two dangers. And if Mr Mandl points out directly before me that the great danger, of course, is that many individuals communicate, it is the fact that the insecurity caused by attacks ends up being the most important among these individuals, and in a sense democracy, the democratic process in the European Union, with attacks that may not be considered so dangerous at first sight. , unsettled and questioned. That is why, before the European elections – as has been pointed out in the debate – we really need to ensure that the Member States step up their resilience efforts and that we succeed in working with the big companies to ensure that fake news and other misinformation are actually combated where they can be combated most quickly.

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: Mr President, Commissioners, Secretary of State, it is very good to have this debate here. Democracy, here in this house, but certainly also in all Member States, is paramount. We are present at elections all over the world as observers. We count exactly whether the votes got right in the van, and then check the whole procedure around it. Now, however, we ourselves are at stake. Actually, this is a very serious moment. I have worked on reports on the critical infrastructure on the Internet in Europe. Well, our democratic elections, everything around it, our system, are such a critical part of our infrastructure, which we should not let ourselves be taken up from the outside.  I was in Israel at the beginning of this month. If you see what such a country invests in their cyber security, in their resilience, and then you contrast that with what we do in Europe, then we still have to find sixth gear. It must be the case that we increase resilience in the assistance we provide at all levels for elections.  A very specific point, which has also been mentioned by the Commissioner: the check that is now being applied to some of our major platforms should be mandatory. There should be a button on all these big sites and platforms that you can press to indicate: I see this post, how did the funding come about? What influence is behind it? Are those movies real? It will have to be different, because the challenge is different.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, it is difficult at the end of this debate to bring any new ideas to such a fundamental subject. I just want to underline and reiterate that I am convinced that in the forthcoming European elections there will be a great deal of effort on the part of Russia to influence the conduct of election campaigns in individual Member States, especially in countries that belong to the so-called close neighbourhood from the point of view of Russian foreign doctrine. This means in countries that unfortunately fell under the influence of the Soviet Union during communism. These are countries where Russia simply wants to exert its political and economic influence and does not want to strengthen that part of society that is pro-European. We must count on this, we must create an awareness-raising campaign against this, both at national and European Union level. I am standing here as an MEP for the Czech Republic and we have seen when, even at the last elections, the presidential elections that took place a few months ago in the Czech Republic, in short and well, the pro-European candidate for president faced major media attacks, faced fake news, which was disseminated against him in hundreds of thousands of emails that were sent out and where topics related to the European agenda were being distorted. Topics such as migration have been misrepresented. We must count on the issue of migration to be greatly misused by the enemies of the European Union.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this is a vitally important subject that we’re debating this afternoon. Foreign, domestic, sometimes criminal, actors have, without doubt, sought to break the rules, sought to interfere in our democratic processes and raised questions about our democratic institutions. Make no mistake: that does represent a security challenge. We, from the Commission side, agree with those of you who say that we need to take action on a number of fronts: we need to build our cybersecurity and our resilience against cyberattacks, we need to tackle cyber manipulation through dis— and misinformation, and we need to tackle the misuse of mined personal data. We also agree that we need to call out examples of interference. I want to join those of you who have praised the excellent work carried out by the EU’s East Stratcom Task Force, which, over the last couple of years, has now gathered more than 4 000 cases of pro-Kremlin disinformation, contradicting publicly available facts, repeated in a number of languages and on a number of occasions. These activities basically reflect a public Russian military doctrine which openly advertises the use of false data and destabilising propaganda as legitimate tools. As a number of you have also observed, unfortunately it is not only Russia. Others are going down this route as well, which is why we also need to tackle the underlying vulnerabilities. We need to build our resilience through longer term actions – as many of you have said – on education, independent media and building critical awareness, but also through some shorter-term, more immediate actions, not least with the upcoming European parliamentary elections in mind. So we are pushing for early agreement on the Cybersecurity Act, the package of measures that we have proposed to try and build our cybersecurity and resilience. I note that in the US Congress they’ve just acted to create a US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency. I think it is high time we followed that example. We’re also acting to tackle cyber criminality. We will continue to support Europol, who have in EC3 an internationally recognised centre of excellence in tackling cyber criminality. But, more generally, we need to work for transparency, traceability and the accountability of cyber criminals, which is why it is so important that we make progress on e—evidence. Without fast and effective access to electronic evidence, it is very hard to hold cyber criminals to account. As well as those steps, we need to tackle cyber manipulation and on that, building on the measures we presented last April in our communication on tackling online disinformation, we have – as has been mentioned – now agreed, in what is actually internationally a first, a Code of Practice on Disinformation with the big social media platforms, the big news platforms. We’ve asked those platforms to restrict targeting options for political advertising, to ensure transparency around sponsored content, to step up their efforts to identify and delete fake accounts, and to establish clear rules around bots. There should also be greater clarity around algorithms – as has been mentioned in this debate – and information on how they prioritise the content that that we see. This needs to be combined with tools enabling users more easily to discover content and access new sources representing alternative points of view, as well as to report disinformation. I think this code is a good starting point, but we need to go further. We need to press the platforms now to deliver granular, measurable objectives that we can hold them to account against. We will do that work, as a number of you have asked, as we prepare the action plan for early December. We still hope that we can see sufficient progress by working quickly together on a voluntary basis, but we’ve been clear that we reserve the right to consider our options again if we don’t see the progress that we need. As my colleague, Commissioner Jourová, mentioned earlier, in September President Juncker presented a set of measures specifically on election security, asking Member States to set up a national election cooperation network of all the relevant authorities. We have brought them together – representatives from each of the Member States, those responsible for running elections, those responsible for cybersecurity, and those responsible for data protection – and we will build an effective European—level network so that those experts can share best practice and support each other, and we can build our collective resilience. From the Commission side, we very much welcome your strong engagement on these issues. As we’ve said before in these debates, raising awareness is the first line of defence, but, in itself, it is not enough. We need to go further. We need to maximise our preparedness ahead of the series of elections that are coming up. We are committed to working with you, with Member States and with the private sector better to secure the foundations of our democracy: free speech, freedom of expression, and indeed the right of all of those who have spoken today, including those who attacked the Commission.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, it’s quite difficult at the end of the debate to say something new in this debate, because I would like to say that this very useful debate showed and demonstrated a high degree of convergence between the European Parliament’s and the Council’s and also the Commissioner’s view on the importance of EU resilience against any influence of foreign actors in the upcoming EP election campaign – and I would like to emphasise this – no matter from which country it is evolving. I fully second what Commissioner King said: we have a lot to do in a lot of different areas and regarding different topics. It is clear that it is still work in progress, and I’m looking forward to further results in the short— and the medium—term. Let me assure you of our firm commitment to continuing the work that I outlined already at the beginning of our debate and of our readiness to adopt and effectively implement concrete measures to protect the internet and the cyberspace from criminal misuse. It is clear that these objectives cannot be met without common efforts to ensure a free, open, safe and secure cyberspace and in close cooperation with other public and private stakeholders. This work is actively supported by the contractual public—private partnership on cybersecurity between the European Commission and the European Cyber Security Organisation. But I doubt that we will be able to complete this work at any time. Our work in the cyber domain is now far away from being completed, and against a background of the developing technology, we have to work a lot also in the future – I’m convinced of that. We need to join forces – and also that was mentioned by the Commissioner – to raise the awareness of all stakeholders, to encourage action, and to improve the capacities and capabilities of the EU and its Member States to tackle the ever—growing sophistication of cyber—attacks and evolving cyber—threats around the world. We need to make good use of all the EU initiatives directed at increasing cyber resilience and invest in the implementation of all recently announced measures. We also need to strengthen the existing framework, based on current experience, to provide more comprehensive response to the constantly evolving challenges which rigorously protect the fundamental rights and freedoms of our citizens.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. – In the coming months the election campaign for the forthcoming elections to the European Parliament will begin and the EU must redouble efforts to ensure that the fundamental right of political participation and democratic election is not interfered with by a hybrid war of poisoning, cyber-terrorism, manipulation or blackmail in any way. Unfortunately, in recent years we have witnessed a set of episodes of criminal interference in electoral processes and consultations and referendums in Member States of the Union. It is therefore necessary that the high degree of convergence between the three institutions in this area be reflected in the rapid adoption of the measures proposed by the Commission, including the establishment of electoral cooperation networks at national and EU level; the implementation of guidance on the application of data protection rules in the electoral context and recommendations on greater transparency in advertising and paid online political communication; strengthening cybersecurity; diligent application of existing electoral rules; and the entry into force of a legislative proposal to sanction the misuse of personal data for electoral purposes.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. – Repeated attempts and experience of interference in elections and election campaigns show that democratic processes must be strictly protected. This applies in particular to the targeted reduction of mass discrediting campaigns based on absolute nonsense and disinformation in the online environment, often spread from abroad. The abuse of lies and misinformation in the political fight is not new. However, especially in the social networking environment, they are spreading faster and thus have a much greater impact. As a result, fake news has become a kind of weapon that is a threat to our society. We must therefore respond to constantly evolving cyber threats by strengthening security. The only purpose of spreading harmful content on the Internet is to create doubt, hostility and division in society.

name: Manolis KEFALOGIANNIS
text: Writing. – Six months from now, European citizens will go to the polls to elect a new European Parliament, a new Commission. They will be called to lead Europe into a new era full of challenges, opportunities and threats. The stakes are critical and some will attempt to weaken the electoral process by spreading fake news, amplifying populist and anti-European voices and insousing nationalisms. Their success will be not only the emergence of populist and anti-European forces, but also the low participation rate of European citizens. The answer to those who want to see a weakened Europe is greater participation of citizens. Strengthening democracy. Democracy and participation go together and in order to increase participation we must give strength to the personal choice of every European citizen. The election of the next MEPs in the Member States should be based on the direct selection of MEPs and not on a list election. We believe in European unification. We must have a common way of electing.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. – In the coming months the election campaign for the forthcoming elections to the European Parliament will begin and the EU must redouble efforts to ensure that the fundamental right of political participation and democratic election is not interfered with by a hybrid war of poisoning, cyber-terrorism, manipulation or blackmail in any way. name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. – According to a recent study by the University of Oxford, fake propaganda affecting public life and elections is on the rise around the world. In Hungary, researchers have experienced such activity since 2010, when the Orban government took office. It is particularly shameful that fake propaganda in Hungary is carried out exclusively by the government - and clearly in support of Vladimir Putin's anti-EU policies. The government's disinformation is part of everything the EP condemned in relation to the Sargentini report. Orban's troll army is working to monopolize the written and electronic press and silence the critical voices of the political opposition and the civil sphere. At the same time, the European Union is constantly being attacked on the Internet with a mass of aggressive, eye-picked lies. They create fear and division among voters - which is then used for their nationalist, racist policies. The cleanliness of the EP elections is therefore also under threat from Hungary of the Union and the Government of The European Union. I would like to draw attention to the fact that, in addition to the campaigns of lies, it is preparing for another manipulation of the Hungarian electoral law. The forthcoming amendment would allow citizens of Hungarian nationality living in another Member State to vote illegally and uncontrolledly in two countries at the same time. This would have a significant impact on the outcome of the elections. It is essential that the Union deal with both issues as a matter of urgency, long before the elections, so that the integrity of the vote can be guaranteed.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Two main elements of our democracy and electoral process that are under attack: the first – you can call it fake news, disinformation etc. We have lost the sense of what is true and false. The problem is ‘more information, but less informed’. We have already started working with the big online platforms to make the internet a better and more reliable place for information and facts. Yet, we are competing for the attention of our citizens with Russian trolls, terrorist organisations and populists. The only way to win is to offer our citizens a logical narrative, based on principles and facts, filled with brave but conceivable ideas for the future.  The second element is our election infrastructure. It is obvious that we should re-conceptualise the use of technology in the process, so the voting rolls, the act of voting, tabulation and results are secure to external influence. We should also reform our election administration, with a focus on resilience to cyber-attacks.  Today, foreign interference aims not only to support one candidate in a race, but also to ruin the basic mechanism that our societies use to make decisions. With no credible elections our societies will end up divided, perplexed and in deep confrontation.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: Written. – Public confidence in the political system has been shaken. This is reflected in the fact that in many countries voter turnout remains at a low level. This is particularly true of the European elections, where voter turnout is often below 40%. We need to come up with solutions to this problem.  In the elections, capital circles and various advocacy organisations sought to get their own candidates elected to key positions of trust in Parliament, the Government and the European Parliament. The aim is, of course, that representatives sponsored with election money should, in their duties, particularly contribute to the interests of their donors. Election campaigns in general are often too simplistic and over-the-top, even smearing of misleading and political opponents, further confounding undecided voters.  Disinformation, which is becoming increasingly common online and in traditional media, is one of the biggest challenges to the realisation of European democracy. The more disinformation is disseminated on social media, fake news, fake factbooks and fake videos, the less people believe in the reliability of any information they receive. Each editor-in-chief and publishing director should understand and take responsibility for publishing only facts. The reader, listener and viewer must be able to easily distinguish between facts and fictions. Simply staring at turnover should not be the main issue in any publishing business. It is important to emphasise the importance of high-quality editorial work and the strengthening of the role of suppliers and independent media. Citizens must have reliable and high-quality information in order for democracy to become a reality. I welcome the measures proposed by the Commission to secure free and fair elections, such as greater transparency in political online advertising and its targeting, as well as stricter electoral funding rules for European parties.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: in writing. – Elections are the foundation that gives legitimacy to the democratic system as a whole, to the legislature and the executive branch. This is why the exercise of undue influence by foreign malicious actors is such a serious problem: this behaviour seeks to undermine the legitimacy of the entire democratic system by eroding its foundations. In the age of social media and targeted advertising, it becomes more difficult to enforce existing rules, for example the ones forbidding the use of foreign money. The internet does not know national borders; therefore, the sponsor of a politically targeted advertisement (which could even contain blatant lies masquerading as facts or news) could be located anywhere. This is why, as a bare minimum, we need more transparency regarding political targeted advertising: who purchased it and where the target audience is located. It might be healthier to ban political targeted advertising on social media altogether; one thing is to use it to sell commercial goods, but using it to influence or even manipulate the democratic choice of citizens is something entirely different. A comprehensive approach is required, since ‘hacking’ of elections is not limited to actual ballot fraud, but also includes undue manipulation of voters themselves.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: The next item is the report by Bogusław Liberadzki, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the rights and obligations of rail passengers (recast) (COM(201) 7)0548 - C8-0324/2017 - 2017/0237(COD)) (A8-0340/2018).

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Rapporteur. – Mr Krasnodębski, i would like to thank you for your comments. Commissioner Bulc, i would like to thank you for your comments. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur Let me start by saying: this is a very important day of our debate on the development of consumer rights, a specific consumer, which is rail passengers in Europe. It is about more than four billion people who travel by rail every year. It is also about the millions of workers employed in rail transport, and therefore a comprehensive and crucially important project on a very large scale. At the outset, I would like to thank my shadow rapporteurs, in particular Mr Denis de Jong, who, on behalf of the IMCO Committee, was comingly activism in the preparation of the report. I would like to stress the high willingness of the Commission to cooperate and to thank Commissioner Bulc.  Let me start with what Parliament can achieve with tomorrow's vote. The first and fundamental issue with regard to passenger rights is compensation for train delays. We propose to increase compensation amounts to 100% in the event of a delay of more than 121 minutes. I realize that it will not be easy. A possible alternative would be compensation of 100 % with a delay of more than 180 minutes.  The second issue, which is particularly important and noteworthy, is to increase the availability of connecting tickets, so-called through-tickets, for passengers who lose their connections because the tickets were intended for connecting flights. They will have the right to take a seat on the next train at no additional cost.  Another issue is accessibility for travellers with reduced mobility: the group of people we want to allow access to mobile means is very large and growing. We propose, of course, that at top-class stations that serve at least 10,000 passengers per day, there should be no prenotification, followed by a three-hour notification at smaller stations and a 12-hour notification at the smallest.  We also open the railway for bicycle transport. We suggest that up to eight bicycles can be transported on the train. Over time, this provision will apply to every train. We also want to extend the scope of the Regulation on the protection of passenger rights not only to international and national trains, but also to regional trains, so that the same rights apply to these trains throughout the European Union. This is one side of the coin.  At the same time, we want to make it very clear that this solution is intended to mobilise states and governments to be more concerned about the quality of railway infrastructure, about rolling stock, as well as about the economic and physical accessibility of transport for passengers. We want rail transport to become an alternative so that all its advantages, such as ecology, cheap access, reliability and safety, can find their place here. We would also like to – and in this direction this solution is going – to level the playing field and the rules for rail transport to compete with other modes of transport. Thank you again for your cooperation and I look forward to your debate.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would also like to thank very much the rapporteur from the Committee on Transport and Tourism (TRAN), Mr Liberadzki, and the shadow rapporteurs, as well as the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO) for their intensive and very dedicated work on the Commission’s proposal to recast the Rail Passengers’ Rights Regulation.  It is indeed, as Mr Liberadzki already said, a unique opportunity to improve rail passengers’ protection and, at the same time, to ensure further development of the rail sector, which also has an essential role to play in the development of multi-modal, integrated mobility as a service solution and in decarbonisation of transport.  First of all, let me stress that the Commission very much welcomes Parliament’s objective to promote more attractive rail services and better passenger protection, but allow me to comment on some of your specific amendments.  First, on amendments beyond the recast legislative technique: we do have some institutional concerns over specific amendments which are not in line with the rules agreed between our institutions for the recast legislative technique. Some changes, such as the compensation levels in cases of service delay or cancellations, are not part of the Commission’s legislative proposal. This said, we fully understand and share your good intentions to increase passengers’ protection in the sector and we will examine the respective provisions put forward in detail taking account of the Commission’s prerogative of legislative initiative. Of course, for those provisions which have been included in the Commission’s recast proposal and which have undergone significant amendment following the EP debate, for example, regulation on through tickets, we stand ready to actively participate in the upcoming interinstitutional discussions.  On persons with reduced mobility, it really goes without saying that we are very much in favour of increasing, to the most feasible and realistic extent, the mobility of all European citizens. We, therefore, very much value Parliament’s effort to improve the situation of persons with disabilities and reduced mobility. We are open to those amendments that can lay solid ground for generally improving the mobility of these citizens in need. Allow me just to share one very concrete example that I was able to directly witness and experience – when we made the special effort to make it happen for a person with disabilities to also use the European programme Discover EU and travel with different modes, primarily railway, throughout the EU and be part of this exciting programme for the youth. It’s a really good example of how we can improve conditions and how we can really enable all European citizens to be able to take advantage of European programmes. So, that’s very much appreciated, Mr Liberadzki. On bicycles, it will be of no surprise to you that I also welcome those amendments which may further contribute to increasing the use of ecologically friendly transport modes such as bicycles. The Commission shares your enthusiasm about new mobility opportunities. Further efforts will be needed in order to ensure that there are no loopholes on this path. For example, passengers shall be properly informed about those new opportunities. We shall also ensure that when train capacity for taking bicycles on board is reached, any possible refusal takes place on transparent and justifiable grounds.  On passenger information, I would also like to stress that the Commission welcomes amendments that increase the level of rail passenger information about their rights, the journey opportunities offered to them, as well as events and outcomes surrounding the trip.  On derogations, we will not be able to truly promote the interests of EU rail passengers and the single market if our legal provisions are accompanied by a widespread practice of granting derogations. The Commission therefore supports increased limitations on such derogation possibilities, which should be based on a purely balanced approach taking into account both passengers’ and industrial interests.  To conclude, I am convinced that all efforts invested in this legislative file will pay off. Improving the current rules would not only increase the mobility of EU citizens and open new opportunities, but also open new opportunities to them. It would also contribute to enhancing competition in the rail sector and also improve rail services. In turn, all this will increase the overall attractiveness of rail transport, to the benefit of passengers, industry, and our environment.  Once again, I would really like to express my appreciation of Parliament’s work on improving rail passengers’ protection and I look forward to today’s debate.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. – Thank you very much to the rapporteur of the Committee on Transport and Tourism for their good cooperation and, of course, to the many IMCO members and shadow rapporteurs who contributed to the original opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, which they were able to accept almost unanimously. That's a good signal for the passengers. I think the end result is very good, especially in terms of compensation. I do not agree with the Commission that this would be outside the reshuffle. We have clear justifications for this. However, you can't explain to passengers that they will only be reimbursed half the ticket price if they are delayed by more than two hours. That should simply be addressed in this initiative. There's good news for people with disabilities. They can quickly count on assistance and do not have to notify days in advance that they are coming to a station. The bikes have been reported, which was also important. There's really only one point left. Please let us not ensure that railways can say that the weather was bad and that you lose your rights as a passenger as a result. We have seen too many leaves on the track, also in the Netherlands, as an excuse. We shouldn't want that. We still have to get out of that tomorrow's vote.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this is a great day for us and for the millions of train users. For the first time, thanks to this regulation, Europe will finally take users into account. Until now, the European Union had always dealt with railway companies and infrastructure managers. It was completely abnormal for the main stakeholders, the users, to be left out. The last report was in 2007, we waited ten years! Ten years later, this injustice will finally be repaired, and this on the whole of the European rail network. You talk about derogations, we do not want them, we have already wasted enough time. Regional and cross-border lines will also be governed by these new rules, which is great news. Never forget that 90% of European rail passengers use these regional routes on a daily basis. What are the main commitments of this landmark reform? They are based on four pillars. First: compensation. If your train is one hour late, then a 50% refund is provided, which is normal. If it is two hours late, which is not acceptable on the European continent, the reimbursement is 100% in this case. That is the norm. Second, in the event of a missed connection, for whatever reason, operators are required to reroute you to your next destination. They can't leave you on the edge of the dock. With this unique ticket, regardless of the operator, the operator will have to meet its obligations at no additional cost. The far west rail is over! Third: assistance. Commissioner, you are talking about an attempt. That is not the case. With this file, we must guarantee to the 80 million people with disabilities or reduced mobility that they will be cared for in all the major stations in Europe, but also in small stations with a three-hour pre-notification. Mobility for all will be the reality of tomorrow. You can't leave people with reduced mobility on the side of the road. Finally, fourth: sustainable mobility. Each train, from 2024, will have to provide eight seats for the bikes. This is a great step towards softer and more respectful mobility and is an essential step in fulfilling our COP commitments. It should be noted that rail is the most publicly funded mode of transport in Europe. It is still a bit unusual for this service to be less well perceived by users than other modes of transport, such as the aircraft. Finally, thanks to this file, rail users will benefit from a better service than in air transport. And for the first time, Europe is taking care of rail users. So I clearly ask the European Commission and the Council not to go back in the forthness of the upcoming negotiations. You talk to us about companies, we have talked about them a lot and we have protected them a lot over the last ten years. Now, I would like to see the main care of the passengers. This is an eminently political issue and all the more important in the run-up to the European elections. The millions of train users will be particularly vigilant.

name: Lucy ANDERSON
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, this regulation provides a vital chance to help get a better deal for rail passengers. The European Parliament must not fail them by caving in to rail industry lobbying. The top complaint of train travellers is delays and cancellations. That fact is not just anecdotal, but is acknowledged independently by the International Rail Regulators’ Group and the European Court of Auditors.  So, particularly problematic is the Commission’s proposal for the introduction of a so—called ‘force majeure’ clause, seeking to allow rail companies to refuse to pay compensation to passengers for delays and cancellations in certain circumstances, including severe weather conditions. This aims to reverse a key passenger—friendly decision of the EU Court of Justice in 2013.  Worse still, is the version of ‘force majeure’ proposed by our own European Parliament Committee on Transport and Tourism (TRAN), which could even be interpreted to include lawful strikes and other industrial action. Whilst the TRAN Committee’s amendments do have some good points, as our rapporteur has explained, they allow exemptions for suburban rail services, despite evidence showing that these are the most widely used services by passengers across Europe, especially younger people. Under the TRAN Committee’s amendments, passengers will only have the right to onward travel on the next train in the course of delays and cancellations where a connection is missed in the course of a single transport contract. In real life, this is often not the case when tickets are bought separately.  So, in the vote tomorrow, I urge all MEPs to support the alternative approach tabled by myself and many others: in particular, do not make rail passengers suffer still further for the consequences of external factors causing problems with their journeys.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Of course, rail is a very important element of the public transport system, also thanks to investments co-financed by the European Union budget. We want more and more people to choose this means of transport, but for this we need not only modern rolling stock (which is becoming more modern), but also significant changes to the rules that will strengthen the position and rights of rail passengers. And that's what we're doing right now.  This report is largely in response to consumer expectations, particularly in areas such as compensation and carrier obligations in the event of train delays. Our vote tomorrow is also of great importance for improving the situation of people with disabilities travelling by rail, who today face numerous barriers already at the stage of buying a ticket. The problem is also access to assistance when boarding the train or even just getting information at train stations. We want to remove these restrictions.  I understand the concerns of the operators, who will now bear the additional costs of these changes, but I am also convinced that this will improve the quality of rail services and will attract new passengers who have been more willing to choose other modes of transport so far. Well, a few statements have shown that we have been succumbing to the rail lobby so far – this time we have succumbed to the passenger lobby.

name: Jens ROHDE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, it is time to end the Member States’ protection of their national rail companies and replace it with the protection of rail passengers. For the ALDE Group, that means we want to introduce compulsory through-ticketing systems for passengers. We want the Commission to develop an EU complaint form for use in the event of cancellations or delays. We want, in the case of missed connections due to delay or cancellation, to ensure a passenger the right to take the next service available. We also want to encourage railway undertakings and ticket vendors to develop an automatic compensation system. We want to push for an exchange of information between ticket vendors and the railway undertaking; we want to rationalise the compensation rates; we want to ensure spaces for bicycles; and, of course, as mentioned by my colleagues, we want to ensure better assistance for people with reduced mobility. Let me say to Ms Anderson, the ALDE Group will support her amendment tomorrow. We too want to delete the force majeure provision, and I want to thank Ms Anderson for putting this amendment forward. If we want to shift more transport from other modes to rail, those demands should not be too much to ask for. En marche! as they say in France.

name: Michael CRAMER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Only a minority of Member States have fully implemented the passenger rights adopted almost ten years ago. That is why I think it is good that we are taking action here today.  I am pleased that we have found a strong compromise on bicycle transport. Anyone who knows me can feel that. The European Parliament wants us to have mandatory parking spaces on all trains in the near future – without loopholes as before. This will no longer force customers to transport their bicycles by other modes of transport.  A large majority is also in favour of the transit ticket. No wonder! Transit sit-throughs were already the authoritative standard by international conventions as early as 1923. We are a long way from that today. 67% of passengers are in favour of uniform rights for the entire rail journey from start to finish, even if you have to change trains, even if you have to change trains several times. However, this is hardly available, especially for cross-border connections. The prerequisite for transit tickets is accessible travel information and booking systems. We have found strong formulations for the necessary open interfaces, open data, so that this will also improve in the future. For full-fledged passengers, however, we must, in principle, remove the state of emergency 'higher violence'. I have always been committed to this, including in the negotiations. Until now, there has been no such thing as a fact in the case of the railways. The introduction of force majeure would lead to a barely unacceptable legal uncertainty at the expense of passengers. Only a tiny part of the delays are caused by force majeure at all. The arbitrary interpretations of the airlines should be a warning to us. The Court of Auditors has also confirmed this in its current report. A tyre defect was for an airline force majeure, which is crazy, but sad reality.  Another problem is assistance at stations, with no pre-registration time. Only at stations with more than ten thousand passengers a day can persons with reduced mobility take advantage of spontaneous assistance. 97% of stations would therefore be exempt from this scheme. This is not an acceptable regulation for me, and even more so for people with reduced mobility. We need to change that.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, this report proposes significant progress in the treatment of train passengers, and we hope that it will be an important step towards improving the quality of service. The train must be the means of transport of the future. It is the most sustainable, the safest, that allows for greater territorial vertebration and accessibility. And, therefore, we must incentivize its use and make it more attractive to users.
