Some positive aspects are that with this proposal we maximize the information available to the user, ensure that bicycle users can access the train without risk to the safety of other travelers, we prioritize relocation without prejudice to compensation and refunds in case of cancellation of a service and guarantee an appropriate claims protocol. But the most important thing is the leap that can be made in the accessibility of the service for vulnerable users. In this regard, the report proposes to ensure station attendance and access to trains with trained personnel, that information should be available in accessible format and that persons with reduced mobility will take priority in relocation, including with guide animals. However, I would like to stress that it is not sufficient to encourage the use of rail to improve passenger rights. It must be promoted as a means of public transport. It must be pushed from public institutions and not made more and more cuts and privatization processes initiated.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the regulation we are going to vote on tomorrow is of great importance for passenger rights in our countries. All too often we have seen problems and difficulties in recent years which have made rail mobility and short- and long-distance connectivity inefficient. Poor information for passengers, inadequate assistance for people with disabilities, difficulties in requesting refunds, delays that forced you to change routes without knowing how to remedy the unforeseen events that occurred on your route. To those of us who have lost important connections and do not fully know our rights in such circumstances. There are certainly more virtuous railway undertakings and others less so.  It will be important, including in future negotiations with the Council, to strike the right balance between passenger rights on the one hand and cost sustainability on the other. Certainly, with this regulation, we as a Parliament are sending out an important signal and calling on businesses to make a greater effort to ensure a timely and effective service, with the hope and hope that rail transport will become increasingly used for the mobility of European citizens.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her work on this Rail travel should and must become more attractive. I think we all agree on that. It is always a good thing to inform the consumer. In my experience, when I inform him, when something is not going according to plan, it is always better than if I put pressure on one side or the other. Consumer protection is, of course, also an important part of balancing the forces between a strong company and a single consumer. However, we must never forget that we are dealing with mature citizens. Making information available to everyone in the public eye is, in any case, the right step for educating consumers. The emphasis is on being consumer-friendly and not hostile to business. There is a big difference. In balance, as this report succeeds, that is also the objective that we can support. Small businesses are excluded - sensible measures. Disabled people receive special attention in this report. Two points that I would like to highlight critically are, on the one hand, the compensation for damage caused by a voucher solution – i think that this is counterproductive and also unworkable – and secondly, I think that amendments made by Mr Cramer are completely misguided when he says that he wants information on CO2 emissions on the ticket. I find this rather harmful, because it dilutes this report.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Mr President, I take it for granted that, in the context of the effort, both by the Member States and the European institutions, to reduce emissions of gaseous pollutants in the Union, the transport of passengers and goods by rail plays a very important role. Moreover, railways are a safer and faster mode of transport, which is usually cheaper and more affordable, especially for the weaker economic classes. However, in order for the railway to be part of the response to the problems I have mentioned, we must, at the same time as the development of new networks, especially in the countries of Eastern and South-Eastern Europe, also establish a framework for the protection of passengers, defining their rights in a clear and accessible way to all. Coordination between companies should also be achieved in order to provide connections and connections at reasonable times, serving passengers and facilitating their movements. Finally, we must take seriously the areas in which the rail link, although economically unprofitable for companies, should be maintained so that the inhabitants of the remote areas are not cut off.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht KOCH
text: Mr President, Commissioner Bulc, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Commissioner Bulc, for the work she has done on this report. We must make rail transport more attractive to The Citizens of Europe, without overburdening the railway companies. We need consumer-friendly and fair rules. It is time to revise existing passenger rights and adapt them to digital development. Let's jump on the train, don't just let it go away! Incidentally, I also expect the same from the Council. What will this revision achieve? My checklist is: firstly, the new rules must ensure that comprehensive passenger rights exist, which are unproblematic and enforceable across borders. By restricting exceptions and excluding language barriers to the complaint, we succeed in doing so. Second, information for passengers must be provided in real time, both before and during the journey. Thirdly, the so-called transit ticket should not be the exception, but the rule. A single ticket must be enough to be able to travel nationally and cross-border. Fourthly, the rights of rail passengers who are restricted or disabled in their mobility must be significantly strengthened. I am very pleased that my proposal has been adopted, which makes the lead time for assistance dependent on the size of the station. Fifthly, it is necessary to increase compensation payments in order to put pressure on the rail sector to increase its quality. At the same time, however, exceptions must already remain in place in the event of impairments caused by force majeure. After all, it cannot apply to the railways other than to bus, sea and air traffic.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, rail transport, precisely because it is the means of transport for commuters and citizens with the greatest need, should protect the rights of consumers and the weakest users. I would like to make it very clear what has also been said earlier by some of my fellow Members, namely that Parliament must stand up for people with reduced mobility and for all disabled people. Providing free assistance at stations and at short notice is essential to ensure their freedom of movement. In fact, especially in the case of small stations, asking a disabled person to give 48 hours' notice to board a train even went against any principle of free movement of persons. Finally, giving passengers more rights means enticeing them to use a cleaner collective means than private cars and thus safeguarding the environment.

name: Jacqueline FOSTER
text: – Mr President, whilst we always welcome better provisions for passengers’ rights, this report does not go far enough and threatens to undermine long-standing practices in the UK rail industry. Our compensation measures are already well established and clear, the system works well and passengers understand it. By reducing the scope for when companies must compensate passengers, this report will dumb down what we’ve achieved and undermine our high standards.  The report also contains some concerning provisions for passengers with reduced mobility. The requirement that they must certify service animals, such as guide dogs, before boarding a train is nonsensical. In addition, the varying notice period required for those needing assistance is deeply confusing. Differences between large urban and small rural stations must be acknowledged, but national transport departments should liaise closely with rail companies and consumer groups to decide on these matters.  Finally, we all want to see greater use of bicycles, but the requirement that all services have eight designated spaces is wholly impractical. Many operators would have to order new rolling stock to meet the demand, and it could result in chronic overcrowding in rush hour services and again such issues as this should be determined locally and nationally. For those reasons, the British Conservatives will be voting against the report at this time, but we do hope that the institutions can improve the text.

name: Matthijs van MILTENBURG
text: – Travelling by train is a sustainable alternative to the polluting car or to the kerosene guzzling aircraft. If we entice more people to take the train more often, we will contribute to making our mobility more sustainable. Then we contribute to the achievement of the Paris climate goals.  However, we will have to make travelling by train much more attractive throughout Europe. This proposal will strengthen the rights of rail passengers across Europe, which I believe is a step in the right direction. Under the new rules, rail passengers will be able to get up to 100% of the ticket price back across Europe in case of delays. And that is a big difference from the situation today. Now only 50% of the ticket price can be recovered. A second point that has already been mentioned is that passengers can more easily take their bicycles on board the train. In a cycling country like the Netherlands, this is of great importance. We will also ensure that transport to the stations and the connecting journey on the way to the destination are more sustainable. Moreover, my third point is that it will be much easier for passengers with reduced mobility, for people with disabilities, to take the train in Europe. From now on, they can count on assistance on the platform without having to arrange it days in advance. This allows them to arrange their trip much more smoothly.  Ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow we will accept the proposal to make trains more attractive in Europe. Not only european rail passengers will be grateful for this, but also the climate!

name: Karima DELLI
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I have only one figure to give you: a European who gets up in the morning to go to work has a nine out of ten chance of taking his car or a bus and only a one in ten chance of taking the train. So, as you can see, we are living in the era of cars, an irrespirable era, at odds with the Paris Agreements and which puts the families' budgets at risk. Today, we have the opportunity to make the train love by equipping at least eight bike slots for all trains, from regional trains to high-speed trains; ensuring assistance for people with reduced mobility at each station, because our priority is to ensure that everyone has access to mobility; and by just compensating passengers who are experiencing delays or cancellations, and I would remind you because it is important. In its current version, the text provides for a refund of 50% of the ticket after a delay of one hour, 75% after a delay of one and a half hours and a full refund after two hours. You can see, ladies and gentlemen, that there are only advantages to taking the train, which is more attractive for our health, for our climate, for the wallet of European citizens and, I will add, for European jobs, because we are building our own train in Europe and its industrial jobs must be preserved on our territory.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – Mr President, as a representative of a country that has one of the densest rail networks in the world, I am very glad that we are seeing a further increase in the rights of rail passengers. Passengers should now be entitled to access to information and compensation in the event of delays or cancellations. They should be informed of their rights, of the connections and other related matters before, during and after the journey. I am also glad that access to rail transport has been facilitated for people with disabilities or reduced mobility. If we are to convince the citizens of the European Union that train travel is a tradition worth continuing, it is necessary to raise the level of this transport and the rights of passengers. The European Parliament should set an example in this area.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: Mr President, the provisions of the report, particularly those which increase compensation for delays, will undoubtedly be a step forward for travellers. But when I hear that the Greens are making the place reserved for bicycles on trains a non-negotiable point, I still wonder about the meaning of priorities and respect for subsidiarity. Safety, punctuality, cleanliness, decent prices are all elements on which efforts must be made. However, the European Union, by imposing its economic dogmas, favours a disengagement of the indispensable public power. It is no coincidence that Japan and Switzerland have dizzying punctuality and satisfaction rates, while in Great Britain, for example, 60% of the population wants the sector to be renationalised. Insecurity and incivilities are almost non-existent, no looting, no repeated theft of catenabilities in these countries, unlike what happens in France, nor controversy, as in Germany, as to whether to reserve cars only for women to guarantee their safety. The maintenance of the network and the maintenance of the infrastructure are very rigorous. The recent serial outages that have severely disrupted French traffic are symptomatic of a declining level of demand. It is any wonder that France, renowned for the excellence of its railways, has gone from second to seventh place in Europe in the Boston Consulting Group rankings? Passenger rights will be better respected on the day it is understood that the performance of the rail system is largely the result of the level of public spending that is being conceded to it.

name: Innocenzo LEONTINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the revision of the Passenger Rights Regulation seeks a better balance between strengthening users' rights and reducing the burden on businesses. It is necessary to protect users in a new European regulatory framework in order to increase the flexibility of the sector and its attractiveness compared to other means of transport that have a more negative impact on the environment. The new criteria increase the accessibility of disabled people to stations and therefore show greater sensitivity and assistance to people with reduced mobility. I am in favour of increasing the levels of compensation caused by the delay by up to 100 % of the price for delays of more than two hours. I am not convinced by the removal of the force majeure clause, because it constitutes a legal force which could lead to endless litigation in the application, since exceptional circumstances are a very important factor in all balanced systems. Furthermore, it is not right to impose unrealistic costs and obligations on businesses that do not meet the needs of users. This would only reduce the attractiveness of the sector.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, today we are debating an important report and concrete measures that will directly impact the daily lives of millions of Europeans who use the train on a daily basis. What we are proposing is to better reimburse users when trains arrive late, to provide them in real time with all the traffic information, to guarantee better quality services and to improve the rights of people with reduced mobility. I deeply regret that in the parliamentary committee some Members have succeeded in manipulating the vote to pass amendments which reintroduce provisions allowing railway operators to exempt themselves from any obligation to repay in the event of a delay. I call here on all Members to vote against these amendments tomorrow and not to give in to the corporate lobbies who would like Members to reduce passenger rights. We were elected to defend our citizens and the public interest. It would therefore be a disastrous political message to vote for amendments that defend the economic interest of the major railway groups against the rights of millions of users and against the very opinion of the European Court of Justice on compensation obligations.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: – Delays, cancellations and incomplete information, we are also confronted with it in Belgium, more than we like. Current European rules do not provide sufficient guarantees for a quality service. If we want to motivate more people to take public transport and if the railway companies themselves want to be ready to compete with new players in the market soon, then we need to do better. If these companies do not receive the necessary structural reforms today, it is because there are too many exemptions and favour measures.  The European Parliament is already pointing the right way. Increased compensation amounts in case of delays, so extra financial pressure to go on a punctual journey, the right of the passenger to always take their bike on the train and stronger ombudsservices, that is the track for the railways of tomorrow. Nevertheless, a warning: watch out for force majeure schemes that all too easily give the railway companies an excuse to evade their obligations. Furthermore, additional efforts are needed to improve accessibility for disabled people. We must now move towards a modern, attractive and competitive rail market.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Madam President, if it were a month ago, I probably would have structured my intervention today differently. I would focus on some of the provisions, highlight something and support some things, but in fact, I’m going to say something different. I have a relatively fresh experience.  After the very long vote in the last plenary on Thursday, I was to take a train from here to Karlsruhe and then to Munich and catch a plane. Because we had a long vote, an unnecessarily long vote, I didn’t manage. Then I missed the TGV, so I had to take several trains before I could get to Karlsruhe, then Stuttgart and then to Munich – and you can already guess what happened with my plane connection in Munich.  Of course, I spent some extra money. Of course, my journey to the Balkans was much longer, but I do still understand that my position is somewhat more favourable than that of thousands or millions of European consumers when they arrive, or when they end up in a similar position.  I really believe that what we will be voting on is not perfect. I’m sure that many of us, on a number of provisions, would like to go further. I’m sure that there are still some question marks, but it is a major step in the right direction to provide railway passengers with completely different quality rights, and not just in the terms that I’ve mentioned – accessibility, etc. I think this is a good indication of what European legislation can bring a consumer.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Sustainable development and environmental protection, including clean air, require an increase in the share of rail services. Unfortunately, nowadays, railways are not competitive with other public carriers in terms of many criteria. One of them, of course, is the difference in consumer rights. The Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council is therefore going in the right direction: it increases passenger rights, makes it easier for people with disabilities and traffic restrictions, including those travelling with children, with prams, bicycles, pets or combined tickets. The compensation powers referred to in the Regulation need to be assessed particularly positively. I therefore support this proposal, but I would just like to point out that I will vote against the introduction of a definition of force majeure, especially in the provision that is proposed.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: – Madam President, Mrs Bulc. When did the Spanish AVE win the battle for the plane, especially on the main lines, and also more and more on the road? For it was when, with a socialist government, a councillor, a woman, and the head of the AVE decided to compensate travellers for the minimum delay and up to 100%, apart from agreeing to give access to the next train if the previous one had been lost. They were fundamental elements of passenger rights that helped the AVE take off and today it is one of the most punctual and best-accepted European trains by travellers, although it can always be improved, that is clear. Attention to people with accessibility difficulties has also been strengthened and infrastructure has been built at the stations. There's still a lot to do, it's true. Sustainable multimodality — with bike access to the train — is also needed, but also urban connections. Finally, we do not agree on the attempt to reverse through a misunderstood sense of protection of the rail sector, limiting passenger rights. Conversely, we are in favour of deepening the guarantee of more rights to passengers.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to congratulate the work carried out in this report on the rights of railway users, because it is really passenger-focused, because it extends the guarantees and also includes some of the Court of Auditors' main recommendations on this matter. Because it is not only necessary to establish clear definitions. In addition, it is vital to simplify the procedures for claiming, and if possible, automating compensation. The first objective, clarify; avoid ambiguities that allow companies to evade their responsibilities. Much can be improved by supporting amendments which definitively clarify what they are and what cannot be considered causes of force majeure to justify a delay or the abolition of a service. They also improve the amounts of compensation and ensure the right of travelers to catch the next train when they lose a connection due to a delay or cancellation. It is committed to more sustainable mobility, always resreserved space for bicycles, and the rights of people with disabilities are improved. The large stations must be fully adapted. In the small ones it is proposed that three hours be sufficient to request assistance. Finally, in order to improve access to this catalogue of rights and guarantees, a European complaint form and an automatic compensation system are committed to improving access to this catalogue of rights and guarantees. It makes no sense, when it is clear that the passenger must be compensated, that the passenger has to ask for his/her due. You have the right to be returned to you as part of the service that includes the service you have paid for.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this regulation gives us the opportunity to support the implementation of the rights of rail passengers more strongly. I believe that it is very important that rail transport is inclusive and accessible to all European citizens, all the more so to people with disabilities or reduced mobility, and this needs to be improved in all Member States. Given that, at European level, we want sustainable, clean and efficient transport, rail transport can gain ground in front of other types of transport, especially through an appropriate guarantee of passenger rights. As regards the right to compensation, I believe that passengers using rail transport must be properly compensated and compensated in the event of delays and cancellations. Moreover, passengers must be entitled to full compensation for the entire journey, whether it is simple or with a connection. At the same time, I believe that, in order to lay the foundations for a dynamic and efficient rail system, we must ensure its competitiveness in relation to air or road, all the more so as we want to achieve the objectives of multimodal and integrated European transport. Good luck!

name: Karoline GRASWANDER-HAINZ
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The recasting of the regulation on passenger rights in rail transport starts at many good points. In the end, the EU will strengthen the rights of rail passengers to provide information and compensation; that is our goal. In the end, however, passengers' rights must also be enforceable. From a consumer protection perspective, for example, it is incomprehensible why guests should lose all right to reimbursement or compensation in the event of weather events. This would allow the railway companies to pass on all the risk to passengers. That is why the principle of force majeure must be rejected without exception. For environmental reasons alone, we must ensure that the incentives to switch to environmentally friendly modes of transport do not become less, but more. For this reason, measures are needed to make rail travel as attractive as possible.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: – Madam President, over this report I have often reflected on what my trainee with severe disabilities, who is in an electric wheelchair, has told me about my train journey by train. Let me quote her experience: "For me, an order for transportation means having to plan my activities 24 hours in advance. I live in a village, so I can't decide, for example, to go to a nearby town in the morning to see my doctor. I can't plan an evening visit to the cinema or anything like that in the morning." She, too, would welcome shortening the time required to order transportation so that platforms are in good condition, that there is better organization of wheelchair transport, more thorough training of employees, and easier access to information. At the end of his letter, he writes, "The right to travel freely and independently should be everyone's right." I warmly agree with this, and I thank Bogusław for taking these comments seriously and for supporting a number of my proposals, such as reducing the time to order assistance services.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – The President, the Commissioner, dear colleagues, the regulation on the rights and obligations of passengers comes after ten years. It was necessary.  Passenger movements on the train, with rail transport, are and must be increasing, given our general policy, Commissioner of the European Union, namely to switch from road transport to rail transport. But for this, we must have the rights of passengers guaranteed. I am also a member of the IMCO committee and obviously there we put a lot of emphasis on passenger rights. I'm also on the TRAN committee. It is clear that improvements have been made in this regulation in terms of passenger information, because often when you travel from one country to another, you do not know what it is. It happened to me in Paris. We need to eliminate those dodges to pay compensation to the passenger when they are uncomfortable, but not only.  Accessibility needs to be improved for people with disabilities and people with reduced mobility, but why not, and for all people, we can buy the ticket anywhere on the train. I hope that tomorrow we will have a good vote on this report.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, every day tens of millions of European citizens move and use the train to get around. The European rail system, over and above the excellence of high-speed lines, still has too many shortcomings. The news is full of news about disruptions, delays and cancellations, especially in local and regional transport most used by workers, commuters and students. Faced with all this, European passengers do not have sufficient protection of their rights. This regulation will significantly increase the level of protection and the quality of services. These include, more certain compensation in the event of delays and cancellations of rides, greater rights of access to services for disadvantaged groups and stricter obligations to equip spaces for the transport of bicycles in wagons. We will try to strengthen the text even further, between now and tomorrow's vote, in order to guarantee greater quality and rights for passengers and to promote the train as a means of transport even more.

name: Arndt KOHN
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteurs for their good work on this important issue of passenger rights. I would also like to thank the Commission for taking up and revising this ten-year-old issue. Fortunately, now it is ten years longer than the vast majority of delays. Nevertheless, delays and train cancellations are part of the everyday life of many people who travel to work, holidays or business. I myself belong to it, I often ride the train myself, and I know what it is like. Now, of course, as legislators, we cannot ban all this by law. But we now have the opportunity to significantly improve passenger rights. 100% refund for delays of more than two hours, improvements in bike transport, improvements in accessibility, that's only three points. If we want the railways to become more attractive and become a good alternative to cars, buses and planes, then we must do something. Then we must not only rely on people's consciences, but also work on consumer friendliness and on this sensible way of mobility. If we all do this together, many more people will be much more than able to train.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Madam President, developing Europe’s rail network as a sustainable alternative to air travel over long distances is a perfectly sensible objective, but, if it is going to be successful then the service offered and available to people needs to be comparable. We have clear rules on air travel compensation and we need the same for the railways because those rules will be an incentive for rail companies to improve their services and to make sure that trains aren’t cancelled and that they run on time. It’s not a complicated principle is it? You advertise a service, the customer buys the service and, if the service fails to deliver, then the consumer is entitled to redress. Really quite simple. That is why we’ve re-submitted amendments, that is why I’ve re—signed them, and that is why I will be voting for them tomorrow. The point of this recast must be to ensure that public transport is run for the benefit of the travelling public and not solely for the benefit of the people who run the railways.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I would like to point out that during this plenary session we have a third pro-consumer document. That's a good thing. Every time we try to pay attention to how people receive the services that business offers them. But I would like to stress that, for the third time, too, there are no estimated costs, there are no estimated burdens, which unfortunately fall on those to whom we are addressing our demands.  I believe that, in general, the direction of thinking is correct: it is really important to ensure that services are better, more user-friendly, so that, in this case, carriers suffer certain consequences even when they are unable to provide services at a certain level. But I always point out that we touch a business that has to have calculations and must have a certain income calculated according to certain rigors. I draw attention to this because it is an aspect too often overlooked in our debates.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Madam President, I want to reinforce specifically the need for stronger, indeed mandatory, missed-connection protection, to ensure an effective European rail system that works in the interests of passengers. I don’t know where exactly in this Chamber seat no 61 is, but those who travel regularly on the railways may know about the very popular, useful and informative blog run by the ‘Man in Seat 61’. He broke down into simple, straightforward terms the importance of this measure a few days ago when he said this: ‘Implementing missed-connection protection is absolutely essential to stop passengers having to pay huge penalties to [train] operator B because of [train] operator A’s delays, rendering rail travel risky and discouraging people from using it.’ We in this Parliament need to be encouraging people to use the railways. Being a Member of the European Parliament from the UK, I’m all too used to delays on the railways. This Parliament and the Commission cannot delay taking action on these issues in the interests of passengers.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, rail is an important means of transport and, of course, much cleaner than road transport. In the Committee on Petitions we have received dozens of petitions and protests from disabled people who cannot access the railways. I think that with what we are discussing and what we are going to decide, we will really contribute to disabled people's access to rail transport. I think it is important, of course, that there should also be spaces for bicycles, because cycling is now used by too many citizens. The imposition of compensation to consumers in the event of cancellations or delays should be on the agenda, since several railway undertakings are trying with various trickes - allegedly with the force majeure clause - to avoid paying compensation to consumers. There, we must be decisive in terms of the measures we will take.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Bogusław Liberadzki, for a really very good document, prepared because we have corrected the 2009 rules. I support all passenger rights. However, I would like to draw some attention to a number of the provisions mentioned concerning the renewal of the rolling stock fleet. Mention has been made, and I think this is very important, because not every state does so in a timely and appropriate manner, and also in the development of intermodal transport. As we know, each country invests large amounts of money each year in new projects and the renewal of old projects. I am thinking of the Connecting Europe Facility fund, which is particularly important for us to invest tens of billions in the creation of new projects, and in the future this will be very important because, in particular, the Rail Baltica project will have a very important political significance, that peripheral states– the Baltic states – will be incorporated into the European Union's transport system. That document will facilitate the introduction of these new projects into the common framework.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for this very thorough debate. I am glad that Parliament has clearly confirmed its support for improving the protection of rail passengers. Today’s discussion has confirmed that we agree on many of the aspects which will allow us to deliver on this important proposal. Before I conclude, please allow me to address some of your comments. On integrated and multimodal travel, let me confirm that, today, we have a set of EU regulations applicable only to each individual transport mode separately. Let me also confirm that we are progressively moving, already, towards multimodal integrated solutions. This year is a year of multimodality and it is a perfect time to address passenger rights, as well, within the multimodal environment. For passengers combining the use of different modes in one journey, the Commission is now launching preparatory work to develop multimodal and integrated-ticket passenger rights. This is our next challenge. So yes, it is important that we set very clear rules, as is reflected in your report. This is especially important for passengers with reduced mobility, who need adequate assistance at transfer points when using a single ticket and otherwise. Our cooperation on this topic is not done yet. On force majeure: let me say that, regarding the inclusion and the scope of the force majeure clause, we fully understand your efforts to ensure the best possible passenger protection and smooth operation of railway services. The introduction of the force majeure clause exempts railway undertakings from having to pay compensation where long delays are caused by events beyond their control and which they were not able to prevent. While a force majeure clause has been included in the proposal, events that trigger it have been restricted to natural disasters – so-called acts of God. Let me repeat that: a very narrow, restrictive definition of situations caused through purely natural disasters – in order to avoid legal uncertainty and to limit the reduction of passenger rights. The introduction of the force majeure clause aligns rail with other modes of transport in terms of passenger rights legislation, and also of consumer legislation such as the Package Travel Directive. It ensures that the general principle of legal fairness is applied. But, as I said earlier, we will have an opportunity to clarify this issue further when we address integrated ticketing and multimodal passenger rights. I will not go over again the issues that I have already addressed in my opening remarks. As a closing comment, I would like to express once more my deep appreciation of the work you have done. It was crucial to conclude the discussion in Parliament before the elections and I am confident that the position adopted by the European Parliament will serve as a solid basis for the negotiation with the Council. I am very much looking forward to a positive vote on your report tomorrow.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I must admit that I have listened with satisfaction to the Commissioner's answers and to the statements made by members. We are following the same path in the same direction, and many of our proposals, As I understand it, have been adopted. We want rights that are attractive to passengers and that will make passengers want to use the railways.  Secondly, the solutions and rights of passengers with regard to rail liability must be feasible for carriers and must not entail an increase in ticket prices. If someone asked about the cost: yes, we estimated the cost. We are talking about several hundred million euros. Let us remember, however, that at this time we will spend tens of billions of euros under cohesion policy, the Structural Funds and the Connecting Europe Facility on modernising rail transport in Europe. We have the right to expect quality improvements. And I believe that no one will deny us this right. We want services to be available to passengers both on price and physically. We are talking about coherent regulations throughout the European Union, perhaps with the exception of Cyprus and Malta, because not a single railway line has been built there yet, but, who knows, anything can happen. We want the responsibility of railways and ticket vendors to be unavoidable, as formulated and enforceable. The general premise that we have followed is that when the railway respects passengers, it is possible to like the railway. If more passengers use the railways, the market share of the railways will be greater. This will benefit all citizens, but also the environment. Thank you once again, Commissioner. Thank you for the debate.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 15 November 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. – I welcome the fact that, in the recasting of the Regulation on the rights and obligations of rail passengers, the European Parliament has also taken into account the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, in order to ensure that persons with disabilities and persons with reduced mobility have mobility opportunities similar to those of other citizens in respect of rail transport. In the future, particular attention should be paid to the non-discriminatory access of persons with disabilities and persons with reduced mobility to vehicles and to unobtreated information on train equipment. In order to ensure the same conditions of travel, these persons should be provided with free assistance for take-off and landing. It is very important that passengers with sensory disabilities, such as the deaf, hard-of-hearing or deaf, have adequate visual and or sound signalling systems available to them to ensure that delays are as well informed as possible. It is also a forward-looking and long-awaited measure that staff should be adequately trained on the needs and assistance of persons with disabilities and persons with reduced mobility.  I hope that the text will not be watered down in interinstitutional discussions, since persons with disabilities and persons with reduced mobility have the same rights as other citizens in terms of freedom of movement and non-discrimination.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The regulation we are talking about today is very important for all rail passengers. They will soon receive protection of their rights similar to that of airline passengers. By voting on the adoption of the regulation, we will take care of a number of solutions for everyone who uses it on a daily basis – first of all, we will increase the compensation thresholds, up to 100% refund of the ticket price for delays exceeding 2 hours, which will motivate companies to take greater care when it comes to punctuality. Today, the procedure for claiming compensation is tedious and complicated, which means that many people give up enforcing their rights. It is very important to introduce a number of facilities for disabled passengers, e.g. the need for free assistance or the introduction of mandatory training for train and station services. It is also worth looking at the obligation to provide bicycle seats on each train and the introduction of the concept of combined travel, which means that the railway undertaking will have to ensure that every passenger can travel without hindrance and, in the event of a problem, ensure that the journey can continue. The new rules are a decisive step towards safeguarding the fundamental rights of passengers, and I hope that they will make rail a much more popular mode of transport. Let us remember that the railway exists for passengers.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. – One of the most important achievements in the rail sector is the establishment of a legal framework for the protection of passengers' rights, which forms part of a broader EU consumer rights policy. In its implementation report, the Commission acknowledged that the regulation on rail passengers' rights and obligations is properly applied in the sector. However, several Member States grant exemptions to certain articles of the Regulation in full compliance with the provisions of this Regulation for insufficient financial means to modernise abandoned railway infrastructure or outdated rolling stock. It is good that such exceptions will no longer be possible from December 2024. Passengers' rights will therefore be equally guaranteed in all EU Member States. There is another important detail. Re-routing providers must provide a similar level of assistance and access to alternative transport services for disabled persons and persons with reduced mobility. These alternative services may be common to all passengers or, if the carrier so decides, an individual vehicle adapted to the specific needs of certain disabled persons or persons with reduced mobility. Access to the eu rail system for persons with disabilities and persons with reduced mobility should also be ensured by means of a prior notification, which is as short as possible and not more than 24 hours. This service should be free of charge.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Writing. – The rights of train passengers in the EU are currently fragmented, making rail transport appear less attractive to the general public. The creation of a harmonised framework of rights for train passengers across Europe and the provision of high protection for all passengers without exception is imperative in order to achieve an increase in rail transport, while at the same time enhancing the protection of passengers' rights. The new legislation modernises the rights of train passengers and protects consumers more effectively by providing them with a framework of rights equivalent to that applicable to air transport. Better service is provided to people with reduced mobility and clear complaint handling procedures are provided, with greater compensation in cases of delays. Specifically, passengers will be able to claim compensation equivalent to 50% of the ticket price for a delay of 60-90 minutes, 75% for a delay of more than 1.5 hours and 100% for delays of more than 3 hours. In Greece, which has one of the smallest rail networks in Europe, the rail market still has considerable room for growth. Investment should therefore be encouraged and better connectivity between European countries promoted, which in combination with affordable prices will decisively enhance the competitiveness of the railway sector.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The aim of the Regulation is to protect the rights of rail passengers in the Union, in particular when travel is disrupted, and to improve the quality and efficiency of rail passenger services. It is important that the scale of change is more favourable to passengers. Ensuring the rights of rail passengers is crucial to promoting this still undervalued mode of transport. We must meet citizens' expectations, in particular in terms of guaranteeing the accessibility of the railways for passengers with disabilities, enabling passengers to carry bicycles and simplifying the provisions on the need to pay compensation in the event of a delay or cancellation of a connection.  Today, the rules are more user-friendly than passengers, which is one of the obvious reasons why rail is becoming more attractive. The trend should be reversed because it is an environmentally friendly and fast means of transport. It should be our duty to create a passenger-friendly law.  Unfortunately, when using the services of several operators at present, you can not count on compensation or free provision of further travel with another carrier in case of late transfer. Rights are limited by or lack of a business-to-business trade agreement. Meanwhile, airline passengers can claim compensation or provide another flight or night with meals in case the aircraft does not land on time. The same should be true for rail services.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on Julie Girling's report on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on persistent organic pollutants (recast) (COM(2018)0144 – C8-0124/2018 – 2018/0070(COD)) (A8-0336/2018).

name: Julie GIRLING
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, this recast updates the current EU legislation in line with the latest decisions made at international level under the Stockholm Convention. There is no disagreement in this House that this is necessary. The latest research on persistent organic pollutants (POPs) shows a worrying persistence of previously banned substances, particularly in the polar regions, and it’s important that we keep up the momentum on this. The report includes a new role for the European Chemicals Agency (ECHA), giving them much more involvement in certain tasks. This is a move that I strongly welcome. I am aware that not all Members of this House are supportive of ECHA – they don’t particularly support it as an organisation – but in my former role as Parliament’s ECHA liaison person for many years, I witnessed at first hand the excellent work that they do. I very much welcome the use of their in-house expertise on POPs, as opposed to using outside consultants. That is a good move forward. We’re limited in what we can change here, as the Stockholm Convention supersedes the EU legislation, so this report has been relatively straightforward compared with previous legislation, and indeed with other things that I’ve worked on. But there are issues, and there is one particular issue – the problem of plastics recycling – which remains to be resolved in the vote tomorrow. This concerns the substance decaBDE. For political reasons which are not clear to me – but which, I would say, just amount to negligence – we find ourselves in a position where this substance was not granted a recycling exemption at UN level, despite the fact that less stable substances from the same chemical group have recycling derogations in place, and these were not removed by the Stockholm Convention. I sought to address this issue at committee level, but the oral amendment that I proposed was rejected by MEPs from some of the political groups. This was regrettable because it would have been best to have the issue dealt with at committee level. So I have re-tabled the same amendment – that’s Amendment 30 – for plenary. I cannot emphasise strongly enough the importance of this amendment when it comes to the EU’s circular economy objectives. Amendment 30 concerns five substances, four of which currently have individual recycling derogations of 1 000 ppm, and it imposes a limit of 1 000 ppm for all five combined. That’s a major net benefit environmentally and it is in line with limits set out in the current Restriction of Hazardous Substances Directive. The fifth substance, decaBDE, has the same recycling derogation under the REACH (Registration, Evaluation and Authorisation of Chemicals) Directive, a limit agreed only last year. I also include in my amendment a review of this limit in five years’ time. Without this amendment, the vast majority of plastics recyclers dealing with WEEE (waste electrical and electronic equipment) and end—of—life vehicles would have to dramatically reduce their activities or stop altogether. This would particularly and disproportionately affect SMEs. We are talking about 900 000 tons of end—of—life vehicle plastic waste each year, which will probably end up being exported outside Europe for recycling, where standards are far less rigorous and there is a real risk of it finding its way illegally into products such as toys, which are then imported into Europe. If we deal with it and recycle it within Europe to high standards, that should not, and cannot, happen. Amendment 37 seeks to impose a more ambitious target and, while I fully support ambition, its adoption would actually be negative rather than positive. What’s more, my Amendment 30 includes a review of the limit in five years’ time and this is crucially important. We have a strong commitment to the circular economy, and I hope that Members will bear that in mind when considering how to vote on these amendments.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the European Parliament, notably the rapporteur, Ms Girling, and the shadow rapporteurs for the work done on the Commission’s proposal to recast the POPs Regulation. POP stands for persistent, organic and pollutant. The term refers to chemical substances that persist in the environment, that bio-accumulate through the food chain and that are highly toxic to human health and the environment. Let me underline that these substances can be transported over thousands of miles in the environment from where they were released. This is why persistent organic pollutants are a global concern. As is often the case, global challenges require global solutions. The international community took action on these chemicals through the establishment of the Stockholm Convention on Persistent Organic Pollutants, which entered into force in 2004. The current EU Regulation on Persistent Organic Pollutants dates from 2004 and implements the international commitments expressed in the Stockholm Convention. The Regulation aims at eliminating the production, placing on the market and use of internationally produced persistent organic pollutants (POPs). In addition, it aims at reducing and eliminating the releases of POPs that are unintentional by—products of industrial processes such as dioxins. Last March, the Commission proposed the recast of the EU Regulation on Persistent Organic Pollutants in order to bring its procedures into line with the procedures set out in the Lisbon Treaty. The recasting process gave us an opportunity to update certain aspects of the regulation, to provide further clarity and to make its processes more efficient. For example, we proposed a role for the European Chemicals Agency (ECHA) to assist the Commission and provide scientific support. In addition, we adopted and streamlined reporting and monitoring obligations and proposed to align the annexes to the Regulation on Persistent Organic Pollutants with the outcome of the 2015 Conference of the Parties to the Stockholm Convention. Finally, we brought certain terms and definitions into line with those used in the EU REACH Regulation. I’m looking forward to hearing your views and I trust that you will give a strong mandate to Ms Girling to start negotiations as soon as possible.

name: Massimo PAOLUCCI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, persistent organic pollutants are certainly not a fascinating name or one of immediate understanding for the citizens who are following this debate. Therefore, in order to make us understand better, we must make it clear that these are dangerous toxic chemicals on a global scale, because they travel very long distances in the atmosphere, that persist in the environment for many years and that accumulate in ecosystems, thus posing serious risks to human health and the environment.  We are talking about dioxins, furans and pesticides, but also flame retardants that are still present in many everyday products such as TV screens, computers or car components. That is why the International Convention obliges us to be very strict in the treatment of these substances, which are very strict even when it comes to managing the presence in waste and materials that are treated for recycling.  That is why I would like to make it clear that we must prevent these products from being exported and treated outside Europe according to environmental standards that are not ours and then returning to Europe through the window. That is why we Socialists want to support and promote recycling activities, but at the same time to set ever more stringent and more ambitious limits.  Secondly, a petition by European citizens and a study commissioned by the European Parliament have shown that contaminated soils and groundwater are likely to exist in Europe. The Socialist Group has requested and obtained, on the basis of what we did a few years ago in the context of the mercury regulation, that the Commission and the Member States work together to identify and evaluate sites contaminated with persistent organic pollutants. These two principles will be defended tomorrow in the vote and in future negotiations with the Member States and the Commission.

name: Bolesław G. PIECHA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Persistent organic pollutants are chemical compounds, not only potentially, but also real dangerous because of their specific properties, which are associated with their toxicity and adverse effects on the human body, but also because they are super persistent in the environment, have bioaccumulation capacity and thus have a negative impact on the environment and human health. People are exposed to persistent organic pollutants in many ways. Mainly by the food or air they breathe. Everyday products, especially plastic ones, can contain many substances that are persistent organic pollutants that have been added to improve the product's properties, making it possible to find persistent organic pollutants almost anywhere, in measurable quantities.  As a politician, but above all as a doctor, I am particularly mindful of the issue of public health in general, and in this context I am thinking about the safety and health of people and animals. This is a beautiful idea, but I have to agree here with the rapporteur on the proposed derogation, which allows for a different concentration in recycled materials. Maybe it's a less ambitious but pragmatic look. I am in favour of proposing real legislation, and in numerous consultations, recycling stakeholders have expressed their support for this change and hence my support for the final report.

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Today we are taking an important step towards creating a non-toxic everyday life for our children and our societies. We need to limit substances such as DDT and dioxins – persistent organic compounds that are not broken down. These substances can cause chronic diseases, and they are carcinogenic. They affect the central nervous system and act as endocrine disruptors in the reproductive system. We get these harmful substances through food, because they are stored in animal adipose tissue. What we are legislating on today is to update EU chemicals legislation in line with the Stockholm Convention in order to limit the use of these organic compounds that are not broken down. We also clarify the role of the European Chemicals Agency. Our children should not be exposed to these toxins in their everyday lives. Therefore, this decision is an important 'green step' in the fight for a non-toxic everyday life.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, the proposed regulation implements the European Union's obligations under the Stockholm Convention on Persistent Organic Pollutants and the Protocol thereto. The basic objective of these international treaties and, consequently, the Regulation is to protect health and the environment from the harmful effects of this group of chemicals. Unfortunately, some major amendments have not been tabled by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, and the proposal has thus been fundamentally weakened, which is why I have also re-loaded them in plenary. I therefore ask you, together with environmental and consumer organisations, to vote in favour of stricter limits on certain other substances. Demonstrably toxic substances need to be banned as quickly as possible, globally in both new and recycled products. It is from recycled plastics that these substances disappear faster. In particular, I would like to ask you to support amendments that will protect consumers in Europe from exposure to these substances, particularly from recycled products, thus promoting a clean circular economy. I propose to update the limits for short-chain chlorinated paraffins, as proposed in a 2015 study conducted at the initiative of the German Environment Agency, and for the sum of PBDEs, which is in line with international commitments to reduce persistent organic pollutants under the Stockholm Convention.  Colleagues, it is imperative that the recast of the Regulation be adopted as soon as possible. This is absolutely necessary if we want to protect European citizens.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: Madam President, 173 countries have banned persistent organic pollutants. However, one cannot pretend that there are no problems with fertility or puberty, as if 80% of insects and a third of birds had not disappeared and as if pollinators were not in danger of death. Glyphosate, chlordecon, neonicotinoids, metam-sodium, there are no longer any health scandals. But what is the European Commission doing to protect the health of Europe's 500 million citizens? Today, almost a third of the chemicals on the European Union market since 2010 are potentially dangerous to human health, in breach of the EUROPEAN REACH regulation. What is the reality? The reality is that neither the Member States nor the European Commission apply Article 191 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which provides that the EU's environmental policy is aimed at a high level of protection and is based on precautionary principles. The reality is that most Member States are blithely violating these precautionary principles and that the European Commission, by letting go, is itself guilty of not assisting a citizen in danger. We must not play, joke, with the health of the 500 million European citizens, it is our full responsibility to act very concretely.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: Madam President, I welcome the revision of this regulation on these persistent organic pollutants (POPs). Indeed, many associations, including WECF (Women Engage for a Common Future) and FNE (France Nature Environment), demonstrate the presence of toxic substances, including flame retardants, which are POPs, in children's toys, kitchen utensils or hair accessories. What for? Because they're recycled plastics. I support my colleague, Mr Andrieu, and find it scandalous that the European Commission has granted exemptions to allow the recycling of plastics containing these substances. Studies on carpets have shown the presence of POPs in the carpets of the seven major manufacturers, be they phthalates, bromine flame retardants, etc. These substances should be banned upstream. Waivers should not be granted. I agree with Mrs Girling when she says that these exemptions must be abolished, because what is important, in the run-up to the European elections, is to show that Europe protects the health of consumers. Right now, we are not ambitious enough.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: – Mr President, persistent organic toxins, such as DDT and dioxins, are highly toxic to humans, animals and the environment. They accumulate in our fatty tissue and can be passed on to our children via breast milk.  Despite the fact that the use has already been restricted, we still find this poison in milk and eggs, but also in animals, such as birds, fish and seals, on clothing, in the soil and in groundwater. That is why we must ban all persistent organic substances, without delay and without exceptions. And of course we need to replace these substances, but not with other poisons. In the Netherlands, the highly toxic perfluorooctane acid has been replaced by GenX. Although GenX is probably also carcinogenic, it is used without any warning in the non-stick layer of pans. In the meantime, we find GenX everywhere in the environment! That is incomprehensible! These substances do not belong in our environment, not in our water and not in our bodies! I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished!

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Every day we are exposed to a lot of chemicals of different kinds. They are in our everyday lives. They are found in toys, food packaging, our clothes, the water we drink, even in the dust, which we might sweep under the carpet. For a large number of these substances, we do not know what the effects are for us humans and on the environment, even though it should really only be demonstrably safe substances in our everyday lives. The POP regulation contains some of the worst substances known to mankind, including brominated flame retardants, such as decaBDE, which are regulated by the Stockholm Convention. However, these substances do not become less dangerous because we reuse them in plastics, for example. Recycled plastic does not get better for our health, so it is important that we do two things at the same time: both get better at recycling and make sure to have a non-toxic everyday life. That is why I will fight to ensure that the decaBDE limit is kept in line with the report by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, i.e. 10 mg/kg. This is important for human health, it is important for the environment and it is also important for the public's confidence in recycled materials.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: Madam President, Commissioner, one of the most serious ecological and health crises in the whole of the European Union affects the outermost regions of Guadeloupe and Martinique, which have been exposed, as you know, for decades to a very toxic persistent organic pollutant: chlordecon. These islands are now ravaged by the persistence of this pollutant. One scientist said that we are in an almost post-Chernobyl situation: the land and soils are polluted for the next seven centuries and the inhabitants are sick. France has not fulfilled its duty to inform people about the risks they are now left to their fate. May this regulation compel France to fulfil its obligations! The West Indians, you see, Commissioner, expect a lot from Europe, and I am counting on you, Commissioner, to do so.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I will change my speech a little because of the debate that has just ended. First of all, I would like to draw attention to the fact that the so-called category of extraterritoriality of rubbish can be taken into account. This means that if we look at one ocean or another and see a huge amount of rubbish, we really have trouble establishing the responsibility of those who should deal with this problem. But there is no extraterritoriality of the sources of these pollutants. They can be reproduced and reached by actors, states, including the societies responsible for these pollution. And the second thing I want to point out is the completed SEDE mission in the Arctic, during which the issue of pollution with these very persistent inorganic chemicals was very strongly emphasised in terms of safety. This is a very important element and I also pay attention to it.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the regulation we are discussing is in line with the Stockholm Convention on Persistent Organic Pollutants or Persistent Organic Contaminants and, in fact, is based on it. These pollutants are chemical toxic substances of exceptional importance, affecting the health of all people. However, while we are discussing this regulation, it turns out that: firstly, no consultation was carried out with stakeholders in order to draw up the regulation, secondly, no external experts were used, and thirdly, no impact assessment was carried out. For a regulation so serious, it is also demonstrated by the debate that it is crucial for the very health of citizens. I think these procedures should have been done, because they are essential. Because external experts, as well as stakeholders, could offer their own interventions.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, persistent organic pollutants, of which perhaps the most mediat is DDT and dioxins, as the name implies, persist in the environment, contaminating natural habitats and have a high toxicity to us humans and to other living beings. We know that most of these pollutants are, moreover, endocrine disruptors, which means that they affect the health and reproduction of various animal species, including ours.  I therefore believe that strong measures are needed to eliminate this type of pollutant and prevent ecotoxicity and bioaccumulation in exponential consequences in humans. As regards the permissible powder limits, we must impose on recycled products the same rules that we already impose on virgin products, without creating a duality of criteria or a difference in quality between products, i.e. encouraging the circular economy means ensuring consumer safety, especially since the amount of recycled source material only tends to increase. We need to assure citizens that they can be rested that food, children's toys and common utensils are not contaminated with these high-risk substances.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I will admit that I have studied a lot about this matter recently, and I must say that I am appalled at how persistent organic pollutants are increasingly filling our environment and becoming a fatal threat to us. A fatal threat to our health, a fatal threat to the environment. I therefore wanted to say that I welcome this proposal, which tightens the existing regulation. Thank you to the Commission, thank you to the rapporteur, I am very happy that the new rules for the European Chemicals Agency are clearly being laid down. On the other hand, and that is why I have entered the debate, I ask the Commission to be much more ambitious in the future. In the future, if we want to address this problem, we will have to address the wider ban on these substances and the effort to find suitable components and suitable substitutes. So please for the future more ambition, it is necessary for our health and the health of our citizens.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank all the Members of Parliament who took part in the debate. It has been a really useful discussion and has touched upon the main elements of the Commission’s proposal.  Let me underline, however, one specific issue concerning your proposal of listing decaBDE (decabromodiphenyl ether) in the recast, since this featured prominently during the discussion. While I fully understand the objective of Parliament to take into account the experience and concerns of the recycling sector, I would like to remind you that it is crucial that our circular economies are as free as possible of toxic chemicals. This is in line with the objective of both the United Nations Stockholm Convention and the EU Regulation on Persistent Organic Pollutants (POPS) to eliminate production and use of these substances. To achieve that objective, it is of utmost importance that materials that contain persistent organic pollutants can be used or placed on the market only if those pollutants are present as unintentional trace contaminants. We must also be aware that products made from recycled materials will be accepted by consumers only if they have confidence in the quality and safety of the recycled material. Before I conclude, let me refer to some of your additional comments. First, regarding Mr Andrieu’s point about breaches of chemical legislation, I’d like you to know that this study was conducted regarding the REACH (Registration, Evaluation, Authorisation and Restriction of Chemicals) Regulation, whereas, in the debate, we were discussing the recast of the POPs Regulation and I would therefore really like to focus only on that. Secondly, we think that it is important to note that, contrary to the Stockholm Convention, discussions regarding other similar substances, the Stockholm Convention decision that listed decaBDE in Annex A to the Convention does not include a derogation for recycling of products containing decaBDE. This is significantly different from the listing of the other PBDEs (polybrominated diphenyl ethers) under the Convention in 2009, where such a recycling derogation was included. In this case, the listing of the PBDEs in the POPs Regulation in 2010 specifies that the unintentional trace contamination (UTC) levels for the PBDEs is ten ppm (parts per million), but in line with the listings in the Convention, a derogation of 1000 ppms for recycled materials is allowed. There is no such derogation in the Stockholm Convention for decaBDE. To conclude, I would like to underline that the Commission stands ready to provide support and to play to the full its honest broker role. I am looking forward to starting negotiations in order to ensure a first regarding agreement during the Austrian Presidency so that this legislation can make a real difference on the ground as soon as possible.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank colleagues for their contributions, some of which were more useful than others. I am particularly concerned at the attempts by one or two Members to roll into POPs (persistent organic pollutants) discussions around agri-chemicals such as glyphosate. It is utterly irresponsible to stand up in this Parliament and imply that glyphosate is a POP. It is not. This legislation is far too serious to play those sorts of politics with.  So, let’s restrict ourselves to dealing with the persistent organic pollutants. As I said in my opening address, there is no disagreement here that we all would like to eliminate them. The point is about how we do it, the rate at which we do it and the methodology. For me, I would just make my point again, yes, it’s true, as Ms Rivasi said, that there are studies that show that decaBDE (decabromodiphenyl ether), for example, has turned up in hair brushes. This is appalling, but I will bet my life that those hairbrushes were produced in the Far East. They were not produced in Europe, and they come from bad recycling.  If we want to prevent that from happening, if we want the recycling to take place in Europe, by European companies bound by European rules, which will not then put the recyclates on the market for products like food contact materials and toys, according to our rules, then we have to take control of that process. Pretending that we’re not going to recycle at all when we have legislation like the ELV (End-of-Life Vehicles) Directive and the WEEE (Waste Electrical & Electronic Equipment) Directive in place is frankly ostrich-like. So, I ask Members yet again to re-examine their support of Amendment 30 or Amendment 37, and to look carefully at Amendment 30, which not only sets out recycling reductions – because it takes four products, rolls them into five and gives the absolute maximum for all five, which is actually a reduction to 20% – but it also has a review mechanism which would allow us in five years, if we can get best available technology in place in the European recycling industry, to recycle these products. It would allow us to be in a position where we could actually eliminate these. If you go ahead with Amendment 37, that is not an option on the table.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 15 November 2018. Skriftlige erclringer (article 162)

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. – I have been warning colleagues for several weeks about the public health gaps in legislation, and I do not agree that this is merely a technical adjustment to international obligations. On the contrary, it is a decision with a significant social impact, the consequences of which we will bear for decades to come. The approach currently taken by the EU to recycling and the limits of persistent organic pollutants is literally toxic. Especially if there are safer alternatives. If we want to guarantee the safety of the materials we recycle, we must first of all eliminate the amount of hazardous substances in primary products, not put them back into circulation. And not at all in the form of contaminated kitchen utens or children's toys. For those who do not know, POP are substances that accumulate in the environment, from where they enter our food chain. In the human body, they disrupt the functioning of the hormonal, nervous and immune systems. Unfortunately, it is taking us too long in the EU to completely ban such dangerous substances, which leads to us still struggling with their legacy for a long time to come. Next year, for example, a five-year transitional period for HBCD will end. But we will have this toxic substance built into our homes for decades to come. I think we can all agree that we should not keep such an inheritance for our children.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the council and Commission statements on the independence of statistical offices in the European Union and the case of Andreas Georgiou (2018/2930(RSP)).

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, high quality, reliable and accurate official statistics are the pillar of the EU’s economic governance, supporting decisions in our economic surveillance procedures in the context of the European Semester. Issues related to statistics are therefore a regular item on the Council’s agenda. The Council regularly – once every year – reviews the EU’s statistical information needs, examines reports provided by EU statistical bodies and adopts conclusions, which evaluate progress and set priorities for the upcoming year. Undoubtedly, high—quality, accurate and reliable statistical data can only be produced by independent statistical authorities.  The professional independence of the EU’s national and Union—level statistical bodies is enshrined in EU law. The EU’s statistical authorities also operate according to the European Statistics Code of Practice. The implementation of the Code’s 16 principles is monitored by the Independent European Statistical Governance Advisory Board, which informs both Parliament and the Council. Indeed, the situation as regards the professional independence of statistical authorities in general has been satisfactory.  The important exceptions, however, are the concerns expressed over the judicial proceedings against the former President of Greece’s statistical authority, ELSTAT, Andreas Georgiou, and two senior ELSTAT officials. The Commission has repeatedly reiterated since 2016 its full confidence in the reliability and accuracy of ELSTAT data from 2010 to 2015 and since then. The issue has also been addressed by the Eurogroup in the context of Greece’s Third Economic Adjustment Programme, whose conditionality included requirements to review the provisions related to the autonomy of independent parties, including ELSTAT. Against this background, in June this year, on the occasion of concluding Greece’s Third Programme, the Eurogroup mandated the institutions to continue monitoring developments in the legal proceedings against the former President and senior staff of ELSTAT and against the members of the Committee of Experts of the Hellenic Republic Asset Development Fund. It also mandated them to monitor the supporting actions taken by the Greek authorities, including legislative actions, if needed, in full respect of the independence of the judiciary. The institutions are expected to report back to the Eurogroup in the context of the post—programme surveillance. These reports, in addition to the regular reporting by the European statistical agencies, will keep us informed on the situation related to ELSTAT.  With this, I will finish my brief statement and I will listen attentively to the Commissioner’s intervention and to your debate.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I appreciate the opportunity to discuss with you the independence of statistics for Europe.
