The independence of statistics and of the statistical authorities that produce them is a fundamental principle explicitly set out in EU law. The current governance of the European statistical system relies primarily on a clear, legal framework, the so—called statistical system. With your support, that law has been improved and strengthened, on the initiative of the Commission and in full observance of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. Like any principle or rule set out in law, statistical independence needs to be monitored and its implementation needs to be ensured in practice. Regulatory monitoring is carried out both by the Commission and by independent peers in the context of the European Statistics Code of Practice, already mentioned by the Presidency. This code aims to enhance the professional independence, integrity and accountability of European statistics and of the European statistical system. You in this House, as the European legislator, have contributed to ensuring the transparency and accountability of the European statistical system by establishing the European Statistical Governance Advisory Board (ESGAB). ESGAB is an independent body of experts that oversees the implementation of the Code of Practice, and every year it makes a report, which it presents to you, honourable Members, as well as to the Council. The annual ESGAB reports have always covered the principle of professional independence and illustrated the progress achieved at national and EU levels. On the basis of the Commission’s and ESGAB’s monitoring, the Member States have identified and implemented improvement measures that contribute to maintaining the confidence of users, and particularly their trust in the independence of statistics. As regards the specific situation in Greece and the situation of Mr Georgiou, let me firstly emphasise that the Commission has full confidence in the reliability and the accuracy of data produced by the statistical authority in Greece under Mr Georgiou’s leadership in the years from 2010. The Commission has consistently confirmed this in previous public statements. Secondly, let me repeat that the Commission neither comments on developments in ongoing national judicial proceedings nor assesses the impact of court decisions that are not final and irrevocable. That said, I can understand that the staff of the Hellenic Statistical Authority (ELSTAT) may feel they are not sufficiently well protected to do their jobs effectively and independently. The Commission has followed the developments in Greece consistently and has repeatedly expressed its concern in that regard, both in public statements and directly to the Greek authorities. The Eurogroup has also consistently expressed its support for Mr Georgiou and, most recently in its statement on Greece of 22 June this year, it has been inviting the European institutions to monitor the developments and to report back to the Eurogroup. It’s important to highlight that the Commission has actively supported Greek statistics on several fronts. The support has led, inter alia, to amendments of Greek law to further enhance the statistical authority’s institutional, operational and financial independence. Other legal amendments have provided for the indemnification of current or former statistics officials for legal expenses incurred in the context of trials following lawsuits or criminal charges against them related to the performance of their duties. Commission officials have also contributed extensively, with their expertise, to strengthening the statistical processes in Greece, and we continue to do that, as we do in other Member States too. In conclusion, I would like to reassure the honourable Members that not only has the independence of the national statistical authorities been strengthened in law, but Eurostat is also actively working to ensure that independence exists in practice too. Your continued vigilance will help us in this task.

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Madam President, the picture I have of Mr Georgiou is that he is an excellent scientist and technocrat who has fallen victim to the circumstances and political legal games. Part of society has charged him, in the heat of the crisis, with Greece's forced inclusion in a loan programme for allegedly changing the elements. Greece had necessarily entered a loan program before Mr. Georgiou finalized the statistics. Unfortunately, by staying in the euro we did not - for reasons of political cost - make the necessary reforms, as other countries have done, leading to over-indebtedness and deadlock. Countries with smaller problems than ours, such as Ireland, Portugal and Cyprus, were also forced to enter into a loan programme and implement the relevant memorandum. So it is not Mr Georgiou's fault for our problems, which continue because of the 2015 crisis. There are, of course, judicial officers who assess the situation differently. Suffice it to say that the former President of the Supreme Court, who is now an adviser to Prime Minister Tsipras, had sent a letter to Mr Juncker denouncing the loan programme. What we can and must do for Mr Georgiou is to insist that his judicial adventure be over and to make sure that the legal costs are passed on to the Greek State, as has already been decided. I therefore believe that the judicial adventures of Mr Georgiou must be put to an end. In my opinion, the routes that afflict him are underground. He has presented them in his own way to the European Parliament's Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, the independence and credibility of statistical authorities is a fundamental pillar of the EU and a prerequisite for a sound economy and a solid monetary union. We are proud of our statistics and we support Eurostat in its work in ensuring their growing quality and reliability. We all know that falsification of statistics occurred in Greece and that the work subsequently undertaken by Mr Georgiou, when he headed the Hellenic Statistical Authority (ELSTAT), has been crucial in improving the situation and bringing the numbers to reality and credibility. We also know that since then, ELSTAT has been carrying out excellent work and the Greek Government has put in place all the necessary measures to ensure and safeguard its independence. As the Eurostat assessment and approval of data collected as from 2010 show, ELSTAT has, since then, acted in an objective and reliable fashion, in compliance with its tasks and code of conduct, and with EU statistics rules. Our message here is clear and simple. We respect the Greek judicial system and its autonomy. However, we regret the judiciary crusade against Mr Georgiou which, we know, was not been triggered by the current Government. We want to reiterate here our full support for him. We are very concerned about the potential consequences of such an affair, and the risk of undermining the independence and impartiality of all statisticians: because independence means not only not being subject to external interference but also being safeguarded against hostile surrounding factors that could prevent people from carrying out their tasks freely and impartially.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Madam President, the issue of artificially inflating the public deficit in 2009 proved decisive in order to enable george papandreou's government to legitimise and initiate Greece's accession to the International Monetary Fund and the Memorandums. Thus, while the Karamanlis government, in September 2009, had identified the public deficit at 6%, the Papandreou government, after PASOK's election victory in October 2009, identified it at 12.7%. What was the result? Undermine the country's borrowing position. Launch a borrowing crisis and lead Greece into the "hug" of the troika, which for eight years impoverished the Greek people, slashed wages and pensions and soared debt from 115% of GDP to 180%. The proof of the artificial widening of the deficit also exposes the European Union itself, as it proves that the memorandum was imposed when it was not necessary for Greece. After all, Mr Dijsselbloem confessed that the memorandum saved the lenders, saved the euro and not Greece. The Georgiou case has concerned the Greek criminal courts, before which he was found guilty. Greek justice is independent and the European Parliament has no power to med. All this discussion is taking place for the sole purpose of internationalizing the new criminal case against Mr. Georgiou, since a new criminal prosecution has been brought. Colleagues, if you want to help Mr. Georgiou, go as defense witnesses to his trial instead of talking here politically. Go to the criminal courts to defend him as witnesses, those of you who think Mr. Georgiou is right.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, the European Union is honouring its charter of fundamental values and it is in this way that we fight against misleading information, protect whistleblowers and respect the principles of the rule of law.  Any community, as long as it mobilizes the funds of its members, must be vigilant about the sincerity of the reports and statistical information. Mutual trust is built on a demand for truth and reliability. Andreas Georgiou, Director General of ELSTAT (the Greek Authority for Macroeconomic, Fiscal and Financial Statistics) has been on the prosecuted since 2011 for complying with EU standards in this area. While two decisions of the Greek Supreme Court ruled against him, in September this year, a third procedure has just been launched against him at the initiative of the Prosecutor General's Office. I observe that the old team, the one that made up the public accounts, is not the subject of any lawsuit. On the other hand, vindictiveness focuses on Andreas Georgiou. I appeal to the Council, Madam Minister, and to the Commission, Commissioner, not to be suspected of complicity in a marked judicial harassment that undermines the indispensable confidence within the Economic and Monetary Union. Put an end to this scandalous situation on a human, political and European level. If Guy Béart sang "He told the truth, he will be executed", this is not our vision, this is not our course of action, this is not our requirement. It's a matter of trust. Finally, I would like to say to our Greek colleagues that it is essential to put an end to this scandalous situation. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Notis MARIAS
text: blue card question. – Mr President, there is independent Greek justice. You said that a new criminal prosecution has already been launched against Mr. Georgiou. With what you've said, you seem to believe in Mr. George's innocence. So I ask you: will you go to the Greek courts to testify as a defence witness for Mr. Georgiou? That's the only way you can help him. You can be a defense witness at his trial. Are you going to go? Because, in practice, that's the only way you can help. Otherwise, all the political debate here means interference in the Greek criminal justice system.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: "blue card" answer. "Dear Marias, make no mistake, we are both in the diversity of the countries we represent, the political formations that we represent. We are the guarantors of a moral pact based on trust. Mr. Georgiou benefited from two non-Places of the Supreme Court. So why the relentlessness shown by the Prosecutor General's Office, which is launching a third case against Mr Georgiou? I would really like you, as a Greek elected official, to be able to lobby the public and the Greek authorities to put an end to this situation.  We will build Europe on a principle of trust and not on the make-up of public accounts.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, in a world where the rule of law is under threat, we must protect the integrity and independence of public officials. In this context, there is deep concern about the charges lodged against Greece’s top statistician, Mr Andreas Georgiou, who was responsible for re-calculating the country’s economic statistics, in accordance with EU law, in 2010. His case represents the trial of evidence-based policy-making and it is a test of the independence of state officials. Policy-makers, as well as the general public, require high-quality statistics in order to make informed decisions within our democracies. Any attempt to undermine independent experts should ring alarm bells. In this case, there is a suspicion that a legal process is being used as a tool to scapegoat statisticians for the impact of national economic policies. The Commission should take steps to protect the independence and integrity of the work of statisticians and to ensure that they are not subject to political pressure. I would like to agree with Mr Gualtieri and also to express my support for Mr Georgiou.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, for the 2009 deficit, ladies and gentlemen, which was 15.1% and not 6% - as the New Democracy government told us with false data and 'cooked' statistics - it is the then rulers and not Mr Georgiou. I am pleased that the Council and the Commission, as well as Eurostat, the Eurogroup and the ESM, confirm that today and all the last years, since 2010, Greek public statistics have been completely reliable. Mr Ferber also confirmed this when Mr Radermacher came and spoke to us in the European Parliament, and Mrs Kotzeva, and said that 'cooked' figures and deficits belong to the period when new democracy and PASOK ruled the country. For this very reason, I would like to tell you that we fully respect and guarantee the independence of both ELSTAT and Greek justice. Those who are now attempting to exploit the judicial adventures that afflict Mr Georgiou in order to hurt my country, Greece, all they achieve is to recall the financial derailment and the false statistics, Madam President, ... (The President removes the floor from the speaker.)

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Madam President, the case of Andreas Georgiou of the Hellenic Statistical Office is not just a criminal or even disciplinary breach of duty. On the one hand, Georgiou bears very serious moral responsibilities which no court has jurisdiction to judge, and, on the other hand, he had to protect the State and Greek interests. However, he chose to obey his bosses, inside and outside Greece. The Greek citizens are not interested in themselves as a person, but in the position they served and especially the work and the result produced. The result was the artificial widening of the deficit in 2009, which led Greece to the vortex of memoranda, poverty, sell-off and misery. It must be understood that an independent national authority remains national and accountable to the state concerned. The employees of the independent authorities continue to be officials of the national states. They are not on an away mission and are not employees of lenders or any European institution. The political responsibility of the Greek governments of New Democracy, PASOK, SYRIZA and ANEL in this matter is real and constitutes a national betrayal. A patriotic government will lead the political accountable to the stool of the accused, because in Greece's rotten political system "crow's eye does not come out".

name: Markus FERBER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her What Andreas Georgiou is accused of would perhaps be punished with a reprimand in Germany, but by no means with a two-year prison sentence. The verdicts against Andreas Georgiou were overturned several times by appeals courts; each time, the Greek judiciary, the Public Prosecutor's Office, has brought new proceedings. In view of this, a question arises: why was it such a concern for the Greek state to condemn Andreas Georgiou? His crime was not that he published statistical data without consulting his colleagues on the Elstat Board – his real crime was that Andreas Georgiou did his job, and that includes the fact that uncomfortable truths must be told. The real scandal is that those who helped report erroneous statistical data are not held accountable. No, instead it is the person who has worked to ensure that the rules are respected and that there is no trickery. By reporting erroneous data, Greece has damaged the integrity of the European statistical system. However, the much greater damage was caused by the treatment of Andreas Georgiou. The European statistical system is based on the basic presumption that the data reported are correct. This, in turn, presupposes that statisticians are allowed to do their work untroubled. For this reason, I can only condemn the action. (The speaker refused to answer a question from Mr Papadimoulis and a question from Mr Chountis under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Jakob von WEIZSÄCKER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Andreas Georgiou has now been accused in the courts for years for telling the truth in a difficult situation. He became head of the Greek Statistical Office in August 2010. He then finally calculated the Greek deficit figures correctly. Before that, the statistics were flawed. All this is confirmed by the European statistical authority. Yes, he became the bearer of bad news in difficult times. But that was precisely his damn duty as a public servant and in accordance with our European rules. At a time when mistrust and fake news threaten to destroy Europe, Mr Georgiou has created confidence. When you travel in other, less fortunate parts of the world, you realize what a blessing it is that our officials are committed to the truth, that it serves the state, not simply the rulers. As far as I know, this great civilisational achievement in Europe has also historically arisen in Greece. Europe can be grateful for that, and Greece can be proud of it. We must preserve this achievement and protect our public servants. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: blue card question. – Thank you, Mr Weizsäcker, you are not afraid of questions like Mr Ferber. So I ask you: which party was it that, in 2009, showed the 'cooked' statistics? If Mr. Georgiou was right in estimating the deficit at 15.1%, who was in government in 2009 and showed here fake statistics saying 6%?

name: Jakob von WEIZSÄCKER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. This is not about who ruled Greece and when. I believe that everyone in this room knows this, but the question here is whether a statistical office can do its job in the required independence. I think, Mr Papadimoulis, that you have found very wise words on this and I have nothing to add to them.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: – Madam President, sometimes we learn from the Islamic world the news that a raped woman is being punished for being raped. And we here in Europe will say, "Well, such absurdity, that just couldn't happen here!" Well, let's see what's going on. The official, the head of the statistics office, is going to be convicted of - or convicted of - telling the truth. And we're going to talk about it with all seriousness, whether it's really a grind or not. And whether he said it would be 15% or 13%. Greece, anyway, has got into the most difficult possible problems, not because of this Mr Georgemus, who has said how things are, but because of those governments that have indebted the country as if there is no tomorrow. I just want to remind you that today we are talking about Italy planning to make a 2.4% deficit and because of this, the fire on the roof is absolutely right! And here we're talking about whether it was 9, 6, 13 or 15. This makes the discussion so terribly absurd.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: – Mr President, Mr Georgiou is in exile in the US for telling the truth. He communicated the correct numbers of the Greek economy at that time and the Greek public deficit figures. He shed the light on the biggest lies that led the Greek state and the EU into one of the most severe financial crises since the end of the Second World War.  Even The Economist, two years ago, denounced the prosecution of Mr Georgiou as a violation of scientific freedom and human rights. Last October, the Financial Times reported that Mr Georgiou received an award for statistical integrity given by the world’s leading statistical societies.  Lastly, the think-tank Bruegel said last June: ‘the European Union must defend Andreas Georgiou. The European Union also needs to reform its statistical framework to ensure a similar scandal cannot happen again.’  What is at stake is the credibility of our European Union above the credibility of the Greek authorities. This is a very dangerous precedent. It is crucial that the statistical basis for our economic decision-making remains reliable and independent from political interference. What is at stake is the reliability and independence of the statistics office and authorities all across Europe.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Notis MARIAS
text: blue card question. Mr Tremosa, I sincerely want to enlighten you on the facts. The Government of New Democracy, in September 2009, said that the deficit is 6%. PASOK won the elections on 4 October 2009. On 19 October 2009, the Finance Minister, Mr Papakonstantinou, went to the Eurogroup and said that the deficit is 12.7%. And I ask you: do you think it is a serious action, within ten days, for a new finance minister to have the data and raise the deficit to this rate? That is the key question. Mr Georgiou was appointed in August 2010, I ask you about 2009. Is it possible that within ten days the government will change the rate without having the opinion of ELSTAT? Watch it, watch it! These are the facts.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: blue-card answer. – Very briefly, I am not an expert in the details of Greek politics, but I do not think that Mr Georgiou is guilty of causing the Greek crisis. A lot of things were done badly over many years, and the right way to proceed is not to prosecute civil servants who try to tell the truth. A precedent is being set for all EU Member States, so this is why we need to take action.

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Greek people have paid dearly for falsifying - both by the Greek authorities and by Eurostat - the statistics of the Greek economy. These falsified statistics were used by the Commission. Commissioner, I have a number of questions from that period, where the Commissioners actually admit it. The political games played with the statistics provided the ground for the imposition of social degradation policies by the troika. The President of ELSTAT in 2010, Mr Georgiou, in breach of national legislation and the existing European framework of national accounts, added in particular - Mr Ferber, that is what I would ask you - the balance sheets of seventeen public bodies without the necessary conditions, thus further inflating the deficit and implementing tougher austerity policies than the Memorandums. The troika is now coming to the pre-requisites of the Third Memorandum and reiterates the demand that the Greek judiciary intervene, that the Greek government intervene and acquit Mr Georgiou, as they do in other cases of their people - such as the people in THEAPD - who have demonstrably harmed the national interest. The Greek people are calling for this issue to be addressed, dear friends, and for the memorial policy and supervision to be stopped with these elements and policies.  (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Jakob von WEIZSÄCKER
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Chountis, I would like to thank Mr Chountis for his work on this I would like to know from you why you believe that the figures drawn up under Mr Georgiou were flawed, when the European Statistical Office has confirmed that the work was correct. That was not apparent from your speech. I would like to know where you see the problem. Our European authorities say that was all right. How do you come to a different conclusion?

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: answer a question with a blue card. Mr President, I was an MEP in the previous period, which was discussed in plenary session of the European Parliament, and in general the issue of statistics and, ultimately, the question of the credibility of Eurostat. It turned out that Eurostat was accepting falsified data - for every use I can say - from other countries, not just Greece. Secondly, the Commission's irresponsibility with regard to such a situation was pervasive. On the subject of Greece, Eurostat subsequently covered Mr Georgiou. I would also like to ask you: do you know whether in your country, the general government deficit statistics also include the balance sheets of the TENs, and under what conditions? Conditions that Mr. Georgiou did not meet? Do you understand what the problem is?

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work and for her work on the Yes, we know this in Germany, Mr Chountis, that the statistics we report are correct. If they were not correct, we would impose a penalty for not being correct, and not because someone reported it as correct. This is an absurd misway of content and an absurd misway of events. So far, several Greek governments have passed on to Mr Georgiou – the current government with particular intensity, and that now makes it the main culprit of the proceedings against Mr Georgiou. I believe that it is extremely regrettable, and we have also said this to Mr Georgiou and the Greek governments with the Financial Working Group for Greece. I've been there twice myself. It is not possible for such things to be done in Greece. Incidentally, I am astonished at this form of waste of resources. And I am also surprised that the Greek judiciary, which has such a pact on cases, suddenly takes this case so seriously that it takes it three times and rejects it again. The Greek Government has always held us back with flimsy arguments. We have repeatedly insisted that this procedure be brought to an end, because it is a matter of credibility.  What is it all about? Mr Ferber asked the question. I can tell you what it is all about. It is an attempt to set an example in order to send clear signals to other officials: do not report anything to Brussels until we have ticked it. The chance of manipulation must be preserved. That is really what this is all about. This lesson, which is being taught to Greek officials, must be rejected and is extremely harmful.  I myself am doing budgetary control here. A Greek official once told me how he wrote his report to the EUROPEAN Commission. He comes into office on Sunday, shuts himself up and does not open the door until the report is ready. In other words, you have a fundamental interest in Europe giving you credibility. Work on credibility! That is what I would urge you to do.  Mr. President! I don't shy away from a fight. But I do not want to hear the nonsense that our Greek colleagues are telling us here. Thank you, no. (The speaker refused to answer a question by Mr Papadimoulis under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Miltiadis KYRKOS
text: Mr President, in 2009 the budget deficit in Greece had escaped. The Conservative government falsely declared a deficit of 6%, while we reached 15% at the end of the year. With the intervention of the Commission, Greece changed the leadership of the Statistical Authority, Mr Andreas Georgiou took office and very soon the phrase "Greek statistics" ceased to mean illegality. In May 2014, the European Parliament explicitly acknowledged this illegality in its report on the Greek crisis. Those responsible for the collapse of the economy and the conscious deception of the European authorities are sending to trial, for the third time, the official who did his duty. With them are those who claim that a conspiracy of dark circles brought the Greek crisis and not the small competitiveness of our economy, the high appointments and corruption. The Greek government must voluntarily defend Andreas Georgiou, both for himself and to give the message that no official who does his job properly will find himself defenceless.

name: Thierry CORNILLET
text: Mr President, this is in fact a matter of credibility today, because the credibility of the Council, the Commission and our Parliament is at stake. We cannot affirm principles and values here and then not defend them when some people sit on them. In this case, it is a matter of credibility, because it is a judicial harassment with threefold consequences. We are very committed to the independence of the judiciary, we are equally committed to the independence of the statistical authorities. This is therefore a threefold consequence for Mr Georgiou - but also in a way for all the civil servants who have done their job - who has been accused for several years, even though he has done his job in accordance with European procedures. For the work of analysing the facts that make these statistical authorities able to produce independent figures on which public policies are based and for the construction of common rules that require trust between partners, it is important that our Parliament, naturally accompanied by the Council, put an end to this legal sham which, in fact, poses a problem for the defence of independent institutions. , which are useful for policy makers, for the future of economic and monetary union and, of course, for the person of Mr Georgiou, who finds himself exiled from his country because of this matter.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: Mr President, the case of Greece was a punitive process. A message from the financial system that it is all-powerful and above institutions and any democratic control. In the Georgiou case, the Greek justice system tried and tried to uncover the truth and subvert the fabricated false image of Greece. Since this case did not have the development they longed for, the European democratic institutions on the other side demanded that Mr Georgiou be cleared of all charges, in the midst of the judicial investigation, by openly interfering in the functioning of Greek justice. And in order for their willing elites not to have similar problems in the future, they demanded and ensured the criminal and civil induation of the members of the new colonial Privatisation Fund, as a basic condition for the completion of the evaluation of the country, something accepted by the current government. Ladies and gentlemen, these practices offend us as representatives of the citizens and disregard the values of the European Union that we here defend. Let us not wonder what it is that "throws water in the mill" of the far right.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Mr President, we are debating the independence of the statistical authorities here and I note that both the Council and the Commission have praised the quality of the statistics, particularly in Greece. I would of course call on the Commission to check that the same is true in each of the Member States of the European Union, because we know how important the independence of the statistical authority is to the credibility of the policies that are being carried out. Similarly, the independence of the statisticians themselves must be preserved. What are we talking about here? Because in reality, as everyone knows, there is a desire behind this debate to question what is happening in Greece around Mr Andreas Georgiou. Is the Greek Statistical Office (ELSTAT) not working well? Obviously, I do not think that is the case. Is it considered then that the Greek government should intervene in a case of justice? I would be surprised if this House would want to go in this direction, as it seems to me that it is attached to both the independence of the statistical offices and the judiciary. However, I note that last June, President Tsipras himself said that he recognized the quality of the statistical data provided by Mr Giorgio and that he was prepared to go to court to testify on his behalf if necessary. Beyond that, if some in this Chamber consider that the current procedure in Greece suffers from shortcomings, then we must go not to a debate that we want to politicize here, but before the European Court of Human Rights.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, the seizure of the rich energy reserves, which are located in the subsoil and undersea area of the Greek territory, has always been the aim of the institutions of international capital and of the European Union. At the same time, Greece had to sacrifice itself to rescue the euro and the German and French banks. For this to happen, the Greek economy had to be destroyed and the president of ELSTAT, Mr Georgiou, was used as an instrument. According to the complaint of two of his subordinates, he falsely explained the deficit that existed in Greece, resulting in the country being placed under memorandums, destroying its economy, plundering its wealth and suffering its people. Of course, the Greek judiciary intervened and Mr Georgiou was charged to a degree of felony. But the damage to national interests had already caused it. That is why the European Union's establishment defends it so strongly.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Mr President, we will not go into the George-ELSTAT case in detail. But it's provocative. Thousands of people who do not have to pay taxes and loans are condemned in Greece, but no case has been brought here, in the "Temple of the European Republic". For Mr Georgiou, however, a photographic exemption provision is being discussed. You are cut for independent authorities, e.g. Statistics. Hypocrisy! With your instructions you "cook" them and make them tools of your unpopular policy. I wonder how objective it is that anyone who works half an hour a week is not considered unemployed? You're cut for independent justice. Joke! When you don't like decisions, you ask for legislative interventions. You have demanded, and SYRIZA has also given you, memorandum laws on advance and retroactive - for those who have been prosecuted - a criminal exemption for the executives of the THIPED for transfers of billions of euros of public property to private individuals. The same goes for "haircuts" of business start-up loans, while you auction thousands of popular homes and ban strikes. You're just vindicating the Communist Party.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, we all agree on the importance of independent statistics for informed policy-making and sound decision-taking at both national and Union levels. Transparency and accountability are key notions in that regard, and therefore I again welcome the opportunity to appear before you. For the Commission, it is essential that the independence of the statistical authorities, and of the people who perform their duties in line with their responsibilities, is protected. The Commission will therefore continue to monitor the application of fundamental statistical principles in all Member States, and I thank the House for its support on this. The situation of Mr Georgiou is of concern to you as well as to the Commission. Let me repeat, once again, that we have full confidence in the reliability and the accuracy of data produced by the Hellenic Statistical Authority (ELSTAT) under his leadership. Concerning the comments made by Mr Chountis, I refer to the reply to question No 4404 from this year. In short, we stand by the correction made by Mr Georgiou in 2010. As I said before, we have also repeatedly voiced that concern via public statements or directly in contacts with the Greek authorities. Furthermore, a Commission official appeared as a witness before a Greek court and offered testimony in support of the implementation of EU law by the Greek statistical authority under Mr Georgiou’s leadership. I am glad that some of you recognised that the independence of ELSTAT has been strengthened. Greek statistics law has been brought into line with EU law, notably Regulation 223 on European statistics, as well as the European Statistics Code of Practice, to ensure professional independence. These make it clear that the content and timing of statistical release is the sole responsibility of the heads of the statistical offices. I also have to tell you that all governments have expressed their support for the European Statistics Code of Practice. On the basis of the code, Member States subject themselves to regular peer views and the results of the peer reviews are published and combined with action plans for improvements where necessary. The Commission fully recognises and respects the independence of the judicial authorities in Greece. They should be allowed to perform their tasks without political considerations or pressure. In that respect, representatives of governments and public authorities at both national and EU levels have a duty to refrain from anticipating the outcome of judicial investigations or proceedings. I count on your continued support, and also your attention, to safeguard the fundamental principles of high quality and trustworthiness in relation to statistics.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I would like to thank everyone very much for this discussion. It is a matter that definitely deserves our attention and I would like to fully second what Madam Commissioner said: the independence of statistical authorities is one of the pillars of the EU’s economic governance.  On the other hand, please let me state, as a former judge, that the independence of the judicial system is also one of the cornerstones of the rule of law and democracy and, therefore, I can only assure you that we will closely follow the developments. However, I hope that we don’t have to come back to such a situation again.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The debate is closed.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on European security policy and the future of the Treaty on Medium-Range Nuclear Forces (2018/2907(RSP)).

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the High Representative / Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for this opportunity to discuss a subject of tremendous importance for European and global security. The treaty on intermediate-range nuclear forces in Europe, in force since 1988, is among the key international agreements which marked the end of the Cold War. While neither the European Union nor any of the EU Member States are parties to the treaty, we do have a very high stake in its preservation and continued implementation. Thanks to the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty, some 3000 missiles with nuclear and conventional warheads have been removed and verifiably destroyed. For those who have the experience and memory of the Cold War, this was a truly historical moment. The tools for waging nuclear war were not only removed from our continent but irreversibly dismantled and destroyed. This happened under the mutual supervision, in the form of one-side inspections. So we are justified in declaring that the INF Treaty has not only contributed to the end of the Cold War, but it also constitutes one of the major pillars of European current security architecture. Calling it a Cold War-era agreement or a relic of the Cold War is a misinterpretation and a misunderstanding. The INF Treaty is always an important contribution to disarmament obligations under Article 6 of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. All EU Member States, whether or not they have nuclear weapons, both NATO members and non-NATO countries, all are state parties to the non-proliferation treaty. We are united in our support for the non-proliferation treaty as the cornerstone of the global nuclear non-proliferation regime. The treaty has made a crucial contribution to international peace, security and stability over the past 50 years. Let me recall that all states party to the non-proliferation treaty are committed to pursuing the objective of achieving a world without nuclear weapons. We, as the European Union, stressed the need for concrete progress towards the full implementation of Article 6 of the non-proliferation treaty especially through an overall reduction in the global stockpile of nuclear weapons. The states that possess the largest nuclear arsenals – which are the Russian Federation and the United States –have a special responsibility on this. The INF Treaty does not only cover nuclear-armed missiles. It is about an entire category of ballistic and cruise missiles, regardless of their warheads. In recent years, the development, test or use of ballistic missiles has been a destabilising factor in regional and international security. It creates an atmosphere of mistrust and suspicion and adds uncertainty in international relations – I am thinking, in particular, of the launches by North Korea, Iran and Syria. The INF Treaty is also a model to be followed and, as such, it is today more relevant than ever before. The current disarmament and non-proliferation architecture needs to become more universal as a guarantee for all. We Europeans are working at all levels to promote the universalisation of existing agreements, such as The Hague Code of Conduct against ballistic missile proliferation. The Hague Code does not prohibit the possession of missiles but aims to prevent proliferation and increases transparency for the benefit of subscribers. Subscribing states exchange information including pre-launch notifications. As of now, 139 countries have subscribed to The Hague Code. This is no small achievement as subscribers include the US and Russia, as well as all EU Member States. The EU has a long history of supporting the universalisation and effective implementation of The Hague Code, both diplomatically and financially, both the immediate contact point in the Austrian MFA and the rotating chairmanships benefit from EU-funded support programme. It is not by chance that very often it is EU Member States which hold the annual rotating chairmanships of The Hague Code, promoting its universalisation and chairing relevant meetings. Last year it was Poland, this year: Sweden. But let me stress that politically binding confidence-building measures like The Hague Code are not a substitute for legally binding arms control and disarmament agreements like the INF Treaty. It is for this reason that, in our view, the United States and the Russian Federation needs to remain engaged in constructive dialogue to preserve to INF Treaty and ensure its full and verifiable implementation, which is crucial for European and global security. We have asked the United States to consider the consequences of its possible withdrawal from the INF on its own security, and on our collective security and we expect the Russian Federation to address the serious concerns regarding its compliance with the INF Treaty. The world doesn’t need a new arms race. That would benefit no one. On the contrary, it would only bring even more instability.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Minister for her clear statement. There is no doubt that what we have seen now is a real blow to the disarmament of nuclear weapons in the world. We all understand that Russia is not complying with the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty and there is real concern, but it’s the wrong reaction from the US President to withdraw from such an important treaty. With the new START (Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty) expiring in 2021, we could, in the worst case, be left out of control of nuclear states with their nuclear arsenal and we could go back to a situation which I think we have to go back to 1972 to see. This is really detrimental.  We should – as the European Union, as Europeans – ask Trump to reconsider. We need to fight hard for disarmament and the control of nuclear weapons. I remember a time when the previous president, President Obama, gave a speech on a world without nuclear arms and I think we are now, unfortunately, on the wrong track. So let’s react and let’s react together as Europeans.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the modernisation of the Russian army after a war in Georgia led to a massive violation of the INF Treaty. This was indicated by the US in 2014, in numerous cases by NATO, by myself in amendments to the Landsbergis report, and during a meeting of the Subcommittee on Security and Defence (SEDE) in January this year by renowned experts. Deterring Russia is a tricky task. We have to rely on the NATO viewpoint rather than support Russia in its actions by following the narrative.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr It's not a surprise when it comes to President Trump. Anything can happen. For the most part, what he does is very worrying. Not least, it is worrying that on 20 October this year he terminated the agreement between the UNITED States and the Soviet Union to abolish medium- and short-range missiles. The question then is how we in the EU and the Member States should approach what comes as a letter in the mail. Firstly, we Greens want Mrs Mogherini, the Presidency and the Member States to do all they can to keep the agreement in force. Secondly, we believe that it is clear that a new initiative is needed with a view to achieving total nuclear disarmament in Europe, and that a regional nuclear-free zone is needed, as the UN calls for in its Resolution 3472 B of 1975. However, as long as there is no new agreement in place, it is crucial that we stick to the various disarmament agreements that already exist. With American nuclear weapons in Europe and Russian nuclear weapons next to our borders, and as both the British and the French continue to invest in their nuclear arsenals, there is little prospect of an EU decision to join the new UN Convention on The Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons. Thirdly, we should therefore accede to the Convention. Nuclear weapons in Europe do not give us security. On the contrary, it is not difficult to imagine that Europe could once again risk becoming the great battlefield and that nuclear-armed medium-range missiles can detonate on European soil if something goes wrong. That is why we can and should lead the way in disarmament, but it is also crucial that other countries, including Russia, the UNITED States and China, support all disarmament agreements, including bilateral ones.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the The INF is a milestone in the history of nuclear disarmament and international security policy. It promoted confidence building between the two nuclear superpowers, the United States and Russia, with far-reaching positive consequences, including for our European security and our social development processes. Last but not least, it also made an important contribution to the necessary denuclearisation of European security structures.  Unfortunately, this trend has reversed in the short past. Both the US and Russia are modernizing their nuclear weapons systems. And yes, the growing distrust of both parties in recent months and years, which is also reflected in the announced dissolution of the INF Treaty, does not make the world any safer. It's threatening.  It remains crucial for us, as the European Parliament, to make every effort to enable the American and Russian sides to adhere to the Treaty. All EU Member States, for their part, must take political action in this direction. And perhaps the INF Treaty is also a model for putting an international treaty of new bilateral, regional or multilateral nuclear disarmament agreements on the agenda of international security and peace policy.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Us denunciation of the Treaty on Euromissiles shows the glaring failure of the European Union's foreign policy, the flagship of the Lisbon Treaty. In this treaty, the European Union has, it can be said, bowed to NATO policy by making itself constitutionally dependent on the decisions taken by others. Today, we complain about American unilateralism. Yet, for more than a decade, the European Union has pursued a policy of escalating tensions with Russia, orchestrated by the United States. By hosting the missile shield, that is, in reality, missile launcher sites. Border countries have shaken up the continent's military balance. By miring Europe in its old grudges - Russian-Polish animosity, war in Ukraine on the borders of culture and civilization - we have, with the full support of the External Action Service, deliberately sabotaged any policy of détente. But détente was the necessary condition for Reagan and Gorbachev to sign the treaty in 1987. We have sowed a wind of new tensions, I fear that we will reap the risks of war again.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, a few days ago, President Trump announced the decision to withdraw his country from the Treaty of Medium-Range Nuclear Forces. This Treaty, signed in 1987 by Gorbachev and Reagan, is very important because it is legally binding and in the context of its implementation three thousand nuclear missiles have been destroyed. However, with the withdrawal of the United States from this Treaty, as well as from the Iran Nuclear Treaty, there is a growing risk that nuclear weapons will increase by all nuclear powers. The U.S. has the ability to strengthen its nuclear arsenal. Russia wants to remain in the Treaty, but feels threatened. And if it decides to include nuclear weapons in its strategic planning, there will be adverse developments. All the countries of Europe, especially Germany, will be affected.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Mr President, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work and for the I see here the reversal of things. I was already politically active in 1980. At that time, there were only Soviet missiles aimed at Europe – exclusively. These were the SS-20. On the other hand, there was the NATO double decision, which led to the Soviet Union being forced to make the deal with Gorbachev in 1987, that both sides would abolish their weapons, that we would not continue to set up and that the SS-20 would disappear. That is the INF Treaty. However, we have known for some years now that Russia is once again erasing these modern-day missiles – missiles, medium-range weapons that do not reach the United States or anyone else, but which are almost exclusively aimed at Europe. In other words, we have a situation like 1980, where we have directed Russian medium-range missiles with nuclear weapons at Europe, but that there are no counter-weapons on the part of Europe and in Europe. In other words, we arrived at 1980 and the Russians destroyed the INF Treaty. I don't think it's so wrong that this is now becoming apparent – and I'm not often a Trump fan . I believe that Russia is called upon to put an end to this, to remove these missiles, so that the content of the INF Treaty is fulfilled. The American missiles in Romania are not surface-to-surface missiles that threaten Russia. These are surface-to-air missiles to shoot down missiles aimed at Europe, and the deployment of missiles in Romania was intended to deter Iranian missiles. I believe that we should invite the Russians to carry out an inspection of the installations in Romania in order to remove any uncertainties that this would be aimed at firing Russian missiles aimed at Europe – not even that is what we want! – and that is why the deal must be done to ensure that the Russians finally remove their missiles aimed at Europe.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Mr President, by disconnecting Russia from this treaty, Mr Trump may indeed be playing putin's dangerous game, because the treaty has effectively reduced the risks of military escalation, operational miscalculations and helped to change the MAD logic of the Cold War to that of dialogue between Russia and the United States. Even if Moscow's treaty is not complied with and even if Trump also aims to renegotiate with Russia, and even indirectly to contain China's nuclear capability, the risks of escalation and catastrophe are tremendous, because today's Russia may be tempted to compensate for weakness in conventional forces by using its nuclear capabilities and in europe's midst. It's insane not to see that our security and global security are at stake. The European Union cannot remain mute and fall. It must intervene in some way and try to negotiate with both of them so that these intermediate-range nuclear forces are actually reduced, but also in all the others who hold them.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by It is difficult to have a claim to the United States that they do not want to firm up a systematically violated treaty. It is also difficult to really assume that the best kind of pressure to comply with the ban on medium-range missiles will be requests, declarations, appeals. If we really want a balance of power, we should learn from this. The first conclusion is that we must be able to exert convincing pressure, such as strengthening the security of the Baltic States or strategically seeking to demilitarise the Kaliningrad region, the greatest threat to Central Europe. Let us really remember that requests are not the best kind of policy.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Mr President, the European Parliament is essentially debating the risk of nuclear annihilation of human civilization and I see colleagues here, some of them supporting Russia's position and others supporting the US position. The great events, the great disasters and the great dangers to humanity come quietly, and it is a pity that they are not even heard by the representatives of the European Union. In the event of the destruction of the planet, no one will have the opportunity to say that "I was right and I predicted it and I said it was the fault of this or that." The European Union - the European Parliament - must send a message to everyone about global disarmament with regard to nuclear weapons, not to mention other weapons. Mr Trump's withdrawal from the agreement and any behaviour by Russia, also reprehensible, must give us the impetus that together we can send the message, as the European Union, that we must destroy all the nuclear weapons at our disposal that can wipe out the planet thousands of times.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there are concerns all over the world about Trump's decision to leave the INF Treaty banning medium-range land-based ballistic missiles in Europe in 1987 by Reagan and Gorbachev. Trump essentially accuses the Russians of not complying with the agreement because of two battalions of New Tor cruise missiles, with a range of 1,500 kilometers, based on Russia's western borders. Moscow denies this, but Obama had already threatened to pull out of the treaty as early as 2014 because of tests on R500 missiles, also complaining about the deployment of Iskander ballistic missiles in the Russian enclave of Kaliningrad. However, the two Moscow installations are the answer to the start of the construction of the anti-missile shield that the US has deployed in Poland and the Czech Republic, equipped with radar and state-of-the-art missiles, officially to intercept any ballistic missiles launched by Iran. The decision to abandon the INF treaty announced by Trump seems to conceal even different motives. For Washington, denouncing the treaty means, above all, pressing for new negotiations with Moscow, but it must also be extended to Beijing, a true emerging strategic power. Denunciation of the treaty would trigger a new nuclear and ballistic rearmament race similar to that desired by Reagan, forcing Russia and China to do the same to undermine their economies, forcing them to invest more in defense than they could and would like.  Then there are not strictly military aspects that Trump seems to want to pursue. The White House appears to be pushing for an escalation of tension with Russia to unite an ever-further distant Europe, relaunching the protection offered by the American missile atomic umbrella. But is it really reassuring for Europe to upset the military balance on its territory?  (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Mr President, the Trump decision to withdraw from the Nuclear Arms Control Treaty demonstrates how dangerously competition between imperialist centres is escalating. This is not some soulless action by Trump, but a reflection of nato doctrine of the "first nuclear strike" and the recent summit to upgrade his nuclear strategy. On the other hand, Russia replies that it will be forced to target nuclear-hosted countries with retaliation. It turns out that he is determined – even in war – to reach every imperialist for his own interests. It turns out how dangerous it is for the people to have the decision of the SYRIZA-ANEL government and Mr. Tsipras, the friend of the "devilishly good" Trump as he calls him, to turn all of Greece into a vast American-NATO base and to transfer to its territory special weapons, even nukes, as in Araxos. The peace and life of the peoples are at immediate risk to the interests of the great powers. Their fight against NATO and the European Union is a condition for their survival.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Madam President-in-Office of the Council, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. On 20 October, President Trump announced the US withdrawal from the INF Treaty.  This announcement does not come out of the blue. The United States of America has expressed its reservations about Russia's violations of the INF Treaty 30 times since the Obama era. Russia's reaction: the construction of Russian cruise missiles, which are strictly prohibited in this INF Treaty. The planned meeting between Trump and Putin has not taken place since then. A possible end to the agreement could turn the current international nuclear order upside down and risk a nuclear arms race. That is the reality. We are now recognising that more and more political decisions are being taken against international law, political decisions against European law, political decisions against building trust. It must therefore be of concern to this Parliament that we all call on them to return to the ground of international agreements, to the basis of dialogue, to the basis of compliance with European and international law. The commemorations that we are all witnessing in our Member States – at the end of the First World War, eighty years of Hitler's invasion of Germany in Austria – clearly show us that we must still appeal today to learn the lessons of history. They clearly show us that we must take it seriously, with European action, with international dialogue, with multilateralism, so that we can overcome national selfishness and expansionist policies. And Chancellor Merkel appealed yesterday for us to take more care of our own security, so that we are not torn between the Trumps and the Putins of this world and that, at worst, our continent becomes a nuclear arena of vanity and irrationality again.  I therefore also ask the Presidency of the Council to help the Member States to support the Commission's proposals to reduce unanimity in foreign, security and defence policy, to strengthen European responsibility and to increase joint management and capacity to act. The alarm signals are lit. We must not move on to the agenda.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on the one hand, the world seems to be continuing on the road to disarmament and non-proliferation following the historic approval of the Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons, voted for by 122 countries and in the process of ratification, a treaty that, moreover, this Parliament formally supported in a 2016 resolution. The humanitarian approach to nuclear weapons is gaining ground, the consequences of which for those who hold them can also be truly terrible.  The USA and Russia, on the other hand, take us back to the years of the Cold War and strategic deterrence. President Trump's decision to withdraw from the Treaty on medium-range missiles, after years of suspected violations by Moscow, risks jeopardising the diplomatic action taken with multilateralism, as well as posing a real danger to European security. Moscow and Washington are thinking about the consequences of the failure of a treaty crucial to the true security of the world. Europe cannot but intervene in every possible way to prevent this truly dangerous drift.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, as Europeans we stand to lose most from the collapse of the INF Treaty, given that we are within range of Russian missiles. For Trump, it isn’t about pressurising Russia into compliance, it is about strategic competition with China and strengthening US military capabilities in the Pacific. That means the European security architecture is no longer, by definition, the US’s principal security interest. My questions were going to be for the External Action Service, but unfortunately there’s no representative here from them or the Commission. So I’m going to ask the Austrian Presidency this. Do you think we can still rescue the INF Treaty and, if not, what is the back—up plan for keeping nuclear missiles out of Europe? Secondly, are there any plans for a larger arms control framework that includes China and other states? Finally, how can the EU revive disarmament in the context of deep scepticism about arms control in China and in the US?

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: - Mr President, ma'am, President Trump's announcement of a possible breakdown of the Intermediate Scope Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty significantly undermines Euro-Atlantic security, as it is one of NATO's pillars. The INF prohibits the manufacture of ground-launched medium-range missiles, which can reach targets between 500 and 5,500 kilometers. Both Trump's announcement and Russia's alleged non-compliance, developing the Rookie 9M729 missile, are a deterioration of the arms control regime in Euro-Atlantic space that for decades has led to peace and stability. In recent years, the Union, through the various security strategies presented, as well as its leadership in the negotiations and implementation of the iran nuclear agreement, has shown its ability to be an international reference player in disarmament and non-proliferation policies. Tensions between the United States and Russia in the inF area can bring us back to the past, when the arms race was a constant source of international dangers and tensions. Quoting Gorbachev, "every agreement for nuclear disarmament must be maintained to save the life of the Earth." The Union needs to continue to promote non-proliferation policies and to make a place as a reference player. If the United States and Russia want to exercise irresponsibility, the Union must know how to act on the international stage to avoid the cold war, or not so cold.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: Mr President, Madam Minister, welcome back to the eighties!, the era of dial telephones, radio cassettes, telephone answering machine and minitel, here we are again. With Donald Trump's announcement that he wants to end the agreement between Washington and Moscow on the non-proliferation of nuclear weapons, we are back thirty years. This is a serious act. I would like to reiterate here the importance of the NIF Treaty (intermediate-range nuclear forces), as has been said, in particular for the security of our citizens, but also for the strategic stability of the European continent. If such a withdrawal takes place, it will call into question the fragile balance born of the rubble of the Cold War and have catastrophic consequences for the preservation of world peace. Mr President, Madam Minister, we're swimming in the middle of a bad soap opera in the middle of Dallas. It is time for Europe to regain its role of balance in the concert of nations and take the planet out of this bad step. Hence my simple question: what concrete action will the Union take to preserve the dialogue between the United States and Russia and to avoid the dismantling of this treaty?

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, President Trump’s decision to withdraw from the Intermediate-range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty has been widely criticised, for good reason. Former military officials described the treaty as a bedrock of arms control. The 1987 treaty eliminated thousands of deadly medium-range missiles in Europe, helping to end the Cold War. Scrapping the treaty will undermine international security, could prompt a new arms race and certainly increases the risks of a nuclear war.  I speak as a lifelong peace campaigner. The INF Treaty occupies a special place in peace history – in our history. It was prompted by the huge nuclear disarmament movements that swept across Europe and the USA in the 1980s. In some respects, the peace movement owns this treaty, and we must do what we can to ensure it is not taken away.  Let’s also remember that in this House, on 27 October 2016, we voted – by a large majority – to support the UN process to make nuclear weapons illegal. We subsequently honoured the international campaign to abolish nuclear weapons, which won the 2017 Nobel Peace Prize.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, at a time when the world is full of poor unemployed people and when enormous wealth is being generated but, of course, it is not distributed fairly, we have the intensity of international competition. The United States of America, China and Russia compete on the planet. It is now 'reasonable' what is happening, namely that they will no longer be bound by any of their so-called nuclear agreements. Mr Trump has withdrawn from the Treaty on Medium-Range Nuclear Forces, the Chinese are strengthening their equipment, and so is Russia. Unfortunately, the planet is at the mercy of the competition of these forces. I believe that a huge movement for global disarmament must be launched. That must be our goal: a ban on nuclear weapons all over the world. That is the only way we can respond and, of course, the citizens must be mobilised and must fight.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Mr President, my first child was born in 1987, and having grown up under the shadow of the mushroom cloud, I can remember the relief I felt at the disarmament process led by Mikhail Gorbachev and Ronald Reagan.  The Treaty on Intermediate-range Nuclear Forces (INF) in Europe that Trump is sabotaging dates from that era. It was a step on the path away from the Cold War and led to the destruction of 3000 missiles. Trump’s reckless actions could launch the world into a new, deadly arms race. This time, it would not be just between two superpowers, but open to any immoral regime that could find the cash to join in.  How can the European nuclear states argue that countries like Korea and Pakistan should not have the very nuclear weapons that they claim is so vital to their own security? As the actions of the authoritarians polarise the foreign policy debate, Britain and France should show leadership by unilaterally dismantling their nuclear weapons and signing up to the  International Campaign to Abolish Nuclear Weapons (ICAN) Treaty on the prohibition of such weapons, becoming the first UN Security Council members to do so.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: – Mr President, as a veteran of the Cold War and a sergeant major of the Soviet army, I am obliged to remind colleagues that Russian weapons – nuclear in particular – are a bluff. Remember submarine Kursk and aircraft carrier Admiral Kuznetsov.  But of course we face the problem that one of the security mechanisms of a nuclear conflict has disappeared, and we need to react. The correct reaction has been proposed by President Macron and Chancellor Merkel. Let’s create a proper and capable European defence force. That would be enough of a deterrent, and Russian nuclear disarmament, together with that of the United States, would follow consequently.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – Mr President, many academics today talk about us being post-fact in the so-called age. That is, at a time when it is possible to say almost everything without any fact-based it. I think Donald Trump is a beautiful example of this phenomenon. Not only do I often feel like I'm dreaming, but now it's all about what he does and what he says. In October, he announced that the United States would withdraw from its agreement with Russia to destroy medium- and short-range missiles, as Moscow is said to be violating it. By presenting evidence or calling for an investigation, Trump is not burdened or threatened directly. They say the road to hell is paved with good intentions. Very often, however, it is paved with the actions of egotistical political amateurs who overestimate their role on the international stage.  No one must threaten peace and international agreements. Peace is not thrown, peace is cared for. And that is the signal that we as the European Union must send.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the High Representative / Vice—President of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for this important exchange. I think it has highlighted the importance of the preservation of the Intermediate—Range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty for European and global security, as well as our common preoccupation with the increased threats to our security. Disarmament, arms control and non—proliferation treaties and agreements like the Treaty on the Non—Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT) and INF constitute our first line of defence. Dismantling such multilateral security arrangements and institutions is in nobody’s interest.  Because I was asked very explicitly, I would also like to answer the question as to whether I believe we can rescue the INF. Yes, of course, I do believe that. We mustn’t give up on that, and must put all our efforts into the rescue of the INF. I also believe that debates like the one today in the European Parliament remind people, including decision makers in Moscow and Washington, of the value of the INF Treaty for European and global security and the stake that we in Europe have in this treaty’s future.  By the way, the INF is only one contribution to Article 6 of the NPT, so a lot more has to be done in the future.  Allegations that the Russian Federation has begun producing and developing new missiles which could be aimed at EU countries, and which are not in compliance with Russia’s treaty obligations, deserve to be treated seriously and need to be resolved. This should happen through a responsible dialogue, including at the highest level. The stakes are simply too high.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162) – The INF Treaty on medium-range nuclear missiles is undoubtedly one of the best legacies received since the Cold War. Tearing it apart would be a huge risk to the security of Europe, its citizens and the world as a whole. However, after years of mutual accusations between Washington and Moscow, the scrapping by the former of the INF Treaty seems to be an increasingly real risk with unpredictable and dangerous consequences. Firstly, the possible abandonment of the Treaty by the US administration would further undermine relations between the US and Russia, increasing the cold war climate not only between these two powers but also with China. The latter, not being bound by the INF Treaty, was able to develop an arsenal of missiles otherwise not allowed and continued to do good and bad weather in the Chinese Seas. Finally, the unilateral American withdrawal from the INF would jeopardise the entire non-proliferation regime. In this context, the EU would be the first to pay the price, turning into the scene of a ruthless and dangerous arms race. Now more than ever, the EU must put in place all the diplomatic instruments necessary to promote a multilateral and inclusive arms control agreement.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: in writing. – The last thing we need is a new transatlantic arms race. The announcement by President Trump to withdraw from the Intermediate-range Nuclear Forces Treaty (INF Treaty) is a threat to European and global security and peace. The United States’ retreat from multilateralism, international norms and rules, as well as international treaties, should at least serve as motivation for us Europeans to foster a strong, self-assured common European foreign policy. Rather than quitting the Treaty, the United States should try to make Russia conform to its rules, as well as consider bringing other powers into the Treaty. Yes, we have to adapt to a changing international world order and should not only rely on instruments of the Cold War era. Instead of simply abolishing these instruments, we should expand and advance them to do justice to this changed strategic order and bring them into the 21st century. That is why it is important to have a strong actor like the EU, which is committed to multilateralism, a rules-based international order and the commitment to international treaties. However, for that we need a more effective, more unified and more credible European foreign policy.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the response to the caravan of migrants from Central America to the Border with Mexico (2018/2920(RSP)).

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, the ongoing caravans of migrants walking across Central America and Mexico turned public attention towards a silent exodus that has been ongoing for years. Every country in the world has every right to protect its borders and every country in the world has the obligation to do so in full respect of human rights and the principle of non—refoulement, as well as the norms on international protection. This applies to Europe and its Member States as it applies to everyone else, including the United States. But beyond looking at the consequences, let me take this opportunity also to also look at the symptoms. Every day, hundreds of people from Honduras, Guatemala and El Salvador begin the journey to the United States. Today migrants are more visible as part of caravans walking in broad daylight, accompanied by NGOs and TV crews. They are all fleeing poverty and hunger, but fear seems to be the main driver of these migrations.  The Northern Triangle countries are among the poorest in Latin America with one third, or even half, of the population living on less than EUR 5 a day. Half of the unemployed are young people so it is hardly surprising that many of them decide to leave their country and look for a better future. Natural disasters have also been a strong driver for migration from the region. Today they are aggravated by the dire effects of climate change, in particular droughts and floods. All these factors combine and today the migrants are also fleeing death, violence and extortion. Between 2010 and 2017, over 100 000 homicides were recorded in the Northern Triangle. It is probably no coincidence that the first of these recent caravans started in San Pedro Sula, which is one of the most violent cities in the world. The European Union has been supporting countries in the region in a twofold approach, providing immediate relief and tackling the root causes. In terms of humanitarian assistance, the Commission is implementing a program of EUR 2.5 million to address the needs of people affected by violence in the Northern Triangle. Concerning the caravan, the Commission is currently looking into possibilities to respond to humanitarian needs, in particular regarding the protection of vulnerable children and women against trafficking.  In Honduras we are investing about EUR 200 million in decent employment and food security, as well as strengthening the rule of law and access to justice. In Guatemala support amounting to over EUR 150 million is focused on food security, competitiveness security, security and human rights. In El Salvador we are investing about EUR 150 million. We support the national strategy to fight violence with a focus on prevention, including support to community organisations on the return of young people to the education system and on the construction of safe public spaces. The EU also funds social programmes such as ‘Ciudad Mujer’ an innovative approach to provide women with psychological and legal support and training for entrepreneurship. Efforts to address security challenges at national level go hand in hand with reinforced regional cooperation against transnational crime and drug trafficking. Regional cooperation is equally important for the development of the region, including the creation of economic opportunities. The Association Agreement between the EU and Central America opens our markets to Central American businesses. Once fully ratified, the political and cooperation dimensions of the Agreement will further reinforce our partnership. The EU is – and will remain – a reliable partner to the countries in the region in addressing the migration challenges, combining response to immediate needs with action on the root causes. Migration is a global challenge that requires global solutions and global responsibility sharing. Through international cooperation with our partners, we can turn migration from a common challenge into a shared opportunity for human development. I know that the Parliament has always supported this approach so I thank you for this debate and look forward to hearing your views.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the so-called migrant march departed on 13 October from the city of San Pedro Sula, and as the Commissioner said, one of the most dangerous cities in the world in northern Honduras, thousands of migrants from Guatemala and El Salvador have joined. Entire families walk in caravans, with their eyes set on the United States. According to Save the Children, one in four members of this caravan are children and adolescents.
