The lack of opportunities, extreme violence and endemic poverty in the northern triangle of Central America have led these families to leave their homeland and embark on this journey that, although arduous, offers more security than solitary migration and avoids paying thousands of dollars to smugglers. Many of these victims of economic misery and social exclusion also face persecution, hard-working recruitment and kidnapping by groups linked to organized crime, from the local Maras to transnational drug traffickers, a pattern that unfortunately now reproduces in Nicaragua too. These people are not criminals, as you can't get enough of repeating President Trump. They are, yes, victims of criminal organizations, who with violence and impunity pretend to govern them, and seek only to live in safety and find a job that will allow them to support their families, as they did in the 19th and 20th centuries, thousands of Europeans who went to the United States to flee violence, discrimination and hunger. President Trump, who in the 22 months of his presidency has demonized immigration, has promised to stop those now trying to reach his country on the pretext of protecting American citizens from criminals and an imminent invasion and announcing the deployment of troops to the southern United States and militarizing the border. The chances of them being granted asylum are therefore slim and many run the risk of being detained and separated from their families pending court hearings that could end with a deportation order. This migrant march and the one that formed from the city of Tapachula in southern Mexico last April show evidence that the hardening of asylum policies and mass deportations undertaken by the United States and Mexico in recent years have failed and their goal of deterring these flows and the announced cuts in economic aid to these countries will do nothing more than exacerbate the social chaos from which they are fleeing these people. The European Union must therefore continue to support regional integration efforts in Central America and to make the opportunity, within the framework of the Association Agreement with Central America, to strengthen political dialogue with the countries of the northern triangle with regard to respect for human rights, strengthening the rule of law and the fight against drug trafficking and impunity. The Union cannot fail to support the regional expansion of the UN anti-impunity commission and to urge transit and destination countries to respect their international human rights obligations on all cross-border crossings. I end, Mr. President, referring to the right to the life process of all migrants, regardless of their status, respect for the principle of non-return and the prohibition of arbitrary and collective expulsions.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr. President, do you know how many kilometers there are from the border of Honduras to that of the United States? More than 4,000 kilometers. It is, more or less, the distance between Lisbon and Istanbul. And that is the path that these people who flee from misery, despair, fear, are willing to travel. Among those 9,000 people who left on 19 October, more than 2,300 were children.  I want to talk about the children in that caravan, because they are the most vulnerable, because they are the ones who are suffering the most, because they are suffering dehydration and disease, because they are dying, because on the wall that separates Mexico from the United States there are hundreds of painted white crosses, which are the white crosses of children who have already died along the way.  That's the real situation. That is why we want to join unHCR's call by Save the Children to ask the United States to comply with international legality.  Children cannot be treated as criminals or drug traffickers. They have the right to international protection by our standards, and the United States is also required to comply with them.  Let the children remain children.

name: Jussi HALLA-AHO
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, many people on both sides of sides of the Atlantic have spent the past two years complaining how unattractive the US has become because of the Trump administration. It is a little difficult to take this seriously when we consider the number of people who are trying so hard to get there from Central America and other places.  The big question here is: what is a civilised country supposed to do when it is invaded by a large number of unarmed civilians? Can it be that it is not supposed to do anything? This is a very acute question in Europe as well. Instead of just condemning everything Mr Trump does, or plans to do, we should work to find an acceptable but efficient way of stopping illegal migrants from entering freely a country that does not want to have them.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, today, following what happened in this Parliament in the vote on the Humanitarian Visa Directive, I must begin by insisting that migration movements and their causes are a comprehensive issue which requires our utmost attention and responsibility. And it forces us to replace for facts the many words we usually hear about solidarity, fraternity, humanity, refuge or asylum. The first, in our case, is that those who consider that this Parliament's voting system has not adequately collected their votes correct the data in the relevant register. It will not serve to change the meaning of the vote, but it will at least bear witness to the true will of the house and legitimize that we can bring that matter here in the future. Self-criticism, assuming the mistake and correcting it without compromising the legal certainty of all our votes. And it's essential to do. People who leave their places of origin usually flee poverty, insecurity and violence. In the case of Central American caravans, the problems that lead to the exodus are clear. They are the fruit of inequality and an interventionist policy that has sometimes driven the country to which these people are addressed. A dynamic that has marked the sign of governments and economic and political systems. The problems of governance and democracy and their impact in terms of inequality and social justice are the breeding ground that makes some of the cities from which these caravans came today, as you said, Commissioner, the most violent in America. In the face of these problems there are those who buy the fake news and those who sell simple and Manichean schemes, which offer too many people the peace of mind of knowing among the good ones and that allow to justify any atrocity against others, who easily end up being the bad guys. For the president of the United States to play this game so crudely, to the point that the most conservative television networks reject their ads about these caravans as racist, is an indicator of how far populism has come. I hope you'll teach us. Moreover, this fallacy, this rude simplification can ward off some uncertainty to which it buys such a broken commodity, but offers no solution. There is international law to respect. And, as the philosopher Daniel Innerarity said in a newspaper article, a democracy to reschedule. Shared responsibility, limits and interests must be answered to the complexity of problems. I'm sorry, President, let me conclude by saying that the first of ... (The president withdrew the floor to the speaker.)

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the first members of the migrant caravan recently arrived from Honduras on the border with the United States. It has already been said: most are fleeing violence and the risk of being killed or starved to death. Continuing in his country put his own life and that of his relatives at risk. For most of them, then, it is a forced displacement.  That's where we're talking about human rights first and foremos.com. The Governments of Mexico and the United States should inform these people—which they do not do—that they can apply for asylum or shelter.  In any case, they should be a guaranteed that their basic needs are met and that their rights are respected, because neither Mexico nor the United States should deal with the issue of the migrant caravan from a repressive or criminalizing approach, which promotes xenophobia, but from a human rights-based approach. Mexico's president-elect now has the opportunity to begin his term with a firm commitment to human rights.  And I can't resist expressing a suspicion: that this huge march has begun some week before the U.S. mid-term election has been able to reinforce President Trump's loathsome xenophobic arguments. I do not blame the members of the march at all, but I wonder if there may have been petty interests in promoting the timetable for its realization.  In any case, our support for the caravan and the migrants for their dignity and for ours.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, the thousands of caravans are fleeing the worsening social and economic conditions in their country and the violence of the death squads, a reality that is not disconnected from the coup d'état in Honduras in 2009, promoted since the United States, or from the results of the fraudulent 2017 elections, which were covered up by the European Union. This dramatic situation has, in its causes, the strategy of destabilisation and interference in sovereign countries, led by the United States as well as the European Union, imposing relations of economic dominance and prey of resources that promote underdevelopment and dependence. Alongside a swift and supportive response to the humanitarian dramas of migration, the key response to migration flows is to attack the causes that lead to millions of human beings around the world being forced to leave their countries. It involves respect for the sovereignty and independence of states, the Charter of the United Nations, international law. It involves genuine development cooperation policies that ensure rights, social progress and peace.

name: Nathan GILL
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, the entire world has been gripped by the migration crisis. It’s not just in the European Union, but it’s also in the United States. We share a common challenge when it comes to dealing with the millions of people who are trying to illegally cross borders. In recent weeks, the United States has seen a migrant caravan consisting of thousands of people travelling from Central America to the US border. We’re witnessing an organised mass migration of economic migrants on a scale that has never been seen before and this, quite simply, is economic migration. Both here and in the EU and over there in the US there are legitimate and legal routes for seeking genuine asylum, but these migrant caravans should not lead to permanent residence in the US. It has been said in this debate that they are not criminals. But if you enter a country illegally, you are breaking laws and you are therefore a criminal. I think President Trump is right to send thousands of US troops to the border to stop the illegal entry of the migrants and to protect their national security.  Let’s just point out that the migrants are now in Mexico. Why are they not staying in Mexico? There are 129 million people who live in Mexico quite happily. Are we saying that everybody in Mexico should be leaving Mexico to go to America as well because it’s unsafe there, or are we saying that the migrants should stay in Mexico now that they are there?  While some argue that the numbers of migrants in the caravan are small, they set a precedent and encourage others to make this dangerous journey to the US. Since 2017, multiple caravans have headed to the border, and each time they are getting bigger and bigger. On our own soil we have seen the effects of mass migration, especially the terrible death toll of migrants crossing turbulent seas in boats completely unfit for that purpose. International law is being broken and EU treaties are just being ignored. A government’s main duty is the protection and the security of its citizens. This includes securing your nation’s border – it’s just common sense. Leaders in Europe would do well to learn from President Trump’s response to what’s happening at the US border instead of just continually pointing their fingers and complaining.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, over and above the humanitarian aspects that move everyone, this march in fact responds to a strategy with a very specific aim, which is to unhinge states by opening up large migratory routes from the Third World to the so-called first world. High finance gurus push NGOs and fund them to use third world populations as a tool to colonize the first world, to reduce wages and create political instability. With the support of the UN, they are now westernising these populations, turning them into political rams, in an attempt to ensure that the first world of which Europe is an integral part should also be aware of them, and the Commission should think better. The phenomenon of caravans revives the theme of the meaning of the value of borders which, as Régis Debray rightly theorized, have an irreplaceable function of filtering and therefore of defending the identity of peoples. Walls are not a degeneration, but they are a consequence of the rejection of demarcation and the defence of identity.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the NGO Movimiento Migrant Mesoamericano has stated that 70 % of migrants from Central America, when they cross into Mexico to reach the United States, are raped and raped. The human body is used as a means of exchange to be offered to unscrupulous border policemen. Anything to escape the hunger, violence and corruption that countries such as Honduras and Guatemala are imbued with. It is a caravan of about 3 000 people, full of hope, because nothing can be worse than what has been left behind. Spotting the wave of despair, Trump thought well to arm the border, no matter how much his policies toward the rest of the continent aggravated the situation. I would remind you of the 40 % cut in funds for Honduras, Guatemala and El Salvador, which reduced economic opportunities by making citizens even more vulnerable. The elimination of temporary work permits in the United States for Salvadorans and Hondurans has also contributed to the impoverishment of those countries by reducing remittances. I mean, the opposite of what it would take. We need sensible policies which should provide for increased cooperation between the countries of North and South America. We need a clear immigration and asylum policy that is also applied consistently by the United States of America.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to express our solidarity with the caravan of men, women and children fleeing misery, fleeing violence in Honduras, Guatemala, El Salvador. I would also like to denounce the attempts at criminalization of this caravan—when we are simply facing a phenomenon of forced migration—and, in a very clear way, the statements and militaristic spoothing that the US Administration is making led by Mr Trump and reminding it that, to a large part, the misery that many of the countries in its immediate vicinity are now living in has to do with their lack of commitment to cooperation , because of the cuts in funds and because of its lack of an immigration integration policy. What can we do about the current caravan as the European Union? Two things: the first, to remind, through our external action, the Member States concerned, the States in the area concerned, that they have obligations under humanitarian law and that they must comply with them; and secondly, to rethly rethly whether our policies and our relationship with the area—with Central America—really contribute to the development of these countries, which is very dubious. And above all, Mrs Jourová, and with this I conclude, I would like to invite you to be very attentive to the possible phenomena of trafficking in women and trafficking in children that may occur in this situation.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: – Madam President, Central America is experiencing a profound humanitarian crisis. The migrant caravan is a brutal image of despair. Thousands of people, mostly Hondurans, children, women, young people, older people, want to flee and seek asylum. The first ones left Honduras on October 12, yesterday 357 arrived in Tijuana and there are thousands on the way. Corruption, organized crime, drug trafficking, which cross the entire political spectrum, and the recent worsening of state violence and impunity are the main causes that lead people to flee one of the poorest and most violent countries in the region. The United States has organized itself to militarize borders and threaten with cuts in support. All this violates the most elementary defense of human rights. The European Union is expected to match the support to a real commitment of the authorities, with the necessary reforms that recover the well-being and defence of the people, as well as the assistance to those who need it. These caravans are also a form of struggle: they are people who walk against abandonment and against the amnesia of history.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: – Madam President, what do these thousands of human beings, men, women, old people, children, who are part of this caravan, flee? They flee the threat of death, flee violence, flee the spectre of hunger, flee from deeply inhumane situations that unfortunately plague much of Central America and, in particular, Honduras. And so our first look has to be on this region and we need to strengthen our cooperation with Central America and contribute to overcoming the very serious problems that are in this region of the world.  On the other hand, they demand the United States and we Europeans are aware of how complex and difficult this issue of refugees is. But we must also always appeal to fundamental humanitarian principles. It is unacceptable to react like that which the current President of the United States, Trump, has systematically verbalized, with the support, moreover, of the most sordid and repugnant extreme—European right. It is therefore necessary to draw attention to the need to respond to these situations, which are mainly humanitarian situations, with a deep sense of humanism, which is the basis of all the values that inspire or should inspire our political intervention.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: – Madam President, for the first time the world is watching the invisible.  The invisible have become visible because they have been organized in a migrant caravan; they are visible because they have decided to make immigration transit a protest against injustice, a protest against a life of precariousness, a life of violence from which they flee, a life that is a direct consequence of our policies.  Would we stand before this migrant caravan if we hadn't looked the other way when the coup d'am in Honduras?  Now, what do we do? We look the other way again when these people experience violence in their transit; we look the other way when all they are offered are weapons, concertinas and the militarization of borders.  We demand urgent humanitarian aid. We demand that Trump be kept at a stop and we demand that the European Parliament send an observation mission to that caravan so that human rights are respected and the right to asylum of all is respected.  May the invisible never be invisible again: they are not numbers, they are people.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Madam President, there are seven thousand people, including two thousand and three hundred children, who are touring Mexico to find a future of hope. People coming from the Northern Triangle, from three Central American countries that have entered for decades into an endless spiral of violence and poverty. A black hole for many, from which they try to escape. And what happened? That while this was happening, there was an election campaign in America. And there has been a president, the American, who has decided to use them as hostages to his election campaign. Dehumanize them, demonize them, threaten them with the military use of force against them. With the sole aim of winning a handful of votes in that election. That's why he's now also disappeared from the American agenda. And what needs to be done is to remind its president, the United States, of its human rights and international law obligations. And the need for you to remember that your country is built on migration as the identity and fruit of it. That's America. And it seems that today they forget it in the face of the world.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, why be surprised? Seven thousand people – men, women and children – from Honduras, Guatemala and El Salvador are nothing more than symbols of global mobility. Unfortunately, President Trump's response has been the suspension of the right of asylum and the mobilization of an army on the Mexican border, placing a barrier to stop those who may have the right to asylum and protection. Closing policies must be responded with solidarity and also with multilateral instruments for the proper management of mobility, such as the United Nations Global Compact on Migration, which the United States has refused to sign and which other European states are questioning. To President Trump and those like him who applaud the closure of borders and the ban on free movement, I would like to remind you of the principle of the portability of rights. Fundamental human rights do not stop in front of a barricade, but are intrinsic to the person himself wherever he is, and it is our duty to guarantee and defend them always in every part of the world.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Madam President, the suspension of the right of asylum and the sending of military personnel to the border by the President of the United States is an affront, from the outset, to the magnificent tradition, to the magnificent history of the United States and also to the very role that the United States has had in the construction of the international building of universal human rights. These people are not economic migrants, they flee miserable living conditions, they flee persecution, they flee crime on the loose in their countries, in Central America, they run away from situations for which the United States has serious responsibility for interventionist, commercial, economic and clumsy policies. And so this attitude on the part of the United States is not tolerable and we Europeans need to speak, not to speak as the far right completely in the shiver of civilization that comes here to deny the humanity of these people and the right to seek asylum in the face of the conditions they come from.  We must have development policies for Central America and the rest of the world, particularly in Africa, that are genuinely developed and that go through democratic construction, because else, in this interdependent and increasingly mobile world, we will have more caravans of this kind.

name: Wajid KHAN
text: – Madam President, as we speak, 7000 people walk towards the United States of America in search of a better life. These people are from some of the poorest and most violent countries in the region, and Trump will greet them with a barbed wire fence and the strongest army in the entire world. I have previously spoken here about the barbarity of the current American administration when they were forcibly separating children from their parents at the border. Now they are brutally closing down the door down on desperate people who want to contribute to their economy. We welcome Mexico’s ‘Estás en tu casa’ programme, which provides healthcare and jobs to those migrants who wish to stay – exactly what the USA and the EU should be doing. The Statue of Liberty welcomed the world’s huddled masses yearning to breathe free. I hope everyone in this Chamber will agree with me, and call for the USA to honour this. The USA must respect the principle of non—refoulement and welcome those who are fleeing desperate situations as fellow human beings. Only by doing this can Trump truly make America great again.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, thousands of poor families and unaccompanied children from Central America are on the move, travelling to the Mexican USA border fleeing violence, poverty and unsustainable lives. 38—year—old José Vega, who is travelling with the caravan from Honduras, said: ‘My hope is someday to build a house for my family to live in peace, to go from sandals to shoes – not to be rich, but to be in peace’. Isn’t that the simple desire of all of us? President Trump’s cruel response, however, is sadly predictable. He has threatened military violence and he uses the racist, xenophobic language that has become a hallmark of his presidency. Trump has become the bully in the school playground. He has scant regard for human rights and uses his position to stir up hate. He is unfit for public office, and he shames his country by his words and actions.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: – Madam President, last week I had the opportunity to visit Guatemala's border with Mexico, in the city of Tecún Umán, on the banks of the Suchiate River.  The humanitarian overflow situation there is totally unsustainable. The Migrant House accommodates 120 people without any national or international assistance. Meanwhile, in a week, 6,000 migrants have passed through that area.  The situation of violence and vulnerability is also dramatic throughout the journey. The border area is an area of crime, sexual exploitation and violence. Mexico's police action without going any further, which has U.S. support right now, has already killed three people alone at this border crossing.  And you will ask yourself: What does the U.S. military do on Mexican territory? For the same thing european funds are doing in Libyan coastguards: outsourcing borders, pushing away violence against migrants where they cannot see or judge what they are doing.  Migration is a right, Commissioner, the free transit of people is a right; and we should start by adopting, complying with and enforcing the Global Compact for Migration agreements.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, as we all know, last month a caravan of some seven thousand migrants, starting in Honduras, finally arrived at the border with the United States of America in search of better living conditions. There is no doubt that living conditions in the Central American states, as in many other states, are not the most appropriate. However, this does not mean that the inhabitants of these countries must leave en masse and, in the form of an invasion, try to enter the nearest prosperous country. In other words, this is the case with the migratory flows that we in Europe are also receiving. But the US government has done the obvious: it has controlled its borders - unlike us - and is controlling the flows of these migrants. If we really care - apart from the hypocritical humanism of the Left - about these people, we should work together to create the right living conditions in their own country. To live and prosper there and not to flee to other countries.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for the fruitful exchange. We all agree that every country has the right to manage its borders. We also agree that migrants’ human rights should be fully upheld. Special attention should be given to the needs of the most vulnerable, including children and women, and, importantly, we also agreed that tackling the root causes of migration, including poverty, citizens’ security and governance—related, is essential. The EU will continue to closely follow the situation and use all the instruments available to support the countries of origin, to provide security and a future to their populations.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the extraterritorial effects of US sanctions on Iran for European companies (2018/2922(RSP)).

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, last week the United States unilaterally re-imposed all the sanctions that they had removed thanks to the nuclear deal with Iran, the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action. On 2 November, the High Representative issued a statement together with the Foreign and Finance Ministers of Germany, France and the United Kingdom, expressing deep regret at this development. The sanctions re-imposed on 5 November cover a wide array of sectors and, together with the designation of some 700 individuals and entities, impact large parts of the Iranian economy. As such, they are a serious challenge to the continued implementation of the plan of action.  The re-imposition of US sanctions may also bring substantial collateral effects, in particular it could weigh on the region’s trade flows and energy supplies, connectivity and ultimately the security and stability of states such as Iraq and Afghanistan.  Let me begin this debate with a few general comments. First, we continue to support the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action as its provisions continue to ensure that Iran does not acquire material or equipment to develop a nuclear weapon. The deal with Iran is working and delivering on its goal, namely ensuring that Iran’s nuclear programme remains exclusively peaceful. This is an assessment based on scientific facts provided through a uniquely high number of inspections and 13 reports by the International Atomic Energy Agency. Moreover, there is no credible peaceful alternative to the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action. The deal with Iran is a key element of the global nuclear non-proliferation architecture. It is crucial for the security of Europe, the region and the entire world. Dismantling the agreement would not only destroy years of diplomatic efforts but also undermine other key multilateral negotiations in the nuclear field and beyond.  It is a matter of security and it is a matter of credibility for the international community. For these reasons, the EU and its Member States are determined to preserve it. We remain committed to the continued implementation of the nuclear deal in all its aspects and in particular we are at work to preserve the economic dividends arising from sanctions lifting. Let me remind everyone that we are talking about economic benefits for the people of Iran which constitute an essential part of the deal. As we remain committed to our side of the deal we also expect Iran to continue implementing in full all its nuclear commitments under the plan of action. The European Union has already taken a number of measures. First, we have updated our blocking statute to ensure that business decisions are not determined by the listed US extra-territorial legislation, which the Union does not recognise as applicable to EU operators. The Commission has significantly engaged with economic operators and Member States on the implementation of the statute.  Second, we have extended the European Investment Bank’s lending mandate. This allows the bank to lend in Iran in the future in line with relevant rules and procedures.  Thirdly, the European Commission is elaborating a range of tools to strengthen the activities of small and medium sized enterprises between the EU and Iran. We are working on technical exchanges to enhance trade, harmonisation of standards and due diligence and compliance efforts.  I am aware of the high level of interest regarding the design and state of play of the special-purpose vehicle. We Europeans cannot accept that a foreign power, not even our closest friend and ally, takes decisions over our legitimate trade with another country. The ongoing work, led by France, Germany and the United Kingdom, aims at preserving the full and effective implementation of the plan of action in all its aspects and in line with UN Security Council Resolution 2231. Protecting legitimate trade is also a basic element of our own sovereignty and it is only natural that we are working in this direction. This is a hugely complex and unique undertaking requiring the best expertise available. Technical work has been advancing over the last days and weeks under the political leadership of Member States and supported by the EEAS and the Commission. Our goal is to build something that is workable, effective and viable. The special-purpose vehicle is not directed against the United States. On the contrary, preserving the nuclear deal is essential to our common security both for Europe, for the United States and for our friends in the Middle East. The special-purpose vehicle is not circumventing sanctions. It is about working in full transparency, ensuring due diligence for the most rigorous standards on anti-money laundering and on countering the financing of terrorism in full respect of UN Security Council resolutions and the primacy of the EU law. I am aware that many of you have concerns regarding Iran’s foreign policy and respect for human rights. So does the European Commission, but the Plan of Action was never meant to solve all of our disagreements with Iran. We continue to voice our disagreements on Iran’s security role in the region and its ballistic missile programme and we have engaged in a frank and active dialogue with Iran on these issues. We maintain a range of EU autonomous restrictive measures. These include an arms embargo and measures against arms trade, against human rights violations, on Iran’s support for the Assad regime in Syria and for terrorism.  Some of these issues are addressed through our EU-Iran high-level dialogue. The EU has also led a dialogue together with France, Germany, Italy and the UK to engage Iran constructively on regional issues. The last meeting of this group was convened in Brussels on 12 September and discussed the situation in Syria and Yemen, and we hope to meet again before the end of the year.  This is also very much about our own security and regional security, but none of these issues is linked to the Plan of Action and they would not be easier to deal with without it. Preserving the nuclear deal with Iran is an essential security interest for Europe, for our region and for the whole world. So we will keep working to preserve a nuclear non-proliferation agreement that is working well, and to prevent a major security crisis in the Middle East.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, my conviction is that the European Union cannot properly answer the question of the extraterritorial effects that US sanctions against Iran can have on European companies, if we do not put this issue in the broader political context of our political relations with Iran. The situation we find ourselves in today, which obliges us to defend the economic interests of European companies, is, in my view, also the consequence of an insufficient political response. We supported the need to continue the implementation of the nuclear agreement with Iran as long as iran complied with its obligations, long before the U.S. withdrawal. The delegation of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, of which I was a member, who visited Tehran in February, carried this message. The reality is that before the decision of the United States on May 8 to withdraw from the agreement, we had some leeway to seriously discuss with the U.S. government its concerns about the nuclear agreement and to find a solution that would have saved us from today's discussion. My first conclusion is that it is not too late. We should have a serious discussion with the United States. Cooperation with them remains vital to respond to Iran. The challenges we face together are many: curbing Iran's nuclear ambitions, improving the dire human rights situation in that country, and addressing issues of Iran's harmful role in the conflict in Syria, threats to the State of Israel, the Iranian regime's support for terrorism and plans to attack European soil. All these subjects have become almost taboo, including in our Parliament, where any attempt to discuss human rights in Iran is systematically blocked by our socialist friends. To defend the interests of European companies, the answer cannot be found in purely economic action, whether it is the establishment of a special entity or the assistance given to Iran to respond to the consequences of US sanctions. Above all, it must be in a coherent political action which, I stress on this point, does not isolate the various aspects of our relations with Iran and does not exclude the building of bridges with the Trump administration on this subject, but again our friends on the left do not displease them. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8 of the regulation)).

name: Ana GOMES
text: 'blue card' question. It seems to me that we both participated in the Foreign Affairs Committee's mission to Iran this year. You can probably confirm here that it was certainly I, a socialist member of this delegation, who asked the most questions about human rights to our Iranian interlocutors. I therefore categorically refute the accusation you have made against the Socialists.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: answer 'blue card'. "Of course I have an answer. Ana has always been an exception within the Socialist Group, whether it is Iran and the issue of rights or, for example, socialist parties in the east, and in particular the Romanian Social Democratic Party. She has always had a straight stance on this subject as well as on human rights and the terrible fate of socialism in the East.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done I would like to focus on the heart of the discussion. The Iran nuclear deal was one of the most intensively prepared multilateral treaties of recent times. For years, various parties have been intensively discussing Iran's withdrawal from its nuclear program. This not only eliminated a constantly smouldering threat of war, but also laid the ground for peaceful development. The resulting removal of economic sanctions should end the isolation of Iran's economy, generate economic win-win, and lay the foundation for domestic prosperity. The hope was that this could also create a new stability zone in a region that has been uneasy for decades. This would be particularly essential for Europe. The European Union also plays an essential role in the conclusion of the Treaty, and it is in the interests of the Union and its Member States that the process does not stall. The Iranian side has so far taken all its commitments seriously. All international controls have so far confirmed this – twelve times in a row. Why the process is not really progressing, and more and more companies are reluctant to engage economically, is mainly due to the fact that the US, under Trump's influence, has abandoned multilateralism. US unilateralism is a major challenge, not just on the Iran issue. That is why we must stand by our agreements, without ifs and buts. Measures such as the activation of the blocking statute are necessary. Confidence-building measures must also be put in place, but mere assertions do not take us any further.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) is far from being a good deal. Iranian companies – our partners in trade – are heavily controlled by the Revolutionary Guard – the organisation directly responsible for financing terrorism, bloody martyrs and meddling in the region. Moreover, there is money laundering present in the Iranian economy – that was admitted even by Foreign Minister Zarif himself in the Iranian Parliament. We have to take all of this into consideration.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), or the nuclear deal that was agreed by the major global powers at a critical time, was actually fatally damaged by President Trump’s withdrawal. But that doesn’t mean that there’s nothing we can do and that all is lost. A reduced nuclear agreement may still work, but I think we, in Europe, have to be realistic.  Of course, High Representatives Ashton and Mogherini stuck out their necks for diplomacy, and that was the right thing to do, but preserving that legacy cannot be a goal in and of itself because it also had a shadow side. I think human rights and the violations that we see every day in Iran, as well as Iran’s troubling role in the Middle East, were overlooked, and rebalancing our European approach towards Iran is very important and should not be hindered by needing to defend the JCPOA. Attempts to maintain policy independence and to give European companies maximum choice to do business are the right steps to take; they are positive. The EU lifted sanctions as it’s part of the deal, while Iran commits to verification of nuclear enrichment. But to push or even punish European companies for choosing to drop business with Iran under threat of US repercussions is taking it too far. Additionally, the whole impression that the EU and Iran are in one sort of camp and that the United States is in another camp is deplorable. We are both liberal democracies, and that should be leading. I think the way forward for us in Europe is to broaden our Iran policy and to include, very ambitiously, human rights and foreign policy concerns while continuing to take reasonable steps to stay committed to our part of the nuclear agreement.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report and for the Of course, we share the deep regret that has been expressed. However, I also deeply regret the fact that we are not able to use realistic language, but are constantly glossing over the situation. No one has any of that yet. The so-called blocking statute is ridiculous! Not a single international group can afford to rely on it. That is why I believe we should start taking ourselves more seriously – including the weaknesses we have. One of the weaknesses, in my view, is that, although we are right to maintain the nuclear deal with Iran, we have no reason to gloss over the negative aspects of Iranian foreign policy as you have done, Commissioner. You said: We voice these agreements, and we have frank and active dialogue. Can't think of more? Is this appropriate to Iran's foreign policy? I very much doubt that. Secondly, we will have to work here with the Chinese and with the Russians, because at this specific point the Americans are moving into a position that we cannot stand. Nevertheless, we are not suddenly in a camp with Iran, China and Russia. What we need to develop is greater European autonomy. This also means advancing the role of the euro internationally.  And what I want to say last, Mr Preda: who simply says: 'We have serious discussions with the US'. That's not a serious person, sorry, forgive me.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Trump's sanctions put the nuclear agreement at risk and violate the pacta sunt servanda principle. The unilateral reinstatement of sanctions, as a result of the US withdrawal from the agreement, is an act of international piracy, diplomatic bullying, unacceptable bullying of the entire international community and has nothing to do with human rights, as shown by the fact that nothing is being done against Saudi Arabia and its regime, indeed arms are being sold to it for the war in Yemen. Iran has been subjected to the world's most comprehensive monitoring and surveillance regime by the International Atomic Energy Agency, which has repeatedly verified Iran's compliance with its obligations under the agreement. It is also the sanctions that affect the population and not the regime, and the European Union will do well to defend the agreement, not only through instruments that guarantee the possibility for European companies to trade with Iran and thus to follow up the agreement that otherwise risks falling, but also, if necessary, by providing European counter-sanctions for American companies and by starting to use the euro for our energy bill.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, you may or may not be a Trump fan, but at least President Trump does not allow politically correct thinking to muddy his vision when dealing with some of the world’s worst tyrants. He understands how these people think, and he acts in what he believes to be the best interests of his country. The US believes that the deal is a bad one, one which is not built upon long—term stability. Whether or not this is the case, we are now in the de facto situation where the Iran deal no longer exists. Iran is considering abandoning the terms set out in the deal, as it sees no economic benefit from adhering to them – a very worrying development.  Clearly, a solution needs to be found to the problem, either by saving the existing agreement or producing something new. The EU must forget about posturing power politics and allow the USA to get on with its own foreign policy. After all, you do not have your own EU army yet to enforce your ideas. The Iranian President has even suggested that the country now faces a war situation, and air defence drills have been taking place. This is obviously extremely concerning. It not only impacts trade and business, but of course on the humanitarian level as well.  In 1998, the US and the EU had similar issues with sanctions, this time involving Cuba. An agreement was struck and the sanctions were lifted. Again the EU must work alongside the US to solve this Iran problem. The United States are not the enemy, and they must not be treated as such. It would be wise to remember the many great sacrifices the American people made during the 20th century in order to promote freedom and peace in Europe. Any thoughts of a potential EU trade war with the US are delusions of grandeur and nothing more.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue—card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: blue-card question. – Mr Agnew, would you concede that the Iranian leadership has so far stuck to the letter and the spirit of the agreement, so it is not justified to blame them for deviating from that, as you did?

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: blue-card answer. – No, I’m not that naive. Thank you.

name: Jacques COLOMBIER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, beyond the fine words and wishful thinking, I will go to the heart of the problem for Europe. French companies, and not least, particularly invested in the promising Iranian market, have recently had to give up their investments in that country. This is particularly the case for car manufacturers PSA and Renault, but also for Total, which has been present in Iran since 1954. French and European companies are actually paying for the passivity, if not the complicity, of the Brussels leaders with the oukases of successive American administrations. In the 1990s, no one in The European circles had expressed alarm at the scope of the Amato-Kennedy Law, which the United States is currently reactivating against the European Union after its unilateral decision to pull out of the Geneva agreement on the Iranian nuclear. Today, alas, we see the result. By giving everything to Washington, we end up bowing to these legal forfeitures. So, a firmer attitude on trade negotiations, the end of any alignment with Washington's exclusive interests as the exit of this stupid policy of confrontation with Russia could send... (the President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I’m sorry, sir, but your time is up. We didn’t hear the rest of your contribution because I had to cut the microphone.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I believe that we are united on Iran's foreign policy. But that is not the issue today. I am horrified – every day again – by the American President, who betrays almost everything that the Americans taught us Germans after the Nazi era. I grew up in Berlin in the 1950s. I can't be an anti-American. I will be eternally grateful to them. But that is why it is all the more painful that this partnership is suffering so much at the moment. The United States has withdrawn from the agreement for no good reason, and we have just received confirmation of this from the authorities investigating it. They are supposed to be the harshest sanctions of all time. They are sanctions against our European small and medium-sized enterprises; the big ones do not take this risk at all. In this respect, we urgently and soon need special purpose vehicles to help small and medium-sized enterprises, which want to continue to work with Iran. Commissioner, you said that it is not against the United States. You said that it is not a way of circumventing the sanctions. What you have said is wrong. Of course, it is directed against the United States, which threatens our companies, and, of course, it is there to circumvent unjustified sanctions! Europe is slowly waking up thanks to Mr Trump. I would ask you to wake up.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Madam President, The American sanctions are against twelve successive confirmations that Iran is meeting its commitments under the nuclear agreement. The last one, from the IEA, arrived for us yesterday.  Trump and his administration are sorry that the sanctions will not affect the Iranian people. Essential medicines and food are already scarce. Prices skyrocket, inflation adds to a rampant devaluation. The sanctions also affect the Iranian airline, which is prevented from refuelling at European airports, calling into question the safety of all Iranians, as well as those visiting the country, including Europeans and Americans. And, perversely, this attack on the Iranian people pushes him further into the arms of the regime's most radical forces. It does not help sectors of society that courageously fight for human rights and who fight for democratic change. The updating of the blocking legislation and the creation of a special purpose vehicle, provided for by Mrs Mogherini, must be supported. Member States need to agree to ensure that this mechanism has legal personality and begins to operate as soon as possible. This is a question of international security and our own credibility in the GSPOA guarantee.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I do not think That Trump will win his bet with Iran. With the withdrawal of the nuclear agreement and the start of sanctions, the US Administration has made three bets: stop uranium enrichment, force the other signatories to withdraw their membership, penalising European companies, and bring down the Iranian regime under economic pressure. Realistically, he won't win the third bet above all. As many observers have pointed out, the nuclear agreement had favoured the moderate part led by President Rohani to the detriment of the conservative side, the Supreme Leader Khamenei. The reintroduction of sanctions will only play into the game of ultraconservatives, those who have always been opposed to dialogue with the United States and the West in general. That is why it is difficult for the sanctions imposed by Trump to stimulate major changes in Iranian policy, if not for the worse, for human rights as well. For all this, I believe that Europe must not be afraid and must pursue its cooperation with Iran to the full, certainly by asking the questions it must ask, but with strength and determination.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, by unilaterally denouncing the joint comprehensive action plan and declaring the re-establishment of sanctions on Iran, President Trump has not only exacerbated tensions in the Middle East but has increased the European Union's responsibility for the defence of global security. Although imperfect, especially for leaving out Iran's ballistic missile test programme, the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action is a historic instrument on multilateral diplomacy and is an important milestone for global nuclear disarmament, as attested by twelve consecutive reports by the International Atomic Energy Agency that monitor iran's compliance with its obligations in this regard. Therefore, Commissioner, I would like to greet Mrs Mogherini for the firmness with which she has advocated the maintenance of this agreement, but I hope that the operationalisation of instruments to circumvent the effects of US sanctions on institutional and trade relations with the Mullahs regime, such as the announced special purpose vehicle, will continue to be conditioned by progress in the field of human rights. Let us not forget that we continue to deal with an undemocratic and oppressive regime that does not refuse to torture and murder its own citizens.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, first of all, we must not embellish the role of Iran, nor of course of the United States. It is obvious that the US and the European Union have opposing political, economic and military interests in the case of Iran. It is obvious that the European Union - and especially France - has made significant investments in Iran, in the car industry and in energy issues with Total. The main issue, however, is that US sanctions against Iran are extraterritorial, i.e. they apply against those European companies that do not follow United States sanctions. This is clearly the logic of the global 'constable' that the United States has, which they think can do whatever they want. It is a neo-colonial concept and practice. The European Union must react. The Blocking Statute is a first step, but there must be countermeasures by the European Union vis-à-vis the United States in order to stop this extraterritorial intervention by the United States.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, the reintroduction of The United States of America's sanctions against Iran affects important and crucial sectors of Iran's economy, such as oil exports, the automotive industry, air transport and, above all, also affects the trade of European companies with those of Iran. In this sense, the European Union welcomes European companies trading with Iranian companies to ignore these United States sanctions. However, I cannot imagine a way in which the European Union can guarantee the protection of the interests of these companies. There must be cooperation with the United States and an agreement with Iran to convince the United States that the European Union's contacts and support for Iran are not directed against the interests of the United States. In addition, the European Union should also consider imposing sanctions on American companies if things go too far.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, this has been a very useful exchange and I thank the honourable Members for their interventions. From this debate I conclude that we share a common interest in using the diplomatic power and instruments of the EU and its Member States to their full potential in support of preserving and implementing the joint comprehensive plan of action, which is vital for EU and international security. May I close by signalling once again my appreciation of Parliament’s role in keeping this important issue on its agenda.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Colleagues, our next sitting is tomorrow, Thursday, 15 November at 9.00. The agenda has been published and is available on the European Parliament website.  You may know that the United Kingdom Cabinet has agreed the draft Brexit withdrawal deal earlier this evening. It has just been published, and some of us may spend the evening reading the 585 pages of that text.
